PROCTEXT.PARA: The PRESIDENT (Senator the Hon. Harold Young) took the chair at 10.30 a.m., and read prayers.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: LAJOVIC

TALK.START.PARA: —I present the following petition from 23 citizens of Australia:

SPEECH.PARA: To the Honourable the President and Members of the Senate, in Parliament assembled:

The humble petition of the undersigned citizens of Australia respectfully showeth that your petitioners are gravely concerned at proposed future hydro-electric developments in South West Tasmania. As this area is on the Register of the National Estate it is therefore of national concern and your petitioners humbly call upon the Senate to conduct a Senate inquiry into South West Tasmania. A Federal inquiry has been recommended by the House of Representatives Standing Committee on Environment and Conservation.

Your petitioners therefore humbly call upon the Federal Parliament not to allocate funds or allow funds to be raised for development of roads or dams in the South West of Tasmania but rather to provide such funds as would enable the preservation of this area. This is a national issue and therefore Tasmanians should not be made to bear any financial burden resulting from its preservation.
And your petitioners as in duty bound will ever pray.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: CHILDS

TALK.START.PARA: —I present the following petition from 71 citizens of Australia:

SPEECH.PARA: To the Honourable the President and Members of the Senate of the Australian Parliament assembled. The humble petition of the undersigned citizens of the State of New South Wales respectfully showeth:
That the plan by the Australian Postal Commission to downgrade postal and mail services throughout Australia, will place in jeopardy the existing services and the security of the mails by-
downgrading a large number of official post offices;
reducing the number of post offices open for business during the lunch period;
reducing the number of street posting boxes;
delaying telegrams by reducing the number of delivery offices;
downgrading post office services by employing untrained and unqualified staff; and
using private contractors for mail cartage.

Your petitioners therefore pray that the Australian Government will take immediate action to prevent the Australian Postal Commission implementing any plan which will downgrade the postal and mail services of the citizens of Australia.
And your petitioners as in duty bound will ever pray.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: GRIMES

TALK.START.PARA: —I present the following petition from 696 citizens of Australia:

SPEECH.PARA: To the Honourable the President and Members of the Senate in Parliament assembled. The petition of the undersigned citizens of Australia respectfully showeth:
1. All children in Tasmania are not treated equally;
2. Persons with intellectual, physical and multiple handicaps in particular will be denied access to Aspect House, 6 Warragul Avenue, New Town in Tasmania if the house is closed;
3. Aspect House is faced with imminent closure because of lack of Government policy and on-going funding;

4. Aspect House is the only community-based facility in an ordinary house in an ordinary surburban setting which provides relief to parents and families engaged in the onerous and demanding task of rearing their handicapped children in the community;
5. That the rights of all children to live with their families should be respected;
6. That we seek Government to take immediate action to prevent the closure of this unique facility.
And your petitioners as in duty bound will ever pray.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: LAJOVIC

TALK.START.PARA: —I present the following petition from 13 citizens of Australia:

SPEECH.PARA: To the Honourable the President and Members of the Senate in Parliament assembled. The Petition of the undersigned respectfully showeth:

That the projected repeal by the Queensland State Government of the Aborigines Act 1971-1979 and the Torres Strait Islander Act 1971-1979 will almost certainly lead to the degazettal of all Aboriginal reserves in Queensland, as happened with Aurukun and Mornington Island.

That, if the Aboriginal communities from these reserves are placed under similar shire council legislation on fifty year leases, they will be exposed to serious encroachment on their land by mining and tourist interests.

That, on past evidence, these interests will clearly have the full backing of the Queensland Government and the rights of Aboriginal people to land rights and self-management will not be granted by that Government.

That the Commonwealth Government has the constitutional power to legislate and acquire land for Aboriginal people since the amendments to the Constitution in 1967, but it is your Petitioners' sincere belief that it has already failed in its duty before the people of Aurukun and Mornington Island.
That the Aboriginal people of Queensland have stated that they want land rights and self-management.

Your Petitioners therefore humbly pray that the Senate, in Parliament assembled, should make use of its constitutional and legislative powers to grant full land rights and self-management to the Aboriginal people of Queensland.
And your petitioners as in duty bound will ever pray.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: GRIMES

TALK.START.PARA: —by leave-I present the following petition from 202 citizens of Australia which is not in accordance with the Standing Orders:

SPEECH.PARA: To the Honourable Members of both Houses, Parliament House, Canberra, A.C.T. 2600.

This Petition by the grace of God is drawn up by the Pensioners of all denominations, the unfortunate Unemployed, and the many Under-privileged people of this Nation, appeal to all Members of the 32nd Parliament representing the voice of the Australian people, for a 50% increase in Pension, together with those people on a fixed income of some 2,300,000 poverty-stricken, in the forthcoming 1981-82 Budget to be brought down in August 1981, in order to stem the tide of rising poverty that is crippling so many, creating much Anxiety, Despair, Ill-Health and Suicidal tendencies.
For this we humbly pray.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: GRIMES

TALK.START.PARA: —by leave-I present the following petition from 551 citizens of Australia which is not in accordance with the Standing Orders:

SPEECH.PARA: To the Honourable the President and Members of the Senate in Parliament assembled. The humble petition of undersigned respectfully showeth:

That many Australians will be financially disadvantaged by the health changes proposed by the Federal Government, especially the withdrawal of Commonwealth medical benefits for the uninsured, and the introduction of a means test for free public hospital care;
That the health insurance changes promote inequity, inefficiency and lack of universal coverage;
That the public hospital system and community health programmes will be financially disadvantaged by the abdication of Commonwealth responsibility and funding.
Your Petitioners therefore humbly pray that the Senate will take all steps necessary to reintroduce a system of health care based on ability to pay, and access to health care based on medical need.
And your petitioners as in duty bound will ever pray.
The Clerk-Petitions have been lodged for presentation as follows:

PETITION.TITLE: Sales Tax
PETITION.PARA: To the Honourable the President and Members of the Senate in Parliament assembled.

The humble petition of the undersigned citizens of Australia respectfully showeth that your petitioners are gravely concerned at the proposed imposition of Sales Tax on items concerned with home building and contents-clothing-books-magazines and newspapers.

Your petitioners therefore call upon the Federal Parliament not to implement such legislation as will permit these increases in costs to become a further burden on home builders, families and children or inhibit the purchase of news and or information.
And your petitioners as in duty bound will ever pray.

PETITION.TITLE: Facilities for Handicapped Children
PETITION.PARA: To the Honourable the President and Members of the Senate in Parliament assembled. The petition of the undersigned citizens of Australia respectfully showeth:
1. All children in Tasmania are not treated equally
2. Persons with intellectual, physical and multiple handicaps in particular will be denied access to Aspect House, 6 Warragul Avenue, New Town in Tasmania if the house is closed
3. Aspect House is faced with imminent closure because of lack of Government policy and on-going funding

4. Aspect House is the only community-based facility in an ordinary house in an ordinary surburban setting which provides relief to parents and families engaged in the onerous and demanding task of rearing their handicapped children in the community
5. That the rights of all children to live with their families should be respected
6. That we seek Government to take immediate action to prevent the closure of this unique facility

TALK.START.PARA: —My question is addressed to the Minister for Social Security. It refers to a number of recent Administrative Appeals Tribunal decisions dealing with social security payments in which the Tribunal, although saying that the Director-General of Social Services is under no obligation legally to make payments, strongly recommends that ex gratia payments be made to the appellants in those cases. I ask the Minister: In what number of cases has such an ex gratia payment been made? What is the Government's policy in general about such decisions and payments?

—I cannot recall a great number of-indeed, I cannot recall any-applications for ex gratia payments of benefits since I have had responsibility for this portfolio. I will have to examine the matters raised by the honourable senator and give him a reply. I cannot be certain on that. There may have been a small number, but it would be a very small number indeed.

—I address my question to the Acting Minister for Health. Has the Minister received a request from the South Australian Health Minister, Mrs Jennifer Adamson, for the Commonwealth to assist with funding for an initial three-year period of the provision of a resident family visitor, through the Child, Adolescent and Family Service, to be stationed at Mount Gambier in South Australia? As there is an urgent need for the provision of a family visitor who would be working in close co-operation with the parents of children with special needs, general practitioners and other professional people, I further ask: If there has been no such request from the South Australian Minister, will the Minister treat my question as an urgent request from the many concerned parents living at Mount Gambier and in surrounding districts for the provision of this much needed and worthwhile service?

—Certainly as Acting Minister for Health I have not received a request of the kind to which the honourable senator referred. Whether the Minister whom I represent had previously received such a request I am not able to say at this time. I imagine that South Australia would be concerned if there were people in the Mount Gambier area with special needs. I imagine that the State of South Australia would be looking at ways in which it could order its own priorities, in the light of available funds, to meet those priorities as it thought best. The new arrangements made by the Commonwealth will give the States greater flexibility in the use of funds provided for health matters. If no request has been received I say to the honourable senator that his question would serve to put me on notice, but in fact it would require a formal request from the State Minister before I could assume that South Australia had asked in any official way for this service to be provided.

—I address my question to the Acting Minister for Health and draw his attention to an article which appeared in the Australian of 10 September relating to an address given by Dr Trefor Morgan of Melbourne's Repatriation Hospital to a scientific meeting of the Royal Australasian College of Physicians. Will the Minister comment on this report and, in particular, Dr Morgan's claim that about 70 per cent of our community has an excessive salt intake? Does the Minister agree that the use of salt in foodstuffs must be more carefully controlled in an effort to reduce excessive salt intake and the risk of hypertension within the community? If so, what action has been taken by the Government to alert the community to the dangers of excessive salt consumption? What consideration will be given by the Government to introducing legislation similar to that currently being studied by the Reagan Administration, which requires the salt content of food to be shown on containers?

ANSWER.SPEAKER: Baume Sen The Hon P.E.

TALK.START.PARA: —I think the doctor to whom Senator Missen is referring is Dr Trefor Morgan, who came from the golden year of medicine at Sydney University. He is an expert in hypertension. I have seen the article. The matter of salt intake is important, and its relationship to the development of hypertension is being better understood. It is presently under consideration by a working party of the National Health and Medical Research Council, which is working on the general subject of sodium in the Australian diet. Dr Morgan is the chairman of that working party, which is currently finalising its report for presentation to the National Health and Medical Research Council.

ANSWER.PARA: Without wishing to pre-empt any recommendations that may be contained in the working party's report, I can say that most Australians consume an excessive amount of sodium, usually in the form of salt-sodium chloride. There is a growing concern about the excessive consumption of salt in the Australian diet as sodium has been linked to the development of high blood pressure in susceptible persons. I understand that those susceptible persons are estimated to constitute up to 20 per cent of the Australian population. The importance of high blood pressure is as it relates to strokes and other diseases of the cardiovascular system. Notwithstanding that the relationship between salt intake and high blood pressure has not been established absolutely, I do agree that Australians should moderate and reduce their intake of salt and that the matter of more adequately controlling the use of salt in foodstuffs such as bread should be examined. The Department of Health has taken action to alert the community to the dangers of excessive salt intake. The Department's well-publicised food and nutrition policy recommends a reduction in the community's intake of salt. The Department has also drawn up a set of eight dietary guidelines for Australia to improve the nutritional health of the community. One of these is to reduce the intake of salt. A publication Dietary Guidelines for Australians, which includes advice to the community to use less salt and gives practical suggestions as to how this can be achieved, is presently being printed.

As to whether we should insist on the declaration of salt content on packaged foods, the National Health and Medical Research Council has already recommended that ingredients of packaged foods should be declared on the label, in descending order of proportion. The recommendation includes a requirement as to the declaration of added salt and has been referred to the States and Territories for adoption. Indeed, several States have already incorporated the recommendations in State food regulations. The question of the declaring of the specific sodium content of packaged foods, as suggested by Senator Missen, is presently under consideration by expert committees of the National Health and Medical Research Council. Obviously, the recommendations from the Council, coming from a Federal body, are a matter for consideration by individual States and Territories, as to possible incorporation in State legislation.

QUESTION.BLOCK.TITLE: SNOWY MOUNTAINS HYDRO-ELECTRIC AUTHORITY: INDUSTRIAL DISPUTE

TALK.START.PARA: —My question is directed to the Minister for National Development and Energy. What is the Government doing to settle the dispute between technical and supervisory staff of the Snowy Mountains Hydro-electric Authority and the Public Service Board over the payment of a $17 power station allowance? Is the Minister aware that as a result of the dispute no maintenance has been carried out on power station plant for six weeks and that if plant breaks down it will not be repaired? Is the Minister also aware that a continuance of the dispute will mean that there will be no flood control of the record snow melt-off and that already water is being wasted and power output is presently down by 25 per cent? In view of the urgency of this matter and the fact that the New South Wales and Victorian State Electricity Commissions cannot now close down plant for maintenance, will the Minister use his best endeavours with the Public Service Board to ensure that this dispute is settled with expedition?

ANSWER.SPEAKER: Carrick Sen The Hon J.L.

TALK.START.PARA: —If, indeed, the whole community used its best endeavours to encourage the officers involved to lift their bans-a significant omission from the honourable senator's question-the dispute would have been before the arbitral authorities and would be settled by now. The real nub of the problem is that those who believe in the arbitral processes should say to those who have imposed the bans: 'You have access to the settlement of your dispute straight away. If you will lift your bans and carry out a normal day's work, the arbitral authorities have undertaken to consider the matter immediately'. I emphasise that point. The matter has been before the Public Service Board; it has been before the arbitrators. It is a tragedy that there should be a dispute at all. It is utterly competent for the matter to be dealt with in a civilised way.

ANSWER.PARA: It is perfectly true, as Senator Coates has said, that as a result of the dispute there has been a 25 per cent decline in the output of the Snowy Mountains Hydro-electric Authority, but that decline is not because of any lack of capacity in the arbitral process. It is because workers are still imposing bans. I believe that, as with Mr Gallagher and the Builders Labourers Federation, we should look at the real problem. I do not want in any way to exacerbate the situation. I believe that it ought not to have occurred. I say to those in the community who are concerned with this dispute, and to the officers involved in it: 'Lift your bans. You have the arbitral process in place. It will be settled'. There is no doubt in the world that it is a very bad thing for Australia to be losing this capacity. I have never believed that a handful of people, however right or wrong their dispute, have the right to hold the rest of Australia to ransom on such matters. Because of their ability to reduce the capacity of the scheme, to alter the flow of water and to offer some threat of flooding if there were to be a heavy melt-off, they must take on themselves a very heavy responsibility in terms of their behaviour. When these kinds of disputes are mentioned in this place we ought to state both sides of the equation. The Australian community is one community; it is not polarised.

TALK.START.PARA: —My question is directed to the Minister representing the Minister for Transport and concerns the call of the Minister for Transport for all local and international vessels in Australian ports to dress ship tomorrow for World Maritime Day. Is the Minister aware of reports that Panama may ban Australian registered ships from the Panama Canal because of Australian union bans on ships of its registry? Is the Minister aware of the supplement to the Daily Commercial News dealing with strike status in Australia? Is the Minister aware that that report on Australian strikes has now reached three pages in length and lists 113 strikes in Australia which are either current or pending and that those strikes are creating great disruption to Australian trade and commerce? Finally, in the light of those circumstances, will the Minister consider instructing Australian ships not to dress ship tomorrow but to wear their flags at half-mast as a warning that irresponsible militant trade union action is destroying our shipping industry?

—It is true that the Government is very concerned about the situation in the maritime industry, particularly the problems occurring at the moment with the maritime engineers. Certainly the difficulties facing Australian shipping as a result of the strikes to which Senator Lewis referred are creating significant difficulties for Australian industry and no doubt are having significant economic effects, not only in the short run but also in the longer run. Senator Lewis referred in particular to the 113 strikes which are current or pending in the maritime industry. Those, of course, are damaging in the extreme to our industrial situation. Senator Lewis was concerned about the dressing of ships. I think we can address ourselves to that matter by remembering tomorrow what difficulties those problems are causing to Australian industry. It is of the greatest importance that I refer the question to the Minister and obtain an early reply for Senator Lewis. In fact, I will endeavour to obtain some immediate information about the Minister's attitude to the strike situation before the end of Question Time today.

QUESTION.BLOCK.TITLE: ABORIGINAL COMMUNITIES WITHOUT SECURE LAND TENURE

QUESTION.SPEAKER: Evans Sen G.J.

TALK.START.PARA: —My question is directed to the Minister for Aboriginal Affairs. I refer the Minister to the answer he gave on 2 April this year to a question on notice from me regarding departmental support for Aboriginal communities without secure land tenure. In the first paragraph of that answer he stated:

QUESTION.PARA: There is no 'Departmental policy of non-involvement in communities without secure land tenure'.
Further on he stated:
Where leases of community areas have not been provided, applications for assistance can still be considered by the Department . . .

That reply was given this year, but I ask the Minister whether he is also aware that, in a letter on 22 October last year, Mr J. Foley, the Acting Area Officer of his Department, wrote to the trustees of the Kroonull Community at Fitzroy Crossing, one of the communities which lack secure land tenure, in the following terms:
In the past the Department has taken the position that it could not fund organisations which do not have land title under the Lands Act and this principle now applies to the Kroonull Community.

I ask the Minister: Which statement does accurately reflect current departmental policy and, if the Minister's more recent reply is the accurate one, what steps will he now take to rectify the position for those communities, in particular the Kroonull Community?

ANSWER.SPEAKER: Baume Sen The Hon P.E.

TALK.START.PARA: —Senator Evans was courteous enough to give me just before Question Time, or some time this morning, a copy of the question he planned to ask. I have been able to obtain a copy of the answer to question on notice No. 253 and to study that answer. I have not been able to obtain the other papers in the time available. Senator Evans referred to a letter of 22 October 1980 written by one of the acting area officers of that time. The reply which I gave to Senator Evans in answer to the question on notice outlines the approach that my Department takes in these matters. That is the position. I made it clear that there are difficulties in providing fixed capital improvements where the groups do not live on reserves or where they do not have security of tenure. The reason is obvious and I think it was set out in the answer: If in fact we provide fixed improvements they become the property of those who own the land.

ANSWER.PARA: I indicated also that the Aboriginal Development Commission was considering an application for land from the Kroonull Community. I will ask my Department to provide me with the other papers which have been referred to by Senator Evans. If those papers were talking about a request for assistance for fixed improvements, a reply in the terms quoted would be consistent with the Department's approach. If the request was for other forms of aid, it would not be consistent. I ask Senator Evans to give us a chance to look at the papers and to try to bring these things into line, one with the other.

TALK.START.PARA: —Mr President, I ask you a question. In an effort to further the improvement in the hospitality extended by members of this Parliament to their guests and in fact for the benefit of the members themselves, will the President request that the Joint House Department engage in what would initially be a trial purchase of prime beef cuts from King Island which, as every member and senator well knows, is Australia's finest beef producing locality? Perhaps the Senate has not realised that the King Island abattoir is now specialising in supplying discriminating markets with superior cuts? Every member of this Parliament should appreciate this and be given the opportunity to benefit accordingly.

—I say, firstly, that I cannot speak on behalf of all honourable senators in this chamber as to whether they are aware that King Island beef is the finest in Australia. If that beef is of the same quality as the honourable senator's promotion of it, I shall certainly refer the question to the Joint House Department.

—Has the attention of the Minister representing the Minister for Communications been drawn to a report in last Sunday's Canberra Times dealing with the Special Broadcasting Service? Does he agree with the claim that ethnic broadcasting is producing 'laundered' news and avoids debate of public issues, even when these are of particular concern to migrants? Has his attention been drawn also to reports of the recent Australian Council of Trade Union Congress which carried a resolution deploring the 'present Government's practice of using government-funded ethnic media as a propaganda outlet, censoring information and preventing discussions on matter of public interest, particularly with regard to the trade union movement'?

—The honourable senator's question adverts to a particular newspaper article which I have not read. I seem to recall that the question of news in this particular broadcasting service was mentioned during a recent Estimates committee examination. At that time-I think this is correct-the kinds of procedures that take place were made known to the committee. I might say that, in some of the communities in which I move, when there are expressions of concern about the presentation of some material on this form of radio it is generally seen to be the non-Labor side that is disadvantaged. I think the perception of disadvantage may depend upon the position from which one comes. Many people may have a slightly paranoid view of the way in which any news is presented. I will take on notice the matters that were raised and refer them to the Minister for Communications.

—I suppose that my question to the Acting Minister for Health follows somewhat on the answer the Minister gave about salt a little while ago. However, it relates to something a little different. The Minister may remember that on previous occasions I have asked whether the Government would request State governments to require by law that the percentage of alcohol in alcoholic drinks be put on the labels of the bottles in which they are contained. Has the Minister any up to date knowledge of the present situation? I ask this question because many people who choose to drink alcoholic drinks would like to know the strength of the drink they are consuming. I realise full well that, if the percentage of alcohol were put on the label, some people might choose a very strong drink instead of a very weak one; but I still think it would be an advantage because it does appear from the total quantity of light beer that is being consumed that many people in this country wish to consume alcoholic drinks which have a low alcohol percentage.

—The Senate, which has been a proponent of the freedom of information legislation and a movement towards freedom of information in the last few years, I think would want to endorse Senator Townley's concern that the maximum consumer information should be available. The benefit that flows to the consumers in the long run from knowing exactly what products they are purchasing and the constituents or components of those products is one against which I do not argue. The recommendations of the National Health and Medical Research Council, to which I referred earlier, related to the labelling of food packages. As far as I know-but I can check this point-they did not relate to the labelling of alcoholic beverages. I can certainly undertake to find out whether there is more up to date information on this matter. I agree with Senator Townley that if people did know in detail about the products they were consuming they could choose either one with a greater content or one with a lesser content of any particular component.

QUESTION.BLOCK.TITLE: TELEVISION STATION LICENCE FEES: AMENDMENT OF MONEY BILLS

TALK.START.PARA: —I ask the Minister representing the Minister for Communications: Is it true, as reported this morning in the Age, that the Government is seeking legal advice on how it can amend one of its own money Bills in the Senate in order to reduce television company licence fees that were to be increased in this Budget? If the Government succeeds in finding a legal means by which the Senate can amend money Bills, will the Minister inform the Senate of this discovery? If the report is correct, can the Minister explain why the Government has changed its mind on the matter?

—I saw the Age report this morning just before I came into the chamber. I found it very intriguing. I have no idea whether it is correct. Clearly this is a question which will need to be referred to the Minister whom I represent.

QUESTION.BLOCK.TITLE: HUMAN RIGHTS COMMISSION: ABORIGINAL FOSTER CHILDREN

QUESTION.SPEAKER: Giles Sen P.J.

TALK.START.PARA: —My question is to the Attorney-General. In a report in the West Australian of 19 September 1981, Mr Robert Riley, Chairman of the Aboriginal Child Care Agency, expressed serious concern at the number of Aboriginal children lost from the Aboriginal society through activities of the State Community Welfare Department. Mr Riley said that according to 'Children in Limbo'-a report recently published- 66 per cent of children in long term care in Western Australia in community welfare institutions and placed with white foster parents were Aboriginals. The Aboriginal community was only 2.3 per cent of the State's total population. Mr Riley said that the Minister for Community Welfare, Mr Hassell, had indicated that foster parents might soon be able to adopt children who had been in their care for two years. Mr Riley said:

QUESTION.PARA: This means that a lot more Aboriginal children will be lost from the State's Aboriginal community. Under the old assimilation policy children were forcibly taken from Aboriginal communities and put in missions. This proposal to ease adoption regulations is exactly the same, only more thorough.

Is the loss of cultural identity a matter which is within the charter of the Human Rights Commission? Can the Attorney-General indicate when the Human Rights Commission will be established and able to deal with such cases?

TALK.START.PARA: —Mr President, until the very last part of the question there seemed to me to be some doubt as to why the question was addressed to me. In relation to the establishment of the Human Rights Commission, I would be hoping to announce very shortly the members of the Commission.
—It was going to be today. What happened?
—Well, the day has not passed yet.
—You really mean 'very shortly'-in that sense?

—I said that I would announce it. I do not know whether it will be announced today, if the honourable senator wants to be pedantic. I apologise to Senator Giles. Every time she asks me a question we are diverted by her colleague Senator Evans.
—You should resist the impulse.

—It is difficult, after the little sleep we have had. As I said, the commissioners will be announced and will start to prepare for the proclamation of the commencement of the Commission's operations. I do not know exactly when the Act will be proclaimed. I will wait until the commissioners are appointed and they have had an opportunity to give consideration to that and advise me about it. Anyway, it is fairly near. As to the charter of the Commission, in light of the detailed questions the honourable senator asked I will have to give consideration to that matter and provide a further answer.

—My question is directed to the Acting Minister for Health. Is it a fact that the unfortunate contributors to the Druids Hospital and Medical Benefits Fund were the martyrs and subsequently became the catalyst for upgrading Commonwealth Department of Health responsibilities towards health funds and also for the creation of a pool to reimburse contributors disadvantaged in future collapses? Further, would it be possible for those Druids contributors subsequently to be paid out of this pool? Finally, will the Government initiate a wide-ranging commission of inquiry into the background of this collapse, taking into account, amongst other things, the chaotic state of the books following the closure and the sale of the buildings to the management company?

ANSWER.SPEAKER: Baume Sen The Hon P.E.

TALK.START.PARA: —The Commonwealth maintains a continuing watch on the regulations which apply to the operation of the various health funds. These regulations ensure that the funds which operate today are operating in a way that is to the benefit of contributors. For example, it is essential that funds are not able to announce unrealistically low contribution rates that might lead to the failure or closure of the funds. We had a problem not so long ago when Medibank Private announced some rates which had not been approved. Medibank Private had to revise its rates as a result of its being required to follow proper procedures. All these procedures are designed to serve the benefits of contributors.

ANSWER.PARA: In recent years, some of the small funds, including the Druids and I think the Ancient Order of Foresters Health Fund, had to close. Whenever that happens the opportunity is taken to review and revise, as people would expect, all the procedures to ensure that nothing could have been done more adequately or more appropriately. I will pass on the honourable senator's suggestion for a commission of inquiry, but I am not certain that that is the best way to ensure what I am sure he is after, that is, that contributors to health insurance funds be protected and secure in obtaining the protection they are seeking through health insurance.

TALK.START.PARA: —Has the Minister representing the Minister for Primary Industry noticed media reports of the discovery of further meat switching at a Melbourne meat works? Is the company named-Steigers Meat Supply Pty Ltd of Northcote-the same company mentioned by me in March 1978? Had that company prior to March 1978 been the subject of a police investigation over allegations of a similar nature? What, if any, Department of Primary Industry surveillance has been kept on the company in the intervening years?

—The Press reports referred to by the honourable senator have escaped my attention. If they are very recent reports, that may be because we have been spending a long time in this place. I will follow up the reports and get an answer to his question.

—My question is directed to the Acting Minister for Health and raises a couple of matters relating to prescriptions obtained by people under the National Health Scheme. I point out that both these suggestions will reduce the income of chemists and not increase it. Firstly, will the Minister ask the Minister for Health to increase the permissible number of doses on one prescription for those people who need to take long term medication? Secondly, no doubt the Minister is aware that often families with young children need several prescriptions for, say, two children, which at the moment amount to quite a sum of money. Will the Minister have examined the possibility of reducing the prescription fee for children's prescriptions to, say, half of what it is at the moment?

ANSWER.SPEAKER: Baume Sen The Hon P.E.

TALK.START.PARA: —I note that my pharmacist colleague from Tasmania says that his proposal would reduce the income of pharmacists and I acknowledge that point. I think he makes two proposals. One of them relates to a concessional fee for a class of people. I think he is talking about children's prescriptions. That would be a policy matter which would have to be looked at by the Government. The other question he asks concerns the number of doses which can be ordered on one prescription for those who require long term therapy. If that did take place, fewer prescriptions would be needed and there would be fewer prescription fees for chemists. He is quite correct; that would reduce remuneration.

ANSWER.PARA: The honourable senator would know, I think, that the Government receives advice on matters of this kind from an expert committee. I think it is the Pharmaceutical Benefits Advisory Committee. The Minister is not able to take any affirmative action without the advice of that Committee. He is able to decline to take the advice of that Committee. This is the kind of matter that would need to be referred back to the Government's advisers for an expert view. It may not be just a question of economics. There may be certain therapeutic considerations to be taken into account. It may or may not be desirable for people to have large volumes of certain medications, for example, which may become out of date or may be misused or misapplied. I shall take the question back to our expert advisers and see what they say.

TALK.START.PARA: —I direct my question to the Minister for Social Security. I preface it by remarking that I have become concerned because some age pensioners have informed me that they are withdrawing their savings from their bank accounts and keeping them in their homes. They are doing this as they fear that the amounts which they have in their bank accounts may prevent them from continuing to receive a full rate age pension because of new legislation which has been suggested in this Parliament. The Minister would be aware that if age pensioners hold large sums of money in their homes they run the risk of having their savings stolen, and perhaps even face the risk of personal injuries from someone who assails them to steal their money. Would the Minister consider making an early announcement to the Senate of the details of his plans to amend the Social Services Act so that those who will not be affected will not take unnecessary risks with their savings?

—I have not had reports of the sort that the honourable senator refers to in his question. I certainly agree with him that it is most undesirable for aged people in particular to have large sums of money in their homes because, obviously, that is a temptation to people who might wish to get access to that money. It would be a serious matter. The announcement which I made on the night of the presentation of the Budget was that the Government would be strengthening the legislation which already exists in the social security area and which provides that deprivation of income for the purpose of obtaining pension can be taken into account by the Director-General in assessing the rate of pension. That matter is still under detailed consideration. In light of the honourable senator's comments I will ensure that the earliest possible announcements are made, which will calm fears. I would say-and I think this is quite clear-that the Government's intention is to aim at artificial schemes which have been mushrooming of late. I think that all pensioners should be aware that when they deprive themselves of income they in fact reduce their real incomes. That is a matter on which I think many pensioners get very poor advice.

—I ask the Minister representing the Prime Minister whether it is true that Australian Federal Police car drivers scheduled to chauffeur Commonwealth Heads of Government dignitaries have been given instructions to run down innocent pedestrians, if necessary, to ensure the safety of their passengers. How does the Prime Minister justify his judgment that innocent Australian pedestrians are worth less than the heads of foreign governments who are the targets of terrorists, many because of their own policies? Why did the Prime Minister choose to hold this meeting in Melbourne, knowing full well the problems of security against terrorism in such a large city?

ANSWER.SPEAKER: Carrick Sen The Hon J.L.

TALK.START.PARA: —It is always a wise course for any honourable senator to make sure that something has occurred before asserting that it has. The Government has given no such instructions at all. That part of the question as asked is, of course, without merit. I understand that the police had issued some instructions, which were police instructions. The Commonwealth Government has made it perfectly clear that where human life is concerned, whether a person is an ordinary Australian or a top dignitary in the world, he or she has equal rights to his or her safety and dignity. Let me repeat: There will be no question of giving priority of safety or protection of any kind in that regard.

ANSWER.PARA: Having said that, let me address myself to the question of the Commonwealth Heads of Government Meeting. The first thing that has to be an assumption is that Australia, as one of the 43 member nations of the Commonwealth, ought to regard it as a tribute to be the host country. Secondly, in a democracy it ought to be our proud responsibility and our privilege to ensure the best facilities for the people and their total protection. Quite clearly if we are to have 43 nations with all their entourages, with all the accommodation that is necessary-perhaps some thousands of actual bedded accommodations-and with all the infrastructure, we are asking of necessity for the meeting to be held in a major city. Therefore, I am utterly surprised that anyone would query why Australia would not hold CHOGM in a major city of Australia.

I turn to why the Meeting is being held in Melbourne. It is to the eternal discredit of a section of mankind that terrorism today walks largely in an uncivilised way across the world scene. It is to our eternal discredit that in a democracy we have to take steps that we ordinarily would not take to ensure that the greater or lesser people of this world may walk the scene with their lives safe and secure. On that basis we accept the responsibility of holding the conference, we accept the need to hold it in a major city and we are proud to bring 43 heads of government together to talk about major things such as world hunger and the North-South dialogue. I thought that, instead of looking at pimples on our nose, the thrust would have been: 'Is it not good that we are facing up to the great problems of mankind?' I think we ought to be ambassadors promoting the success of this conference instead of nit-picking.

We will certainly give equal protection to all human beings who walk in this country. Nevertheless, the police in the compass of terrorism have to make major decisions from time to time involving human lives. Honourable senators should have some sympathy for the decision-making responsibilities of the police in such a situation. We should, as the main target of our attack, be rejecting the ugliness of terrorism.

TALK.START.PARA: —My question, which is directed to the Minister representing the Minister for Industrial Relations, follows questions asked in the last few days by my South Australian colleagues, Senators Teague and Jessop, in relation to the critical fuel situation in South Australia. Will the Government thoroughly re-evaluate Commonwealth industrial legislation in light of the fuel shortage crisis faced by South Australia in recent days, arising out of the federal maritime dispute and the apparent inability of current legislation and procedures to protect the interests of the Australian community in such circumstances?

—The matter of re-evaluation of legislation of this sort seems to arise whenever there is a period of industrial difficulty. I think it would be fair to say that no area of the law is more likely to receive continuous evaluation and re-evaluation than industrial law. The dispute to which the honourable senator referred is the subject of a further meeting of the union involved, I think this morning. That follows a great deal of activity before the Australian Conciliation and Arbitration Commission. Whilst I will refer that inquiry to the Minister for Industrial Relations, I suggest that the mere imposition of industrial laws does not necessarily appear to be the answer to some of these intractable disputes. There are parties to these disputes-unions and employers. The resolution of such disputes requires reasonable and rational behaviour on the part of both. In this case, as I understand it, directions have been given to this union to return to work, so far without success. It is hard to see any piece of legislation which is likely to ensure that people are forced to work in a situation where they simply refuse to do so.

—Is the Minister representing the Minister for Foreign Affairs aware that at its recent congress the Australian Council of Trade Unions endorsed the call by the Actors and Announcers Equity Association of Australia for a ban on the sale of television programs to South Africa in accordance with the policy of the United Nations? Has the Minister received representations from the Secretary of the ACTU, Mr Peter Nolan, on this matter? If so, what action will the Government take to enforce the United Nations resolution calling for a ban on cultural contacts with South Africa? Will the Government state its attitude on this matter before the Commonwealth Heads of Government Meeting?

ANSWER.SPEAKER: Guilfoyle Sen The Hon Dame M.G.C.

TALK.START.PARA: — I recall that a question was asked a day or two ago on the subject of the Actors Equity attitude with regard to the sale of programs to South Africa. I have referred that question to the Minister for Foreign Affairs. As far as I am aware, I have not had any information back from him, but I will see that that response is provided as early as possible. I have nothing to add to the comment that was made at that time.

QUESTION.BLOCK.TITLE: NORTHERN TERRITORY: ACCOMMODATION FOR PUBLIC SERVANTS

TALK.START.PARA: —I refer the Minister representing the Minister for Administrative Services to a review which was recently conducted in the Northern Territory into the requirements of Commonwealth public servants for accommodation in the Northern Territory and the sale of Commonwealth houses to Commonwealth public servants. Can the Minister indicate the outcome of that report and the Government's attitude to the sale of Commonwealth accommodation to its public servants in the Northern Territory?

ANSWER.SPEAKER: Baume Sen The Hon P.E.

TALK.START.PARA: —As Minister for Aboriginal Affairs, the honourable senator's question is of particular interest to me. I have a large number of officers in the Northern Territory and accommodation for my officers is a continuing worry and problem, particularly in the central area of Australia. In Alice Springs there is a limited amount of available housing stock and intense competition for that housing. I am reminded, for example, that officers who go to Alice Springs have considerable difficulty in finding somewhere to live. They are forced to live in caravans for which they pay quite considerable rent.

ANSWER.PARA: I am advised that an interdepartmental working party met recently and has completed a comprehensive review of housing policies in the Northern Territory. The report of the working party now needs to come to Government for its consideration. Some decisions will have to be taken by the Government. The Minister whom I represent in this place has given undertakings that all concerned, including all Commonwealth employees in the Territory, will be advised of the outcome of that review as soon as practicable. I acknowledge Senator Kilgariff's concern for what is a continuing and very significant problem for his constituents in the Northern Territory.

TALK.START.PARA: —My question is directed to the Minister representing the Minister for Foreign Affairs. As it is now two years since Australian Broadcasting Commission journalist, Tony Joyce, who was a personal friend of mine, was shot and killed in Zambia and little or no action has apparently been taken to apprehend those responsible, will the Minister undertake to question President Kaunda during the forthcoming Commonwealth Heads of Government Meeting as to what the Zambian Government has done about resolving this matter to the satisfaction of the Australian people, particularly his family and friends?

ANSWER.SPEAKER: Guilfoyle Sen The Hon Dame M.G.C.

TALK.START.PARA: — I think the Prime Minister made some comment on this matter a few days ago. I have not the precise wording of the comment made at that time. I think that if I seek that comment I will be able to have it before the end of Question Time to help Senator Sibraa with the matter he has raised.

QUESTION.BLOCK.TITLE: REVIEW OF COMMONWEALTH FUNCTIONS: DEPARTMENTAL APPROPRIATIONS

TALK.START.PARA: —My question, which is directed to the Minister for Finance, concerns the decision in the Review of Commonwealth Functions to cut by 3 per cent departmental expenditure on furniture, repairs, property, leases and administration. I refer to the Senate's current consideration of estimates for departmental appropriations. This 3 per cent reduction when applied to last financial year's actual expenditure in many cases appears to have become merely a bookkeeping entry. Can the Minister say whether the money increase in departmental appropriations for these items in fact averages 7 per cent or less; that is, an estimated inflation increase of 10 per cent less the RCF's 3 per cent cut?

ANSWER.SPEAKER: Guilfoyle Sen The Hon Dame M.G.C.

TALK.START.PARA: — When the amounts for this expenditure were considered by the Budget Cabinet it took into account those expenditures that may have occurred last year and would not be recurring this year. For instance, if a machine were bought last year but such a purchase would not be required this year, the amount was adjusted. In other words, the 3 per cent reduction in this item is a reconciled figure of the one-off situations that occurred last year and not this year and what may be required this year; for instance, a contracted arrangement for some machinery, fittings or something that is required this year. The Department of Finance, when looking at the requirements of each department, took into account these items that had a special application in one year or the other. So it is actually an adjusted figure in most instances but does, with those adjustments, reflect the RCF decision concerning the 3 per cent reduction.

—Mr President, I wish to ask a supplementary question. May I put on notice that aspect of my question which asks whether, in fact, the increases in the departments' appropriations for the current financial year average only 7 per cent?

ANSWER.SPEAKER: Guilfoyle Sen The Hon Dame M.G.C.

TALK.START.PARA: — Perhaps Senator Teague is requiring a question to be placed on notice asking every department to explain the increase. Is that what the honourable senator had in mind?
—Just a general average.

— Perhaps we could get a general comment. I think the honourable senator will find that the situation is as I have already said; that it is a negotiated figure or figure reconciled between differences in expenditure last year and this year taking into account those one-year expenditures that are not common in both. I do not think I can add further to that comment. Each department was scrutinised closely. The Department of Finance and each department concerned came to arrangements on workable solutions in accordance with that RCF decision. I do not think I would take the matter further than that even if there were a question on notice on it.

—Is the Attorney-General aware of the allegation made on Nationwide on 17 June by the former New South Wales policeman, Mr Terry Griffiths, that on four occasions garbage collectors were prevented by security forces from emptying an overflowing rubbish bin at the Hilton Hotel during the 1978 Commonwealth Heads of Government Regional Meeting because the Australian Security Intelligence Organisation had planted in that bin the bomb which subsequently injured Mr Griffiths and killed three other people? Has he noted that garbage truck drivers, Mr Neville Porter and Mr Bill Carlson, confirmed in the Sydney Sun-Herald of 28 June that police had prevented their crews from emptying the overflowing bin? Has he ordered an investigation of these very serious allegations? In particular, have the policemen who chased away the garbage trucks been asked why and on whose instructions they did so?

—Senator Walsh asked whether I had seen a Nationwide program. I have not seen the program, but I have heard of the allegation that was made. The Director-General of the Australian Security Intelligence Organisation, in his address, I think, to the Press Club, answered the charge that was made insofar it was made against ASIO. Of course, when the allegations were made I talked to the Director-General in relation to the matter. As to what the police did at the time, they are State police and the matter would be the responsibility of the New South Wales police.

—I ask a supplementary question. My question did not relate to whether Senator Durack had asked the head of ASIO whether ASIO had planted a bomb in the rubbish bin. I do not think it would be very difficult to predict what the answer to such a question would be. My question concerned whether any other investigations of the allegations have been made. The policemen, on the evidence of two garbage truck drivers, did chase garbage trucks away from the building and prevent them from emptying that bin. Has any effort been made to trace the policemen and ask them why they did it and on whose instructions they were acting?

—I am not aware of the evidence the two garbage truck men gave. There were wild allegations about ASIO's official involvement in the affair. Now, ASIO does not instruct the New South Wales police. That question would be for the New South Wales police. The actual evidence that Senator Walsh referred to is some statements that were made, the details of which I am not aware. I will endeavour to find out something more about the statements or the allegations that have been made. As retailed here by Senator Walsh, they are matters for the New South Wales Police Minister.

—My question is directed to the Minister representing the Minister for Communications. I refer again to the matter of Telecom Australia and the fact that many months ago the Auditor-General declared that there were more than 20 causes of error in telephone accounts. Some of these, of course, reduced the subscriber's cost but most increased the cost to the consumer. Is the Minister able to say whether most of those causes have yet been corrected? What is the state of play with Telecom giving subscribers an accurate account showing in particular the details of STD calls, including the date, length, and cost of the call, as is done in countries such as Canada and the United States?

—I recall that the Auditor-General had some comments to make and I imagine that the Department of Communications will have these under study now. I think the honourable senator said there were 20 or more causes of error in telephone accounts. If so, I am sure the Department will want to take corrective action to overcome these errors. I have a recollection that a statement was made not so long ago about the desire of some people to have detailed accounts for STD calls, and I believe there is some information we may be able to get on that matter. If I am incorrect I will advise the honourable senator. In any event, I will undertake to refer to the Department of Communications all the parts of the honourable senator's question to obtain for him such detail as is available.

—My question is directed to the Minister for Social Security. Can the Minister inform the Parliament why his Department has failed to allocate funds for the current financial year for a rehabilitation program at Angatja in South Australia for Aboriginal juveniles addicted to petrol sniffing? Is the Minister also aware that his Department had given verbal assurances that funding would be available? Further, is the Minister aware that the Department of Aboriginal Affairs and its Minister provided $20,000 to support the program? Is the Minister also aware that the plan was instigated by Charlie and Nganyintja Ilyatjari of Angatja, two respected Pitjantjatara elders, who have been trying since 1978 to get funds for their program? As the program is soundly based, run by Aborigines, and badly needed in this area, what are the reasons for refusal of support by the Minister and his Department?

—My colleague Senator Baume has indicated, as was mentioned by the honourable senator, that assistance is being given to this program through the Department of Aboriginal Affairs. It may be that that particular program has been brought to my attention; I am not absolutely sure. I am not particularly embarrassed by that. Only last week I received advice from, I think, the Social Welfare Research Centre of the University of New South Wales that there are in Australia 37,000 voluntary organisations performing good works in the social welfare field. I find it difficult to keep in touch with them all. I believe that Senator Peter Baume has only 1,000 organisations which are funded through the Department of Aboriginal Affairs. The question raises a serious issue. Petrol sniffing is a problem in a number of isolated Aboriginal communities. It is one which, as I know from experience in my previous portfolio, does not lend itself to either easy diagnosis or easy treatment. In other words, some quite similar communities have problems with petrol sniffing; others do not. The people whom I have met and talked with, who have worked in this field, seem uncertain about the precise ways in which best to deal with it. That is not to say, however, that it is not of great value to have people in the field making an effort concerning it. I will ask my Department to check what applications have been received from that particular organisation. I have some passing recollection of a reference to a petrol sniffing project. It may have been this one.
—It is in the homelands area.
—Senator Baume says it is in the homelands area. I will let the honourable senator have a further reply when I have received further information.

QUESTION.BLOCK.TITLE: EXPORTS: REVALUATION OF THE AUSTRALIAN DOLLAR

TALK.START.PARA: —My question is directed to the Acting Treasurer. In view of the difficulties that are caused to traditional export industries such as those which are associated with primary production and the new mineral industries, will the Government give consideration to altering the mix or basket of currencies to overcome some of the problems of the very steep effective revaluation of the Australian dollar?

ANSWER.SPEAKER: Guilfoyle Sen The Hon Dame M.G.C.

TALK.START.PARA: — I will ask the Treasurer and the Government to give consideration to Senator Watson's question.

—My question is directed to the Acting Minister for Health. Following the recent advice of the so-called 'compassionate' Minister for Employment and Youth Affairs to a young Australian who has been unemployed for 18 months, that she did not need a job but instead should see a psychologist, I ask the Minister what provision has been made in the outpatient departments of public hospitals to cater for the expected rush of unemployed disadvantaged persons, who number 1,000,000-some 340,000 officially recorded and 670,000 hidden-as recorded by the Australian Bureau of Statistics, who, if they adopt this excellent advice by the Minister will be queueing in their thousands to visit psychologists? Alternatively, will the Minister agree that by giving such advice the Minister for Employment and Youth Affairs has shown his incompetence and insensitivity to unemployment and unemployed people and is, as a consequence, not a fit person for his job and should himself see a psychologist?

—It is always a disappointment when honourable senators use Question Time to ask questions which cannot possibly be to the benefit of the people of Australia. I reject the gratuitous and unnecessary insult to my colleague the Minister for Employment and Youth Affairs. The Minister and his Department have a record of placing in employment most applicants for jobs, and of doing that job very effectively.
—He is an oaf and you know it-a complete oaf.
—Order! Senator Evans, I suggest that that remark was unparliamentary and ask you to withdraw it.
—I withdraw the suggestion that he is an oaf.

—The record of the Department is one of placing people in employment and the Minister in question administers a very extensive and successful program of youth training. The question was unnecessary and contributed nothing to the Senate.
—Mr President, I ask that further questions be placed on notice.

—I have had this happen with Senator Carrick before. I was on my feet, as was Senator McLaren, before Senator Carrick got up. If my thighs are more vigorous than Senator Carrick's and I was able to stand up before he did I should have been given the call. Let me be quite blunt about this. We were here until 2 o'clock this morning. It does not matter if Senator Carrick will not let me ask the question now; I will ask it in the adjournment debate.
—Mr President--
—Order! Senator--
—Mr President, let me if I may disregard the abusive nature--
—Mr President, I take a point of order. I draw your attention to the fact that when you asked the Minister to sit down he refused to do so. He disregarded your request. I suggest that that was--
—Name him.
—No. Mr President, I suggest that Senator Carrick's action was a clear defiance of a ruling of the Chair. He should be made to answer for that.

—Senator Keeffe, there is no point of order. The Minister was speaking when I rose to my feet. My timing was a little late. I conceded that the Minister was addressing the chamber and as such I resumed my seat. I now call the Leader of the Government in the Senate.

—Mr President, had Senator Mulvihill made his request in a civilised way and not in an abusive way he would have been extended the courtesy I have always given under such circumstances. I disregard his abusiveness and invite him to ask his question.
—Senator Mulvihill, the Leader of the Government in the Senate has invited you to ask your question, but I hope you are aware of what he said.

—My question is directed to Senator Baume. Senator Carrick talked about civilised ways. I was extremely hurt on behalf of a lot of manual workers by what Senator Baume said in his gospel about salt and hypertension. The question I want to ask is an important one and I ask it of Senator Baume now.
—In which capacity?

—I am directing this question to Senator Baume. It is a question about salt and hypertension. Was the Minister suggesting in the thesis he expounded earlier that what he was saying applied to the steel worker working at an open hearth at Port Kembla on a hot summer's day? How does that worker substitute the salt he loses in perspiration? I am justified in asking that question. In deference to Senator Carrick, I point out that it was important that the question be asked. That is why I ask it.

—I presume that the honourable senator asked that question of me in my capacity as Acting Minister for Health, Mr President. The honourable senator asserted correctly that there are occasions when salt replacement is not only desirable but necessary. With that proposition no one would disagree. Nothing in the answer I gave in any way would alter the truth of that assertion. People who work in situations in which they sweat a lot and lose salt require salt replacement. Apart from that, my previous answer remains correct.

QUESTION.SPEAKER: Guilfoyle Sen The Hon Dame M.G.C.

TALK.START.PARA: —Earlier this morning Senator Sibraa asked me a question about the late Mr Tony Joyce. I responded by saying that the Prime Minister had commented on that matter. I have a copy of the Prime Minister's comments made a week ago at Question Time in the other place. The points made by the Prime Minister in response to a question asked by Mr Lionel Bowen are these:

QUESTION.PARA: There is some information that I can give the honourable gentleman. The honourable gentleman will know from earlier indications that have been given in the Parliament since Tony Joyce was shot in November of 1979 that representations to the Zambian Government have been made on a number of occasions. I wrote to President Kaunda on the day on which news of the shooting was received seeking information. Subsequently, the Acting Foreign Minister wrote to his Zambian counterpart to establish the outcome of investigations undertaken by the Zambian authorities. Tony Joyce was a fine man and a credit to his profession. His death was a great loss. We were all concerned, naturally, to know how and why this tragedy occurred. Earlier this year President Kaunda wrote to me personally about the matter. The President pointed out that Zambia was under attack at this time from Rhodesia. As a result Zambian military and security units were deployed to guard economic and strategically important installations throughout the country, working under highly explosive and very difficult conditions. Movement within the country was restricted and under security control. Investigations conducted by Zambia have not identified the individual or individuals responsible for the shooting. There are different accounts of what happened. It seems unlikely, because of the difficulty and uncertain circumstances prevailing at the time, that the issue will ever be fully resolved.

In his letter to me President Kaunda very sincerely expressed his regret that Tony Joyce, who was merely carrying out his normal duties, was caught up in this unfortunate situation and lost his life on Zambian soil. I spoke to Mrs Joyce at the time of Tony Joyce's death and conveyed the Australian Government's condolences and my deep personal regret. Since I received President Kaunda's letter I have spoken to Mrs Joyce again and conveyed the sentiments expressed by the President. Tony Joyce's death has been a matter of great sorrow for his family and his friends and I am sure that all honourable members would join with me in expressing again our sincere sympathy to Mrs Joyce.

That was the Prime Minister's comment which I think covers the points that were raised. I think the honourable senator asked whether this matter could be raised again at the meetings next week. I think, in view of the correspondence and the communications between the President and the Prime Minister, that such an approach would not take the matter any further than the response of the Prime Minister last week was able to do.

TALK.START.PARA: —by leave-I wish to make a very brief statement. I thank the Minister for Finance for the comprehensive answer to the question. The family and friends of Tony Joyce who are concerned about the circumstances requested me to ask specifically whether this matter could be raised at a person to person meeting with President Kaunda because there are some aspects of the case about which they are still not happy.

—During Question Time today Senator Grimes asked me a question about a couple of cases in which the Administrative Appeals Tribunal recommended that an ex gratia payment be made to appellants-people who have appealed against decisions of my Department in respect of pensions or benefits. I am advised that there are only two cases in the category that the honourable senator has raised in his question. Neither I nor my Director-General has any authority to make an ex gratia payment in the circumstances of these cases. The Minister for Finance may, pursuant to the Audit Act 1901, approve an ex gratia payment. My Department has written to the Department of Finance seeking advice on the matters raised in the question. I should be able to give the honourable senator further information at a later stage.

ANSWER.SPEAKER: Chaney Sen The Hon F.M.

TALK.START.PARA: —Over the last couple of days Senator Jessop, Senator Teague and Senator Hill have raised with me their concern over the effects in Australia, particularly South Australia, of the marine engineers industrial action. The Minister for Industrial Relations has informed me in respect of Senator Jessop's concern about the effectiveness of current industrial legislation, and that concern was also reflected in Senator Hill's question, that the Conciliation and Arbitration Act already places considerable emphasis on means to safeguard the public interest in any industrial situation. The Minister further advises that the Government is conscious of the need for such legislation to be able effectively to safeguard the public interest and the legislation is under continual review to ensure that that intention is realised. I think that answer is consistent with the answer I gave Senator Hill a few minutes ago.

ANSWER.PARA: In respect of the current dispute, the Government is, as I have already indicated in response to similar questions yesterday, concerned at the situation, particularly in South Australia, as a result of this dispute. We have sought the intervention of the Australian Council of Trade Unions in an effort to bring some sanity and sense of perspective back into the union's thinking. The ACTU has sought a full return to work to allow negotiations to proceed or at least a lifting of the bans on oil supply vessels. Additional exemptions have been given by the marine engineers in this regard. The Conciliation and Arbitration Commission has been heavily involved-again, I indicated that in response to honourable senators' questions yesterday and today-in seeking a resolution of this very damaging dispute. The Government continues to support the Commission in its endeavours and to urge all parties to accept its rulings. As a result of discussions between the six maritime unions and further proceedings before a Deputy President of the Conciliation and Arbitration Commission on 23 September, I am advised that the executive of the Australian Institute of Marine and Power Engineers is to meet today. The Minister for Industrial Relations is most hopeful that following this meeting Institute members will decide to return to work on Friday.

ANSWER.SPEAKER: Chaney Sen The Hon F.M.

TALK.START.PARA: —On 27 August Senator Coates asked me a question concerning the issue of additional health cards to applicants' spouses and children. I wish to advise him that my Department will provide copies of health care cards to dependants. This was known to him, of course, at the time he asked the question. Copies of the card will be issued on request and there will be no need for dependants to justify their need. When I responded to Senator Coates on that date I advised him that we are now ensuring-this was, of course, a prospective assurance because at that stage the scheme was not in operation-that the unemployed, new migrants and so on will automatically receive a similar card.

ANSWER.PARA: I would like to clarify the situation which currently applies to migrants. At the moment new migrants are required to apply for a card. Arrangements are in train for overseas posts of the Department of Immigration and Ethnic Affairs, which is responsible for the issue of migrant visas, to provide, at the same time as the issue of a visa, an application form for a health card. On the presentation of this form to a regional office of the Department of Social Security in Australia a card will automatically be issued. These arrangements should be in operation at overseas posts in four weeks time. With respect to that matter, and the lesser degree of the automaticity of the application of the card, the problem is that the Government does not supervise the date of entry of migrants. It does, of course, control the issue of visas but those visas, once issued, are open for a considerable period and the migrant makes his or her own decision about method and time of entry. For that reason it is necessary for the application to be lodged on arrival in Australia so that the full six-month entitlement can be obtained.

ANSWER.SPEAKER: Messner Sen The Hon A.J.

TALK.START.PARA: —Mr President, on 16 September 1981 Senator Mason asked me a question without notice in connection with welfare housing and I undertook to get a more detailed reply from the Minister for Housing and Construction. I have some more information on this matter. As it is rather long, I ask that it be incorporated in Hansard.

ANSWER.PARA: Leave granted.
The document read as follows-

Australians have for many years enjoyed a very high standard of housing and the Government's policies are intended to maintain this situation. The Government's welfare housing programs are directed at the needy who unfortunately cannot gain access to housing on the private market. That those policies are working is evidenced by the waiting list for public market housing which now stands at about 86,000, compared with about 104,000 in June 1975.
As is usual at Budget time, there has been extensive lobbying for additional funds for welfare housing, including representations by the Victorian Minister of Housing.

These representations do not adequately recognise that welfare housing is a joint Commonwealth-State responsibility and that the States can, if they wish, use their general revenue funds made available by the Commonwealth to their welfare housing programs, where they see this as a priority.

While full details are not yet available from all States, it is clear that some States have increased their Budget outlays on housing and, most importantly, are further developing innovative schemes such as interest subsidies to make more effective use of available funds.

I also remind the honourable senator that States have available to them surpluses and revolving funds arising from past Commonwealth involvement in the operation of their housing programs, which are estimated to be a further $160 million in 1981-82.
The Commonwealth is not considering increasing funds available for welfare housing. It announced that it is providing $262.2 million in 1981-82 and this amount is set out in the Budget documents.

The Commonwealth's allocation for funding for welfare housing, combined with the resources available to the States for welfare housing, and the policies contained in the 1981 Commonwealth-State Housing Agreement, are a responsible package aimed at efficiently providing the needy with decent housing.

TALK.START.PARA: —Mr President, earlier today Senator Lewis asked me a question in connection with the shipping industry. I have a little more information in connection with the cost to the Australian industry through industrial disputes. Whilst it is not possible to be precise, it is estimated that the cost to the Australian shipping industry of the marine engineers dispute during this month of September is of the order of $12m. The total cost to the industry of the several rolling stoppages by maritime unions since May would be of the order of $25m.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Jones Sen G.N.

TALK.START.PARA: —Mr President, I seek leave to make a personal explanation.
—In relation to what, Senator?
—In relation to a question that was asked in the other place this morning.

SPEECH.PARA: Leave granted.

TALK.START.PARA: —Although I do not have a copy of the Hansard report I refer to a question that was asked this morning in the other place by Mr Katter in relation to my 'amazing revelation on radioactive hamburgers'. First of all, I just say that I did not make that statement. What I did say-and I stand by it-is that next we will be able to export radioactive beef to America. The reference to radioactive hamburgers was a flair from the pen of a very talented journalist. In answer to the question, Mr Nixon said that I would be better off going back to Breakfast Creek and having a couple of drinks. I believe the statement by Mr Nixon does very little for his portfolio and very little for the other place. In relation to the matter that was raised I do wish to validate the point that I made in relation to exporting radioactive beef. I have here a copy of a letter from a station owner who owned five stations in Queensland and who very clearly and concisely outlined what will happen in that area.

—Senator, I suggest that you do not go into any of the details in that letter. You have been given leave to make a personal explanation and I suggest you do confine your remarks to that explanation rather than go into further debate and canvass issues.

—I do believe that I need to clarify some of the matters in this Statement because it seems to me that the honourable member for Kennedy was trying to make out that the statement I had made in relation to radioactive beef was a loose statement that had no basis to it. I think he misrepresented me and I need your leave, Mr President, to clarify the situation in relation to that statement I made.

—Senator Jones, if you so desire you could seek leave to have that letter incorporated in the Hansard, but you could just give a very brief explanation of it to back up your case in your personal explanation.
—I seek leave to incorporate part of that letter in Hansard and also a copy of a statement made by the Wardens Court in Charters Towers.
—Has the Minister seen it?
—I suggest the whole of the letter be incorporated in the Hansard.
—Could I briefly refer to just one particular line in this--
—Do you seek leave to have the letter incorporated?
—Part of it.
—Because it is essential to know what is the full sense of the letter, I suggest that the whole of it be incorporated.

—I would be only too glad to give the Minister a copy of the letter so that the confidentiality of the writer can be covered. I would also incorporate all the letter in Hansard, other than the signature and the address of the people concerned.

—I do not want in any way to prevent the presentation of this material. Indeed, when the Senate resumes after the break I will be happy to give some technical and expert information on this whole subject. I am looking at the procedures of this situation. I think it is absolutely necessary to assure ourselves whether or not the incorporation of the whole letter is possible. I do not want to infringe confidentiality in any way. I want to be sure that the Senate has the full sense of the correspondence when it is in Hansard. Perhaps I could look at the letter now to see whether it can be incorporated.
—I suggest that while the Leader of the Government is looking at the letter Senator Jones should continue with his explanation.
