—The first point I raise concerns this letter from the manager of a station company that owns five cattle properties in Queensland. He very clearly points out to the Conservation Council in Townsville that there are some very real problems in relation to Keelbottom Creek and the fact that 6,000 head of cattle graze and water in that area. Secondly, the Wardens Court in Charters Towers took evidence. In summing up the evidence, the Warden said:

SPEECH.PARA: Stockpiling of ore will present a problem if there is exposure to the weather with subsequent leaching of toxic substances into the environment. However, it is my opinion that it is the treatment of ore in this area and the long term storage of tailings and residues in the area which drains into Keelbottom Creek and ultimately the Burdekin River which are the main matters for concern.
I recommend to the Minister that this application be rejected in so far as it relates to the areas to be used for the Evaporation ponds . . .

I think that clearly shows that the statement I made that we will be able to export radioactive beef to America is backed up by the evidence placed before the Wardens Court in Charters Towers. In view of the question asked by Mr Katter and the answer given by Mr Nixon, I suggest that they take the time to read the report from the Wardens Court. Perhaps they will then know a little more about the subject of which they are talking.

TALK.START.PARA: —I think the Deputy Leader of the Opposition agrees that it is desirable that the whole text of the letter be incorporated. If the honourable senator feels that the writer's name and origin should be protected, that is perfectly all right. I indicate that, because what was a personal explanation has become a statement, I intend to make a statement, probably on the Tuesday the Senate resumes, to clarify many matters which on expert advice suggest that the facts are otherwise.

INTERJECT.SPEAKER: The PRESIDENT

TALK.START.PARA: —Is leave granted for the letter to be incorporated in Hansard?

INTERJECT.PARA: There being no objection, leave is granted.

We wish to acknowledge receipt of your letter of 10th instant together with the attached copies of various newspaper articles and the Mining Warden's recommendation. Our Pastoral inspector, Mr J. W. Stewart, has been asked to contact you and obtain a further two copies if they are available.

In any further action by your Council, we trust that you will not only give consideration to the interests of future prospectors and adventurers. Those people may occasionally operate in the area. Surely greater consideration should be given to people in the pastoral industry who spend a long period of their life in the area, not only on . . . Station, but also further down Keelbottom Creek. It is those people, just a short distance downstream from the mine, who are subject to the greatest concentration of radioactive contamination in their domestic water supply.
We wish you every success in your efforts to protect the people of the area from the effects of operations at Ben Lomond.

TALK.START.PARA: —I wish also to incorporate in Hansard the Warden's report.

SPEECH.PARA: Leave granted.
The document read as follows-

Application has been made by Minatome Australia Pty Ltd for a Mining Lease No. 893 over an area of 2035 hectares situated at Ben Lomond East in the Charters Towers Gold and Mineral Field, for the purpose of mining for Uranium, Molybdenum, Copper, Lead, Zinc and Silver and also for the carrying on of mining operations. The applicant already holds a Mining Lease No.827 over an area of 128 hectares at the site, which was granted on 27th March 1980. Since 5th August 1975 the applicant has held an Authority to Prospect No. 1543M over an area which encompasses both M.L. 827 and M.L.A. 893.

An objection to such Application has been lodged in accordance with Section 21 (8) of the Mining Act by Adrian JEFFRIES on behalf of the Townsville Regional Conservation Council on the following grounds-
1. Until it can be shown that it is in the public interest to grant a mineral lease over the area, no such lease should be recommended.

2. The Impact Assessment Study for the proposed mining development which was produced by Minatome Australia Pty Ltd in relation to Mining Lease Application No. 827 is an inadequate document which contains insufficient information upon which to base a proper assessment of the impact of this proposal. As the Federal Government is currently examining this proposal, any hearing with respect to this Mining Lease Application should be adjourned until the company produces an environmental impact statement that complies with the requirements of the Environmental Protection (Impact of Proposals) Act 1974.

3. The toxic and noxious wastes from the proposed mine will have a deleterious effect on the surrounding environment and on the health and well being of mine workers. In particular it will render unusable a significant portion of the Charters Towers Gold and Mineral Field for use by future prospectors and adventurers due to the presence of long term dangerous waste products.

4. That it is not in the public interest that a lease be granted permitting the mining of uranium until such time that it is shown that the processing, distribution, uses and disposal of the mined product do not cause unacceptable deterioration in public health and the environment.
5. The granting of the said mining lease will result in a diminution of outdoor recreation and environmental education resources already scarce in the Townsville area.

The applicant's purpose of obtaining this Lease is for the establishment of the major facilities associated with the mining treatment plant for the treatment of the ore mined from M.L. 827. Also for the construction of access roads, dams, water supply, power line, storage dams, evaporation ponds and pipelines thereto and storage sites for tailings. The area applied for also covers part of the ore body which extends beyond M.L. 827.

Section 21 (9) of the Mining Act provides that . . . the Wardens Court shall hear and determine the application . . . together with any and every objection lodged in the manner prescribed . . . and that the determination of the Wardens Court upon an application shall consist of a recomendation to the Minister as to whether the application should be granted or rejected in whole or in part.

Numerous witnesses have been called on behalf of the Applicant and the Objector, many of whom appeared well qualified in respect of opinions expressed. The hearing has extended over ten days and an inspection of the site was carried out by helicopter and motor vehicle. There were numerous exhibits tendered by both sides.

The case of John Sinclair v. The Mining Warden at Maryborough and Anor, clearly sets out the functions of the Warden in matters such as this. In my opinion the applicant has complied with all the formalities contained in the Mining Act and Regulations preliminary to the hearing in the Wardens Court. I do not consider that any irregularity exists in the making or lodgment of the application or in the marking out of the land applied for, that may give rise to any consideration by me that the application should be rejected under the provisions of Section 21 (11) (a).

Mere compliance with the formalities of course is not enough and I must satisfy myself on the material before me that the application is one proper for the recomendation of the granting of a Lease. The application covers an area of land which is mainly to be used in the treatment process, and for roads, pipelines, dams, ponds and the like. It also covers an extension of the ore body to the east of M.L. 827. The operation envisaged is a very large one, the shape of the area applied for is very irregular and appears to include only the area reasonably necessary for the mining operation. I am satisfied that the applicant has fully justified the application for such a large area as is covered by the application.

The grounds set out in the objection overlap in some respects. I am satisfied in relation to ground 1 that the applicant has established that the granting of the lease will be of economic benefit to the community. Of course in the overall assessment of the public interest the benefits provided must be weighed against the detriments, if any, to be caused by the mining operation.

In relation to ground 2 of the objection it is clear that the final detailed engineering planning for the proposed operation has not yet been completed and that the design is in the conceptual state only. The Environmental Impact Study (Exhibit 3) lacks detail and according to the evidence changes have occurred since its preparation in matters such as increased production, alteration in the water management scheme and changes to the treatment process. The proposals for the mining and milling operations are set out in Exhibit 10 and in the evidence of Mr Folwell, Operations Manager. Such proposals have been attacked by the Objector for their lack of engineering detail and the lack of hydrological and geological study which the objector contends is essential before it can be shown that it is feasible to permanently isolate from the environment all dangerous substances produced from the mining operation. It appears to me that the Environmental Impact Study required under Federal Legislation should be available for study before any decision is made on the granting of a Lease.

Ground 3 of the objection covers three heads-namely any deleterious effects on the surrounding environment, and on the health and well being of mine workers, and the rendering unusable for use by future prospectors and adventurers of a significant portion of the Charters Towers Gold and Mineral Field. There have been tendered in evidence-a copy of the Code of Practice on Radiation Protection in the Mining and Milling of Radioactive Ores-1980, copies of the Ranger Uranium Environmental Inquiry Reports, a copy of Rules and Regulations drawn up by the Nuclear Regulatory Commission in the United States of America in October 1980 which sets out licensing requirements for uranium and thorium milling activities including tailings and wastes generated from these activities. The latter of course do nor represent the law in Australia. In so far as the environment is concerned the proposed method of milling and the disposal of tailings and wastes and their eventual isolation, and the stabilization and rehabilitation of the area appear to conform with conventional requirements. Doubts have been cast by the Objector and the witnesses called on the ability of the Applicant to successfully carry out such proposals in this particular area having regard to some of the unique qualities of the site. The lack of hydrogeological study of the area has been pointed out, and evidence called to show that faulting and fracturing is abundant in the area. This has not been denied by the applicants witnesses who contend that such studies will take place at a later stage when more detailed engineering will take place. The objector has called evidence to show the unsuitability of the clay in the area for use as a sealer in the Evaporation Ponds and Tailing dumps, and also to encapsulate those areas in their final stabilisation. Evidence of the highly erosive quality of the country has been given and of the exceptionally high rainfalls which might be expected from time to time, which it is contended by the Objector would render stabilisation of contaminated wastes and tailings over a very long term impracticable. There is some doubt as to the identity and quality of all the toxic materials which might be expected to accumulate in the Evaporation Ponds during the life time of the mining operation.

It appears that there must be some seepage or leakage from the Evaporation Ponds whilst they contain water during the mining operation, and that there is also danger of movement of water through the residue in the Evaporation Ponds when mining is finished and through tailings which have been placed in the dump and the open pit. It appears to me that only detailed hydrological and geological study can provide the necessary information on which to base any decision as to the suitability of the sites for the establishment of the Evaporation Ponds and tailing dumps. As to the long term isolation of tailings and wastes it also appears that such study is essential.

I am satisfied that proper safeguards exist for the protection of the health and well-being of miners engaged in uranium mining such as is proposed and I do not consider that there is any evidence that the proposed mining will have any deleterious effect on the health and well-being of miners engaged therein so long as the Code of Practice is adhered to and all safeguards as provided by relative legislation are taken.

There is no evidence of any great degree of prospecting activity in the area. The old Argentine workings are some kilometres away. The only areas which could contain long term wastes after mining would be the area of the Evaporation Ponds of some 60 hectares and the area of the tailings dumps and waste rock dump. Considering the extent of the Charters Towers Gold and Mineral Field (which I have calculated at some 3000 square miles) I consider that the area rendered unusable for use by future prospectors and adventurers due to the presence of dangerous wastes would be insignificant.

I consider that part of ground 4 of the Objection (dealing with the processing of the mined product) is dealt with under ground 3. In so far as the remainder of this ground of objection is concerned in my opinion there is no evidence that the distribution, uses and disposal of the mined product would cause unacceptable deterioration in public health and the environment.

In relation to ground 5 of the objection, the area applied for is very inaccessible and in very mountainous and rough terrain and I cannot see that there will be any real diminution of outdoor recreation and environmental education resources. According to the evidence it is Keelbottom Creek and its environs which are the popular areas frequented by the public and by student groups and these areas are not included in the Lease application. I think that there would be a valid ground for objection under this head only if there was pollution from the mining operations of the creeks and environment in this area.

Having dealt with each particular ground of objection and the conclusions I have drawn on the evidence in respect of each ground it remains to consider the public interest. Clearly the evidence for the Objector has been directed to the public interest not only for the conservation of the area for various public uses but also to ensure that mining operations do not in any way pollute or contaminate the environment generally, the creek systems that drain the area of the mining operations and ultimately the Burdekin River into which the creek systems drain.

Evidence has been given of the possible movement of toxic metals through groundwater systems and through creek systems, and it seems that no limits can be placed on their possible ultimate destination, except that they would tend to accumulate at weirs and dams. The evidence of the Objectors witnesses does not clearly demonstrate to any accurate degree the quantity of toxic metals or wastes which may escape into the creek systems or the potential threat posed by them. On the other hand the applicant's witnesses have not satisfied me that there will be no escape of any toxic substances, or that any escape would be so negligible as to pose no danger to the environment.

In his Judgment in the case of Sinclair v. The Mining Warden at Maryborough and Another, Gibbs J. said ''For example a warden may recommend against an application not because he has formed the opinion that the public interest will be prejudicially affected but because he considers that the public interest might be prejudicially affected and that in all the circumstances of the case the application should not be granted until it is possible to say whether the effect of granting it will be prejudicial or not.'' This I feel is the position here. On the evidence I am left in some doubt on the following matters-

(a) The suitability of the site for the Evaporation Ponds, the site of the tailings dump and the open pit as a site for a tailing dump because of the lack of detailed geological and hydrological study to determine the potential of such sites for seepage or leakage of toxic materials into groundwater or nearby creek systems.

(b) The availability and suitability of clay which may be required as a liner in seepage control, should the necessary study prove such control necessary, and of the clay required for encapsulation of the residue sludge of the Evaporation Ponds and of the tailings dumps, taking into consideration the erosive nature of the country and the size of the area to be lined and sealed off from the environment.

(c) The possibility of effective long term isolation of any toxic materials contained in the residue sludge of the Evaporation Ponds and in the tailings dumps, taking into consideration the erosive nature of the country, the extremely high rainfall that might be expected in the area particularly during the cyclonic season, and the absence of any ongoing active maintenance during the hundreds of years after mining ceases.

(d) The quantity and description of all toxic materials likely to be generated by the mining and treatment process and deposited in the tailings dumps and Evaporation Ponds, and the likelihood of danger to the environment which would be caused by any escape of toxic material whether by leakage, seepage or otherwise, and the extent of pollution or contamination likely to be caused in the creeks in the area and in the Burdekin River.
I am of the opinion that the public interest or right may be prejudicially affected if the Mining Lease is granted at this stage.

This application covers an area where the ore body located in M.L. 827 extends beyond that lease, as well as areas for access roads, power supply, water supply and other facilities connected with the treatment plant. There has already been exploratory mining carried out on M.L. 827 and samples of ore have been stockpiled in the area. I can see no real objection to the mining of ore in this locality and the grant of a Lease over the area containing the extension of the ore body, and other areas for facilities for mining purposes only. Stockpiling of ore will present a problem if there is exposure to the weather with subsequent leaching of toxic substances into the environment. However it is my opinion that it is the treatment of ore in this area and the long term storage of tailings and residues in the area which drains into Keelbottom Creek and ultimately the Burdekin River which are the main matters for concern.

I recommend to the Minister that this application be rejected in so far as it relates to the areas to be used for the Evaporation Ponds, and tailings dump and the treatment plant and facilities pertaining thereto.
E. W. Lendich Warden Wardens Court,
Charters Towers,
27 April 1981

INTERJECT.SPEAKER: The PRESIDENT

TALK.START.PARA: —I wish to inform the Senate that Mr Harold Gibson Weir has ceased to hold the office of Commonwealth Parliamentary Librarian. Mr Weir has been absent from duty since early July this year and, on the recommendation of the Commonwealth Medical Officer, is currently on sick leave pending retirement.

INTERJECT.PARA: Mr Weir was first recruited to the Commonwealth Public Service in August 1965 when he joined the Department of Labour and National Service. His first appointment to the parliamentary service was in January 1968 when he joined the Staff of the Department of the Parliamentary Library to establish the Education and Welfare group of the Legislative Research Service. Under his direction that group became a highly effective element in the research service.

In June 1973 Mr Weir left to take up a position with the Institute of Criminology where he was subsequently promoted to Secretary of the Institute. He returned to the Parliamentary Library in August 1976 as Assistant Parliamentary Librarian and was appointed Parliamentary Librarian in 1978. In that capacity he worked strenuously to ensure that all parliamentarians received prompt and impartial service.

Under his administration the Department of the Parliamentary Library underwent change and development to a degree probably not known since the inception of the Legislative Research Service in the mid 1960s. During his time as Parliamentary Librarian the resources of the Department greatly increased and there are better career opportunities for staff than ever before. Technical advances have been very considerable and at the national and international level the Department is recognised as one of the best of its kind.

I greatly regret that ill-health has caused his early retirement. I wish to pay tribute to his most valuable contribution to the working of the Parliament and wish him and Mrs Weir a long and happy retirement.

TALKER.NAME: Senator CARRICK
TALKER.ROLE: Leader of the Government in the Senate)

TALK.START.PARA: —by leave-Mr President, the Senate would wish me to place on record its gratitude to Mr Weir for his long and dedicated service and its deep regrets that ill-health has caused him to reach the decision that he has made. Our wish is that his health will improve and that he will make a full recovery. I offer our warm wishes to him and his family for a long and very happy and healthy retirement.
—by leave-On behalf of the Opposition may I say that we regret Mr Weir's ill-health. We wish him well in his retirement.

—by leave-I should like to join with my Senate colleagues in placing on record our appreciation of the services of Mr Weir. I am deeply saddened that he has found it necessary to retire from the position of Parliamentary Librarian, a position that he held with distinction since his appointment. I had the great privilege of working with him in my capacity as a member of the Parliamentary Library Committee and in my capacity as a sub-committee member of that Committee. Mr Weir is a man of the highest integrity. He believed, quite justifiably, that the Parliamentary Library should be apolitical, that is to say not political, and should provide the highest service to members of parliament to assist them in the exercise of their functions. This he did with great merit and great distinction. I should like to wish him a speedy recovery. I hope that he and his wife enjoy their retirement.

—by leave-I should like to include the condolences of the Australian Democrats on the matter of Mr Weir's health. I first met him here in Canberra in 1978 when I was raw and a lot more naive than I am now.
—You are joking.

—The honourable senator may not believe it, but it is true, nevertheless. Mr Weir was of great assistance to me as far as access to the Parliamentary Library and its research facilities is concerned. On a social basis he was, co-incidentally, the godfather of my research assistant. I had not only a professional regard for the man but also a personal one. I and the Party should like to express our regrets about his ill health.

DEBATE.TITLE: COMPANIES AND SECURITIES LEGISLATION (MISCELLANEOUS AMENDMENTS) BILL 1981

PROCTEXT.PARA: Bill received from the House of Representatives.
Ordered that the Bill may be taken through all its stages without delay.
Bill (on motion by Senator Peter Baume) read a first time.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Baume Sen The Hon P.E.

TALK.START.PARA: —I move:

SPEECH.PARA: That the Bill be now read a second time.
I seek leave to have the second reading speech incorporated in Hansard.
Leave granted.
The speech read as follows-

This Bill, the Companies and Securities Legislation (Miscellaneous Amendments) Bill 1981, is a further step in giving effect to the Commonwealth's obligations under the co-operative companies and securities scheme.
I am confident that all honourable senators are aware of the co-operative scheme, the four basic elements being:
(a) the establishment of the Ministerial Council for Companies and Securities;
(b) the establishment of the National Companies and Securities Commission;
(c) the continuation of existing State and Territory corporate affairs offices; and
(d) the attainment of legislative uniformity throughout Australia without requiring the States to surrender or refer any constitutional power.

Further background information on the co-operative companies and securities scheme is contained in paragraphs 6 to 27 of the explanatory memorandum which has been distributed to honourable senators for information.

The first stage of the co-operative scheme commenced on 1 July this year when three of the four substantive codes came into operation in the six States and the Australian Capital Territory. These codes are:
(a) the interpretation code;
(b) the share acquisition code; and
(c) the securities industry code.

The Ministerial Council for Companies and Securities is hopeful that the Companies Code will be able to be implemented from 1 January 1982 although this depends to a large degree on the speed with which the remaining legislative and administrative matters can be finalised.
Background information on each of the four substantive codes is contained in paragraphs 28 to 41 of the explanatory memorandum I have already referred to.
Before I discuss the Bill itself, I would like to indicate to the Senate where we are heading with the co-operative companies and securities scheme.

At the last meeting of the Ministerial Council, it was agreed that during 1982 there would be no substantive amendments to the initial legislation. Initial legislation is that contained in the four codes I have referred to as amended up to and including the Bill I am presenting to the Senate today.

The first reason for this decision is the necessity to give the NCSC, State and Territory administrations and outside practitioners time to get used to the new administrative and legislative structures.

The second reason is that it will provide an opportunity to commence work on the preparation of exposure drafts of the various proposals for reform that have been held over until the initial legislation is in place.

The aim would be to prepare exposure drafts in April 1982 with a view to seeking public comments between July and October 1982. This legislation would, following consideration by the Ministerial Council, be introduced into the Commonwealth Parliament in the 1983 autumn sittings.

The parties involved in the co-operative scheme have emphasised the necessity for public consultation. The share acquisition, securities industry and companies codes have been exposed for public comment and debate. The contribution made by interested organisations and individuals has been substantial.
The Ministerial Council proposes to continue this consultative process where proposals for reform are put forward in the future.
If these objectives are achieved, I envisage that any amendments introduced in 1982 would cover tidying-up and other non-controversial matters.
Companies and Securities Legislation (Miscellaneous Amendments) Bill
The main purpose of this Bill is to make various minor adjustments to the Companies Code before each State introduces its Companies (Application of Laws) Bill.
A general outline of the Bill is contained in paragraphs 1 and 4 of the Explanatory Memorandum, and a detailed outline of each closure is contained in paragraphs 46 to 183.

The Bill contains several editorial amendments to provisions in the Commonwealth Acts under the co-operative scheme. The opportunity has also been taken in this Bill to make some other minor amendments.
The Bill has been approved by the Ministerial Council for Companies and Securities for introduction into the Commonwealth Parliament. I commend the Bill to the Senate.
Debate (on motion by Senator Ryan) adjourned.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Haines Sen J.

TALK.START.PARA: —I seek leave to amend notice of motion No. 1 standing in my name on the Notice Paper to accord with the form in which my proposed amendment has been circulated.

SPEECH.PARA: Leave not granted.

TALK.START.PARA: —by leave-In explanation of our not granting leave I inform Senator Haines that a reference proposed to a standing committee of the Senate is Business of the Senate. It therefore has precedence of all other business. By moving a reference to a standing committee the honourable senator has obtained precedence for her motion. She is now seeking a reference to a select committee. References to a select committee are General Business and they have the lowest order of precedence. The order of precedence is Business of the Senate, Government Business and General Business. It is perfectly appropriate, as far as we are concerned, for the honourable senator to seek leave to give a notice of motion for a reference to a select committee because by doing that she will be following the normal procedure in relation to General Business matters. Otherwise it is not an appropriate use of the forms of the Senate, which provide that Business of the Senate issues are for references to standing committees only. For that reason, leave is not granted.
—Leave is not granted for the proposed amendment.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Haines Sen J.

TALK.START.PARA: —I thank the Minister for Aboriginal Affairs (Senator Peter Baume) for his lucid explanation of the difference between a reference to a standing committee and a reference to a select committee and their order of precedence. It was one of the reasons I originally gave notice of the motion in the form that I did. However, at the request of the Opposition and in what my friend, if not colleague, Senator Evans, persists in calling a spirit of friendship and co-operation, I elected to amend the terms from a standing committee to a select committee. Although such a course might not be so expeditious, I felt that it could have been of more value to the Senate since the standing committees in this place are becoming overloaded and the number of senators constituting select committees is decreasing.
—Give notice of a motion to have it referred to a select committee. We will not object.
—If it is all the same to the Minister, having attempted to accommodate the Australian Labor Party by way of an amendment, I will move back to the original intention. I therefore move:

SPEECH.PARA: That the following matter be referred to the Standing Committee on Social Welfare: The conduct of private hospitals and nursing homes in Australia, including those conducted for profit and non-profit institutions, with particular reference to:
(a) the extent of Government subsidy of such institutions;
(b) their financial organisation and motivation;
(c) the type and frequency of services provided, with particular reference to so-called discretionary surgery in private hospitals;
(d) the comparison between private hospitals conducted for profit, non-profit private hospitals and public hospitals in respect of-
(i) type and frequency of services provided, and waiting lists for those services, with particular reference to discretionary surgery,
(ii) charges,
(iii) length of patient stay,
(iv) bed numbers and usage,
(v) degree of consultation with patients or their guardians, particularly in respect of discretionary surgery, and
(vi) degree of consideration of and response to community needs;
(e) variations by State, region and size and type of hospital in-
(i) bed usage,
(ii) surgery undertaken, and
(iii) length of patient stay;
(f) recording, accounting and referral procedures in private hospitals and nursing homes;
(g) staffing arrangements in private hospitals and nursing homes;
(h) the composition of private hospital and nursing home boards, with particular reference to any potential conflicts of interest; and
(j) the present and future role of private hospitals and nursing homes within the health care delivery system as a whole,
and that in its report the Committee make such recommendations as it considers appropriate for changes in public policy and law.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Baume Sen The Hon P.E.

TALK.START.PARA: —I understand that the motion can now be debated. The reference proposed is to a standing committee of the Senate. I have some objection to such a reference at this time, although it does not go to the subject matter which Senator Haines seeks to have referred. However, the Jamison Committee of Inquiry into the Efficiency and Administration of Hospitals, which had a large secretariat, only recently conducted extensive investigations and spent, I think, a couple of years looking at most of the matters the honourable senator wishes to have examined again. I would have some doubts as to whether the proposal for a Senate inquiry is properly based. But that is not my worry because the honourable senator is quite competent to move that the Senate Standing Committee on Social Welfare look at anything.

SPEECH.PARA: But matters of courtesy are involved. The chairman of the Committee is temporarily away from Australia. She will be back at the end of this week or early next week. I think it is entirely inappropriate to seek to force upon the Committee a reference which it has not, as a committee, had an opportunity to examine. I have been the chairman of a Senate standing committee and one of the difficulties is to program a committee's work properly and appropriately. I do not believe that the Standing Committee on Social Welfare has had an appropriate opportunity to look at this matter and decide whether it wants this reference. I cannot comprehend why the Australian Democrats have proposed such a reference without having gone first to the Committee to seek its views and to clear with it whether it was willing to take the reference. All that would be involved would be a brief delay. Surely the Committee should have some say and, at least, a chance to be heard. I have made Senator Haines aware of the fact that Senator Walters is away. I have also made her aware of the fact that I think it is inappropriate to try to force this on the Committee as some kind of urgent matter. It is inappropriate that she should use the forms of the Senate to seek to make this reference now and pick up, apparently some advantage of the moment. If she was seriously concerned about the issue she would have had the courtesy to wait until she can consult with the Committee chairman who will have to have the carriage of the matter.

I now advert to what we have just done. Senator Haines changed her course and said: 'All right, let us make it a select committee. Let us use the forms of the Senate to get ourselves precedence on the Notice Paper and then let us try to vary those forms to get a General Business motion up'. I repeat to the honourable senator that if she sought at any stage now to give notice of an intention to refer something to a select committee, which is the normal procedure, we would give leave for a notice of motion to be given. A notice of motion gives honourable senators an opportunity to examine what is being proposed. But is anyone really suggesting that we accept a technique whereby an honourable senator, as Senator Haines has done today, can slip in an amended motion for the establishment of a select committee when, in terms of the Standing Orders of the Senate, due notice has not been given?

I have not discussed the merit of the matter which it is sought to refer to a committee. It is of no concern to me. No doubt, if given an opportunity, the Senate Standing Committee on Social Welfare will express a view on its business priorities and on it desire to take the reference. I have been chairman of that Committee. It has a record of producing worthwhile material, but I know that it can take on board only an appropriate amount of work at any time if it is to carry out its duty to the Senate and produce reports of good value.

I want to say one other thing about service on Senate committees. It sits ill with the Australian Democrats seeking a reference to a Senate standing committee when, as I say, it has not cleared it with the committee and has not had the courtesy to wait until the chairman of the committee returns to Australia, and when members of that party will not serve and carry their fair share of committee service. On the eight legislative and general purpose standing committees there are 48 positions. That is a position for almost every senator who is not a Minister, a presiding officer or a leader. The Australian Democrats take two positions on the legislative and general purpose standing committees. Senator Mason is a member of the Senate Standing Committee on Science and the Environment and Senator Siddons is a member of the Senate Standing Committee on Trade and Commerce. No other member of the Australian Democrats serves on a standing committee. Yet they have the gall to try to put work on the standing committees on which they will not serve.

Senator Haines serves on the Standing Orders Committee, but that is not a legislative and general purpose standing committee. On the Estimates committees of the Senate, on which there are, I think, 48 places, I do not believe the Australian Democrats are listed to hold any place. The Australian Democrats are not represented at all on the joint statutory committees. The Australian Democrats are not represented on joint committees. I believe that on most of the general standing committees of the Senate the Australian Democrats are not represented. It simply will not work for the Australian Democrats to have the humbug to try to make work for other senators to do-for them to grandstand, to try to get all the glory of having raised a matter and then ask other senators to do the work. Until they are willing to do their fair share, I suggest the Senate reject this reference.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Mason Sen C.V.J.

TALKER.NAME: Senator MASON
TALKER.ROLE: Acting Leader of the Australian Democrats)

TALK.START.PARA: —The Minister for Aboriginal Affairs, Senator Peter Baume, has just put on a most extraordinary performance in this place. At the moment I am the Acting Leader of the Australian Democrats. I am maintaining my position as a member of a standing committee of the Senate. If Senator Baume wants to throw around beams or things of that kind, I suggest that he should get himself onto a standing committee. If it is all right for the Acting Leader of the Australian Democrats to be on a standing committee, it is perfectly all right for Ministers to be on them. He has no right to say that he has some sort of exemption, or that we are not fulfilling our places on committees. It is a fact that our new senators have been in this place only a matter of weeks. I should have thought, as a matter of courtesy, that they would have been allowed a little time to study the work that the committees do and, therefore, to be in a position to decide on which ones they can appropriately serve. That has been the situation.

SPEECH.PARA: Senator Siddons is a member of the Senate Standing Committee on Trade and Commerce. Senator Haines is going ahead to be a member of the Standing Orders Committee. What more does the Minister want? I think the whole argument which he put forward is ridiculous. He is trying to cloud the issue with something that is not relevant to this matter at all. The Australian Democrats are trying to bring into the open a question of great concern in this community. It is an important matter and requires attention. If honourable senators, having read through the suggested terms of reference, go on record as saying that these matters are not important, then they are welcome to do so. I know what sort of reception they would get from the community for having done that.

There is no question at all from anything that the Minister has said that there should not be a committee to inquire into this area. It is only a matter of the Senate in its wisdom deciding whether it would be better for that committee to be a standing committee or a select committee. Senator Baume has said that that issue must be obscured and clouded because of the Standing Orders of the Senate. If necessary, I can suspend the Standing Orders. The Government does it every day. Let us not have any nonsense about that. The Government uses the suspension of Standing Orders regularly in order to decide what it will do. It uses that technique from day to day. We use it ourselves from time to time. I suggest in good intent that it should not be necessary to have that sort of smokescreen poured over this important matter. Of course, this technique is used by the Government when something comes up which it does not want to have examined. This is the point. The Government does not want to have the question of private hospitals and nursing homes in Australia examined. That is what the Minister is saying: At this stage the Government believes it would be embarrassing to it and so it does not want to have the matter raised. All of the other nonsense that has been said so far is simply a smokescreen. I think that clears the air a little.

I would like to hear further debate on that matter and some assertion from the Government that it does not have anything to hide, that is does not really want to obstruct this inquiry. If it does not want to obstruct it then let us bring it on. Let us talk intelligently and in a reasonable way. Let us get this committee organised. Let us inquire into this terrible situation of so many elderly people and others in this country being exploited through the misuse of private hospitals. Senator Baume knows as well as I do that that is happening. I am sure that in his own private heart he is as deeply concerned about it as I am. Let the Minister level up. Let us be honest about the matter and get the committee going. I have great pleasure in seconding the motion of Senator Haines.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Missen Sen A.J.

TALK.START.PARA: —I wish to say a few words because I believe this issue ought to be examined. I support what the Minister for Aboriginal Affairs (Senator Peter Baume) has said in regard to the matter. The Australian Democrats have to realise that they cannot continue their practice of humbugging about, spending so much time on the development of terms of references for committees and then not be prepared to go ahead and actually serve and do the hackwork of the committee. It has been stated that they require time in which to find their feet. I would have thought that six months or eight months after their election the new senators would have worked out what the committees are doing and what they have done, and that they would have looked at committee reports. They would then be in a good position to decide what service they could do. I regret and have publicly deplored the fact that the Australian Democrats are not carrying out their fair share of the work not only on the standing committees but also on the other committees, such as the Estimates committees. It is all right for them to say: 'We are busy doing something else', but this morning they had the hide to say that the Minister ought to be a member of a standing committee. For Senator Mason to equate himself with the work of a Minister, when he is a shadow shadow Minister-he is very shadowy--
—They are not shadow Ministers.

—Senator Mason could call himself a shadow shadow Minister. He is a shadow shadow leader. I am not picking on the Acting Leader of the Australian Democrats because I know he has a difficult job to do in all the circumstances. He is setting an example to the troops by serving on a Senate standing committee. But alas, I say to the Duke of Plaza-Toro: Where are the troops behind you? They are not following his example and becoming members of committees as they should be doing. If this parliament and this Senate were to establish more committees a problem would occur in relation to the number of committee staff. As honourable senators know, the number is still ludicrously small.

SPEECH.PARA: Senator Mason thinks he can shuffle around 64 senators to serve on a lot of committees without that greatly increasing their already excessive work load, but he should realise that there is a limitation to the number of committees that can be set up and operate effectively. As one who has been the chairman of many standing committees-at one stage, three at a time-I know that it is very embarrassing for a committee to take on a reference and do nothing about it. If a committee puts aside an inquiry for a year or 15 months it is criticised in this chamber. On one occasion my committee took on three or four references because we thought we would consider them in sequence when we could, but a year later people said: 'The Senate demanded that you deal with these matters and you have not done so'. Therefore, we were criticised for it.

TALK.START.PARA: —Let us have a select committee. That will do what we want.

—A select committee does not change the situation. A select committee would necessitate the employment of additional people to staff that committee and a new secretary. The committee would still have to hold meetings and take evidence on the reference and so on. Setting up a select committee is no answer to the problem at all. We must accept that there is a limit to the number of members of the Senate. There is a limit on our abilities and the number of functions we can perform at one time along with other things. The Australian Democrats have to carry out their share of the work of the Senate-not only by making suggestions on matters that ought to be examined but also by rationing the ideas that can be put forward at one time. The Australian Democrats should not expect to impose, as it is trying to do, an inquiry on to a committee when the chairman of that committee is absent. The chairman knows the extent to which the committee could manage another reference. The Australian Democrats should have the courtesy at least to postpone this matter for a period and not to try to force the inquiry on to a standing committee.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Grimes Sen D.J.

TALK.START.PARA: —Far be it from me to interfere in a squabble between the conservative forces in this House, but I think I should indicate that on this last day of sitting before a break we have a deliberate attempt at time wasting, I suggest, by the Government and a deliberate misstatement of what is happening. We have humbug, I suggest, on both sides. The situation is that a couple of weeks ago Senator Haines gave notice of her motion that there be a reference to the Senate Standing Committee on Social Welfare to look into private hospitals and nursing homes. She spoke to me, as both spokesman on health in this place and a member of the Senate Standing Committee on Social Welfare, about the matter. It is my understanding that she also spoke to the Minister for Aboriginal Affairs, Senator Peter Baume, as he is the Acting Minister for Health. So we have all known about it. I put it to Senator Haines, and I believe Senator Baume put it to Senator Haines, that it was not right to refer the matter to the Standing Committee on Social Welfare because of the absence of the Chairman and because she had not consulted with the members of the Committee. Senator Haines accepted that.

SPEECH.PARA: Senator Baume knows she accepted that. She then looked at how she could raise this important matter. I suggested-I think she agrees-that the matter would be better referred to a Senate select committee, perhaps a small Senate select committee. Everyone in this place knows that that has happened. It is utter humbug for the Minister and Senator Missen to go on as though they knew that that was not going to happen. Senator Haines, feeling that this matter was important, found that the best way to raise the matter was, in fact, to move her motion in the original way and have it amended to read that the matter be referred to a Senate select committee.

As Senator Baume said, she is using the processes of this House to bring up her motion and her reference. To accuse her of humbug and nonsense in doing that is the height of hypocrisy. The Government does that every day of the week in this place. It manipulates the Standing Orders and the order of business to get its own way and to stop debate on other issues. It is only after the crunch has come-as it came last night when the Government realised what the numbers were-that we will debate Senator Ryan's Bill on Queensland Aborigines today. If the Government had the numbers we would not be debating that Bill; it would be manipulating the processes of this chamber to avoid it.

Let us stop this nonsense of saying that people are being naughty and are manipulating the affairs of the chamber. They are not. They are using the processes to raise what they consider to be an important motion. The matters raised by Senator Missen and Senator Baume are, of course, important. The Australian Democrats in this place have a penchant to raise all sorts of matters they consider to be important. Their Leader has proposed something like 17 Senate inquiries, including inquiries into animal welfare. I must say that I have yet to see the Democrats being willing to take their fair share of that burden.

By the same token, yesterday I suggested on behalf of the Opposition one way in which we could overcome those difficulties. I suggested that we do what we have done in the past, set up a committee of four senators instead of six-a perfectly efficient method. Senator Missen, who is today complaining about the work load of senators, on that occasion said that that was an outrageous suggestion, that four people could not do the work and that we had to have six people. The Government was willing to use the processes of this place under the Standing Orders to defeat my amendment by insisting on six instead of four. So I withdrew the suggestion of having four people and we ended up with six.

What will happen and what everybody knows will happen is that another member of the Democrats will move an amendment to Senator Haines's motion to make it read that the matter be referred to a select committee. It may be a clumsy way to go about it but it is the only way the Democrats can go about it in order to bring up this important matter now. I suggest that we let them go about it, let the Senate decide just what sort of committee we will have and not have this nonsense of arguing about standing committees.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Gietzelt Sen A.T.

TALK.START.PARA: —The Australian Democrats are a new party seeking, therefore, to make an impact on a number of important issues. It is interesting that the issues they are raising are issues that have been raised in the Senate over a period. The Government has not in any way, shape or form reacted to a number of the matters that have been the subject of notices of motion that senators from the Australian Democrats have sought to have the Senate examine. We all recall a very vigorous and detailed analysis of what was happening to private hospitals by Senator Justin O'Byrne. He raised the matter on a number of occasions in this place. What has the Government done about it? It has done absolutely nothing, as in a number of areas we are seeking to have select committees deal with.

SPEECH.PARA: Shortly I will be seeking to raise the electoral deficiencies that exist. I expect to get some support from the Australian Democrats on that matter. Everybody knows that this Government has had some inquiries into the deficiencies of the Commonwealth Electoral Act but it has done nothing about them other than to have inquiries. It has not been prepared even to make available to the Parliament the subject of its inquiries. It recognises the deficiencies that exist in that Act. Of course, in the area of private hospital care very serious exploitation is taking place of people who have nobody other than governments to protect them. The Government is deficient and is falling down in its responsibilities to these people who are being ruthlessly exploited by the private hospital system, most of which is owned by medicos, by people involved in the medical care area.

I know that because when I was in local government I knew that numerous applications for the erection of private hospitals came from local medicos who were seeking further ways in which they could invest their tremendous accumulation of capital. We know that a multiplicity of private hospitals has grown into the system As former Senator Justin O'Byrne pointed out, we are now faced with a foreign invasion of our private hospital system. What better way is there to examine this problem and to find out what really are our social and parliamentary responsibilities than to have a select committee inquiry? We can agree with some of the observations that have been made by Senator Missen. We know that this suggestion will impose an increased work load upon senators. But there are areas in which those of us who are already overworked are prepared to be even further overworked in order to carry out our responsibilities in--

TALK.START.PARA: —I undertake that we will play our part on this.

—I have the assurance of the Democrats on this matter because they feel strongly about it as, indeed, does the Australian Labor Party. The Fraser-Anthony Government in its death throes is not doing anything about a whole variety of areas of concern to the Australian community. It is prepared to have the Parliament rise three weeks earlier than has ever happened before. It was prepared to extend the Senate sittings in the May-June period in order to get legislation passed before the views of the electors were expressed on the result of the change in the political composition of this place; but now the Government is proposing to have the Senate and the House of Representatives rise early in November-not because there is not work to be done but rather that it cannot face the political reality, the political dissension that exists in the ranks of the Government parties.

SPEECH.PARA: Unfortunately, in areas such as medical care people in the private hospitals suffer because of the lack of Government attention. I am surprised at Senator Baume. He is an honourable senator for whose identity with health care matters, because of his own participation in the medical profession, I have a great deal of respect. He knows as well as many other medicos what is going on in private health areas-exploitation of our community. It seems to me that it is just humbug and hypocrisy to suggest that the motivation of some honourable senators is suspect because they want to take up these matters. We in the Labor Party will find someone on our side of politics to serve on this committee, as indeed will the Democrats. If the Government is not prepared to provide somebody that will be to its disadvantage. We will be insisting that staff be made available for these select committees and these extra commitments so that the committees fulfil their proper role.

We have heard a lot, even from Senator Missen in times gone past, about the role of the Executive, the role of the Senate, and the role of the Parliament. Surely it is not asking too much in a situation where honourable senators want to undertake a proper examination of areas in which they feel very grave irregularities and deficiencies are occurring, for the Senate to take some steps to examine and carry out a survey of those matters with a view to some rectification. I believe this will be a feature of the work of the Senate, perhaps for the next six years, perhaps even for the next 60 years, and that the Senate will take on the sort of important investigative role that has made the American Senate system so important in American politics.

No matter what change of government takes place, as assuredly it will in 1983, I will still espouse the same view. The Senate should have an investigative role, not for the purpose Senator Lewis and some other honourable senators suggested yesterday of putting ourselves in a position of being prosecutors and carrying out some sort of persecution of people and issues, but rather to acquaint the Parliament and the Australian people with the gross abuses that are taking place. I suggest that there is prima facie evidence of gross abuse of private hospitals in Australia. Therefore the Australian Labor Party will give support to the motion of the Australian Democrats.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Lewis Sen A.W.R.

TALK.START.PARA: —The Senate Standing Orders are to protect honourable senators and to enable them to carry out their duties as best they can. What bothers me about this matter is that it has now reached the stage of being a convention of the Senate that, if there is to be a reference to one of the legislative and general purpose standing committees of the Senate, the reference is first of all mentioned to the chairman of the committee, who then has an opportunity to consider its terms and discuss them with the members of the committee before the motion for reference is carried. That means that when honourable senators see that there is a proposal to refer a matter to a standing committee they need not concern themselves very much about the terms of that reference. They know that if the convention, observed in normal circumstances, has been carried out the usual inquiries will have been made by the chairman and members of the committee.

SPEECH.PARA: On the other hand, where there is a motion to refer a matter to a select committee, honourable senators know that it has not been considered by the members of the committee and that they need to apply their minds to the matter. That is why the Standing Orders create a situation where notice of the reference can be given and honourable senators have time to consider it. It is not until such time as honourable senators find out that it is not proposed to refer a matter to one of the legislative and general purpose standing committees that they discover they ought to be looking at it. When did honourable senators find out about the proposal in regard to private hospitals and nursing homes? They found out about three-quarters of an hour ago, when Senator Haines sought leave to alter the notice she had given.

With all due respect to Senator Haines and the Australian Democrats, they seem to be interested in serving only on such committees as may achieve maximum political publicity. If one looks at the seven standing committees of the Senate it will be seen that one Democrat is serving on one of those seven standing committees. On the legislative and general purpose standing committees, of which there are eight, I think there are two members of the Australian Democrat party serving. I do not think an Australian Democrat is serving on any of the eight Estimates committees of the Senate. I do not think a Democrat is serving on the three joint statutory committees, nor is there a Democrat serving on the three joint standing committees. Yet in their motion they propose to lumber with this reference a committee which may have all sorts of responsibilities. I have spoken to one of the members of the Senate Standing Committee on Social Welfare, who said it would not be possible to look at the matter of private hospitals and nursing homes in less than six months. The Australian Democrats have given a notice of motion setting out a whole list of matters, but there has been no investigation by anyone other than themselves as to whether these are the only matters the Committee ought to look at or whether matters are included which the committee ought not to be concerned about. The Democrats have come into the Senate and by a misuse of the Standing Orders of the Senate, with all due respect, endeavoured to get some priority for their motion. I am totally opposed to that misuse of Standing Orders.
Amendment (by Senator Macklin) proposed:
That all words after 'That' be omitted and in their place the following words be substituted:
'(1) a select committee, to be known as the Select Committee on Private Hospitals and Nursing Homes, be appointed to inquire into and report upon . . .
The conduct of private hospitals and nursing homes in Australia, including those conducted for profit and non-profit institutions, with particular reference to:
(a) the extent of Government subsidy of such institutions;
(b) their financial organisation and motivation;
(c) the type and frequency of services provided, with particular reference to so-called discretionary surgery in private hospitals;
(d) the comparison between private hospitals conducted for profit, non-profit private hospitals and public hospitals in respect of-
(i) type and frequency of services provided, and waiting lists for those services, with particular reference to discretionary surgery,
(ii) charges,
(iii) length of patient stay,
(iv) bed numbers and usage,
(v) degree of consultation with patients or their guardians, particularly in respect of discretionary surgery, and
(vi) degree of consideration of and response to community needs;
(e) variations by State, region and size and type of hospital in-
(i) bed usage,
(ii) surgery undertaken, and
(iii) length of patient stay;
(f) recording, accounting and referral procedures in private hospitals and nursing homes;
(g) staffing arrangements in private hospitals and nursing homes;
(h) the composition of private hospital and nursing home boards, with particular reference to any potential conflicts of interest; and
(j) the present and future role of private hospitals and nursing homes within the health care delivery system as a whole,
and that in its report the Committee make such recommendations as it considers appropriate for changes in public policy and law.'
(2) The Committee consist of four Senators, as follows:
(a) two to be nominated by the Leader of the Government in the Senate;
(b) one to be nominated by the Leader of the Opposition in the Senate; and
(c) one to be nominated by the Leader of the Australian Democrats.
(3) The Committee proceed to the despatch of business notwithstanding that all members have not been duly nominated and appointed and notwithstanding any vacancy.
(4) The Committee elect as Chairman one of the members nominated by the Leader of the Government.

(5) The Chairman of the Committee may, from time to time, appoint another member of the Committee to be the Deputy-Chairman of the Committee, and that the member so appointed act as Chairman of the Committee at any time when there is no Chairman or the Chairman is not present at a meeting of the Committee.
(6) In the event of an equality of voting, the Chairman or the Deputy Chairman when acting as Chairman, have a casting vote.
(7) Two members of the Committee be necessary to constitute a meeting of the Committee for the exercise of its powers.

(8) The Committee have power to send for and examine persons, papers and records, to move from place to place, to sit in public or in private, notwithstanding any prorogation of the Parliament or dissolution of the House of Representatives, and have leave to report from time to time its proceedings and the evidence taken and such interim recommendations it may deem fit.

(9) The Committee be provided with all necessary staff, facilities and resources and be empowered to appoint persons with specialist knowledge for the purposes of the Committee with the approval of the President.
(10) The Committee be empowered to print from day to day such papers and evidence as may be ordered by it, and a daily Hansard be published of such proceedings as take place in public.
(11) Except where the Committee by vote otherwise decides, its hearings of evidence be open to the public.
(12) The committee report to the Senate as soon as possible.

(13) If the Senate be not sitting when the Committee has completed its report, the Committee may send its report to the President of the Senate or, if the President is not available, to the Deputy-President, who is authorised to give directions for its printing and circulation and, in such event, the President or Deputy-President shall lay the report upon the Table at the next sitting of the Senate.
(14) The foregoing provisions of this Resolution, so far as they are inconsistent with the Standing Orders, have effect notwithstanding anything contained in the Standing Orders.

TALK.START.PARA: —Is the amendment seconded?
—I second the amendment.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Haines Sen J.

TALK.START.PARA: — I have been quite astounded at the sorts of things raised during the debate to date on what I intended to be a quiet little affair. I wonder what would happen if I tried to stir trouble in this place. Before getting to the gist of the matter, I wish to answer a number of points raised by both the Minister for Aboriginal Affairs (Senator Peter Baume) and Senator Lewis. Much has been made of the fact that the Chairman of the Senate Standing Committee on Social Welfare, Senator Shirley Walters, is away. I inform the Senate, as I previously informed the Minister, that I spoke to her about this matter very early in the present session. I informed her that the Australian Democrats intended, for a number of reasons, to refer to her Committee the matter of private hospitals, private nursing homes, and discretionary surgery. When I informed her of that she in no way indicated her displeasure or concern over the matter.

SPEECH.PARA: It has also been continually thrown in our faces that apparently we are not carrying enough of the work load of the Senate. I assumed that honourable senators in this place were more than competent to handle their work load. It seems, however, that they are not. If the assertions of Senator Lewis and Senator Missen are to be accepted, it seems that they see themselves as somewhat inadequate. The Australian Democrats are quite happy to help them out. However, I refer the Senate to a minor anomaly. When I was in this place in 1978 I did just about everything but grovel-in fact, I may well have done that-to both the Opposition and the Government in order to be allowed the privilege, in the six months I was in this place, to have an official position on a Senate standing committee. That was denied me, and instead I took up the option that is open to all honourable senators to attend Senate committee meetings as a committee moves around the country investigating particular matters. In fact, I did that with the Senate Standing Committee on Education and the Arts when it investigated the influence of television on children. I do not for a moment regret the time I put into that. It was a most interesting Committee, and I found it an invaluable experience.

I have extremely high regard for the work that the Senate committees, both select and standing, achieve for the Parliament. For instance, the work of the Senate Standing Committee on Social Welfare, when Senator Peter Baume was its more than competent chairman, in its investigation of the drug situation in Australia is to be commended. Certainly no slight is intended by me or by my party by the fact that we are spreading ourselves fairly thinly. However, I would point out that, between us, we are on three standing committees and two select committees, and that it is my intention to be one of the four members of the select committee that Senator Macklin has proposed. Thus it seems to me that for five of us to be on six committees when there are only four of us available at the moment is really not doing too badly at all.

The Minister brought up the question of the Jamison report-the report of the Commission of Inquiry into the Efficiency and Administration of Hospitals. I intend to say a little more later about the comments in that report concerning private hospitals and nursing homes. Whatever submissions were made to the Jamison Commission, its comments on the private sector of the health care system in this country were extremely limited. As I said at the beginning of my remarks, I am somewhat astonished at the strength of feeling that is being indicated on the Government benches over an inquiry which I feel-my feeling is shared by members of the Australian Labor Party-is of considerable relevance to the Australian people. I deeply regret that what I feel is a serious question relating to health care in this country is being turned into a political football. It is implied that in our terms of reference we beg the question and make assertions or come to judgments. That is not so. I would have thought that anybody who made even a cursory glance at the terms of reference would see that we have bent over backwards not to prejudice the question in any way. Rather, we leave it entirely to the committee to decide. A great deal has been said, especially in the last few months, about our health care system, about the doctors who are involved in it, about the hospitals and the nursing homes where it is practised, and about uses and the occasional abuses.

TALK.START.PARA: —I rise on a point of order. I suggest that the honourable senator is now talking about the contents of the amended notice of motion rather than about the question that is proposed to the Senate.
—I had intended to canvass the issues now. If that is out of order, I will not do so.
—The honourable senator may proceed at this stage.

—It seems to me that health care is in a similar box to education in this country. It should not be in the position of constantly being inquired into, argued about, changed, manipulated and politicised. Nevertheless, that is what is happening. As with education, health care should be strictly a non-party political matter. Again I refer to the fact that our terms of reference reflect an attempt to make the inquiry non political. Unfortunately, within the health field, there is opportunity for a small minority of people to make vast sums of money out of the system as it operates at the moment. If this is not actually to the detriment of other people, at least it is not greatly assisting them. In view of this we have moved for this inquiry.

SPEECH.PARA: In the interest of expediency and of reaching a decision on the matter before the sitting is suspended for lunch, I shall restrain my eloquence and say, simply, that we have moved this motion in response to increasing expressions of concern in the community about the ownership and operation of private hospitals and private nursing homes, recognising that the majority wish being tainted by criticism which, one hopes, is applicable only to a few. The motion also has been moved in response to disturbing disclosures in the Press, the Bulletin in particular but other areas of the printed medium as well, concerning increasing numbers of deaths from tonsilectomies performed on young children, the alarming increases in other forms of so-called discretionary surgery and the apparent lack of adequate consultation between doctor and patient. Finally, we have moved it in response to recent changes in the health insurance area which clearly will support the private sector. Since taxpayers are supporting that sector through the Consolidated Revenue, the payment of subsidies and so on, we maintain that the public has a right to know what it is supporting.

To achieve those ends it is essential that a thorough and specific investigation be undertaken into the ownership and operation of private hospitals and nursing homes, the scope and degree of government assistance to those hospitals and nursing homes, and the acquisition of statistics, which are extremely hard to acquire or get out of anybody at all at the moment, on discretionary surgery in Australia. I commend the amendment to the Senate.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Grimes Sen D.J.

TALK.START.PARA: —I rise to support the amendment but not the motion. When the notice of motion was first put on the Notice Paper the Opposition's welfare committee considered it, as it considers all such matters. We did not take the attitude that Senator Lewis takes, that only the members of the Standing Committee on Social Welfare should consider it. I commend our approach to Senator Lewis and his colleagues. If they adopted it they would not be caught short, as they have been on this occasion.

SPEECH.PARA: We oppose referral of this matter to the Senate Standing Committee for much the same reasons as Senator Peter Baume and Senator Missen have given. However, we believe that it is an important matter, that the terms of reference are satisfactory and that it is essential that people in this community know just what is going on in the private hospital system. Therefore, we support the reference of this matter to a small select committee of this House. We are perfectly willing to serve on it so that we can look at this very important problem.
