DEBATE.SUB1.TITLE: Reference to Standing Committee on Constitutional and Legal Affairs

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Missen Sen A.J.

TALK.START.PARA: —I move:

SPEECH.PARA: That the following matter be referred to the Standing Committee on Constitutional and Legal Affairs:
Continuing oversight of the implementation of reports of the Law Reform Commission.

I feel I must make a brief comment on this matter, particularly on the origins of the proposal for parliamentary oversight of Law Reform Commission reports, in view of the fact that what is sought by the Senate Standing Committee on Constitutional and Legal Affairs is a continuing reference in regard to the matter. The Committee in its report entitled Reforming the Law, tabled in the Parliament in May 1979, made a series of recommendations involving the Parliament in the processing of law reform proposals put forward by the Australian Law Reform Commission. Among those recommendations, which appear at paragraph 2.60 of the report, were proposals that all reports of the Law Reform Commission, following their tabling in the Parliament in accordance with the requirement under the Law Reform Commission Act 1973, should be referred to an appropriate parliamentary committee.

It was further recommended that the committee in question should consider and report promptly to the Parliament on whether the legislation proposed by the Commission should be enacted as it stands or should be subject to specified amendments. It was recommended that, if the proposed legislation is merely technical or otherwise non-controversial, the committee should specifically report to that effect. It was recommended also that the committee in its deliberations should liaise closely with the Commission to ensure full understanding of the Commission's proposals and an appreciation of why alternative approaches were rejected and that any proposed amendments are able to be accommodated within the framework of the Commission's Act.

The Constitutional and Legal Affairs Committee's recommendations envisage that the normal obligation on the responsible Minister to respond within six months to a parliamentary committee report should attach also to a parliamentary committee report on a Law Reform Commission proposal. In so doing the Minister would be required to inform the Parliament of the Government's intentions regarding the Commission's proposals. The Constitutional and Legal Affairs Committee in its recommendations emphasised that reference of a Commission report to a parliamentary committee should not preclude the Government from acting as quickly as it thinks fit to implement the report. Finally, it was recommended that the committee to whom a Commission report is referred should retain, both during its deliberations and after it has reported to the Parliament, a general watching brief over the progress of that report and should take such action as it considers desirable to prompt the introduction and passage of legislation to give it effect. Those recommendations have not been accepted by the Government, but I think it is important to remind the Senate that we thought that was the ideal type of scrutiny for the purpose.

The Constitutional and Legal Affairs Commitee, in its discussion on those recommendations, pointed out in the report that reference to a bipartisan parliamentary committee was 'perhaps the most frequently recurring suggestion as to the appropriate machinery for processing recommendations of the Law Reform Commission' when a Commission report was tabled in the Parliament. That comment appears at paragraph 246 of the report. Some of the proponents of this suggestion specified the Constitutional and Legal Affairs Committee as the appropriate body to undertake the review function. The committee scrutiny was envisaged as capable of achieving a number of diverse functions. Many people saw its role as being to prod the Executive into action on those matters unlikely to be accorded high priority because of their technical nature. Such a committee could periodically press the Government department, or departments, responsible for considering a report and preparing a ministerial submission to Cabinet for explanations of progress being made. Similarly, the committee could attempt to ensure that other proposals were not being ignored because of their controversial nature. Among the suggestions made in the report entitled Reforming the Law was the following:

A particular means by which pressure might be applied to the Executive would be for a Parliamentary committee which had decided to endorse a report of the Law Reform Commission to 'adopt' it for all intents and purposes, thus invoking the procedure presently employed in respect of all reports of Parliamentary committees, namely that the Government undertakes to make a statement to the Parliament within six months of the tabling of a committee report as to the Government's proposed action.

Among other suggestions was that the report of the parliamentary committee should be expressed in such a form that approval of the report would amount to a motion that a Bill comprising the draft legislation proposed by the Law Reform Commission, as amended if necessary by the Committee, be read a first time. In discussing that recommendation, the Constitutional and Legal Affairs Committee noted that implementation of such a procedure need not detract from the Government's right to assess independently the Law Reform Commission's proposals, to determine whether to accept the proposals in full or in part and even to determine the priority of legislation. This could be achieved through the Government's control of parliamentary time. It need not allow the legislation to proceed to second and third reading stages. It would nevertheless be obliged promptly to decide its attitude to the legislation and either move to have it processed through all stages, amend it, or oppose it for publicly stated reasons. I stress that that was just a suggestion and of course, it has not been adopted.

A further possible function to be assigned to the parliamentary committee was that it could certify that particular proposals were not controversial, thereby enabling them to be passed without debate unless any member of the appropriate chamber requested such a debate and the chamber resolved to debate the proposals. The Constitutional and Legal Affairs Committee was conscious of the subjective nature of such a certification power and recognised that it should not conclusively determine the course of subsequent debate. It was suggested that if, following an informal certification by the Committee, the proposal was laid on the table for a certain time before a motion to pass without debate was moved members could specify those first, without taking up valuable parliamentary time to do so. The Constitutional and Legal Affairs Committee, at paragraph 2.49 of the report, commented:

Parliamentary debate on a proposal could be expected to be shorter and more enlightened if members of either chamber were able to arrest any doubts about a particular proposal by referring to the report of the Committee which had examined the law reform proposal.

The Constitutional and Legal Affairs Committee still holds the view that a lot is to be gained from the examination by a parliamentary committee of reports of the Law Reform Commission and is prepared to take up that role itself, as was suggested by some people who gave evidence to the Committee during its inquiry into the processing of law reform proposals. We envisage the role as a continuing one to which we will turn our attention as the need requires. It is not contemplated that that will be a matter to which we will immediately turn. We have no particular intention in regard to any particular report of the Law Reform Commission, but we feel that a continuing reference of this nature would be a useful one, not only to draw the Senate's attention to the need but also to draw to the attention of other standing committees and other committees of the Parliament the reports on matters which are in their domains.

For the information of the Senate I seek to have incorporated in Hansard a document which outlines the current position regarding the reports of the Law Reform Commission which are still awaiting substantial implementation, or rejection, by the Government. It is to those reports that the Committee will direct its attention.
Leave granted.
The document read as follows-

TALK.START.PARA: —I thank the Senate and I trust that it will support the motion which I have moved.
—Is the motion moved by Senator Missen seconded?
—Mr Deputy President, I second the motion moved by Senator Missen to refer this matter to the Standing Committee on Constitutional and Legal Affairs.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Evans Sen G.J.

TALK.START.PARA: —It will come as no surprise that the Opposition warmly endorses the proposal to refer Law Reform Commission reports to the Standing Committee on Constitutional and Legal Affairs. We have been unceasing in our endeavours to get the Government to pay far more serious attention to the reports of the Australian Law Reform Commission than it has been in the habit of doing in the past. We see the proposed mechanism which Senator Missen has outlined as being a very useful way of placing additional momentum behind the reform process. The record of implementation of recommendations contained in Law Reform Commission reports by the Government has been a very poor one indeed. It is true that several reports have been transformed, to a greater or lesser extent, into law to the extent of the Commonwealth's competence to do so. I acknowledge that that has been the case with respect to the two reports entitled Complaints Against Police, the report entitled Alcohol, Drugs and Driving, the report Human Tissue Transplants and, to a partial extent, the report Privacy in the Census. But no legislative action whatsoever has been taken in respect of six other reports of the Commission-the majority of those that have been prepared since its inception, which date all the way back in fact to 1975. I might briefly indicate what those six reports are. For a start there is the Criminal Investigation report which has been the subject of a promise for the introduction of a new criminal investigation Bill based on a modification of the Commission's recommendations. We are supposedly going to see that Bill this session. I will believe that when I see it, given the history of that report.

SPEECH.PARA: Then there is the report entitled Insolvency: The Regular Payment of Debts, which has been languishing in the Department of Business and Consumer Affairs since 1977. There is the report entitled Unfair Publication: Defamation and Privacy which has been languishing in the other limbo of lost causes-the Standing Committee of Attorneys-General-since 1978 with the Attorney-General (Senator Durack) making it abundantly clear this week at an Estimates committee hearing that he would take no unilateral action whatsoever on behalf of the Commonwealth to implement the findings of that report to the extent of the Commonwealth's competence to do so.

The 1979 report on privacy, the first stage of which has been partially implemented, is still awaiting further legislation which again we have been promised this session, but with the rumours so rife about an early rising of this Parliament this session there must be very real doubt whether that in fact will come to pass. The same applies to the sentencing report of January 1980 which, although largely in interim form, does contain a number of legislative recommendations for immediate implementation which again have been the subject of a Government promise to introduce this session. But again, whether we see them remains very much to be seen. I will believe them when I see them. The Lands Acquisition report of March 1980 has been buried since that time in the bowels of the Department of Administrative Services. I have no idea when it is going to see daylight. Finally, of course, there is the report on insurance agents and brokers of July 1980 on which the Government has taken a firm position, namely, a firm position to reject out of hand-a position which will, of course, be tested by the private member's Bill that I have introduced and which I hope will be coming on shortly for full debate in this House.

In conclusion, I just add that whenever I speak on this subject in public debate, as I have on several occasions, namely the inertia, the lethargy, the failure of will and the failure of nerve of the Government on law reform issues, and again, whenever I refer, as I often do, to that emerging phenomenon known as Durack's law, namely that the prospect of the implementation of any given law reform proposal varies in inverse proportion to the importance of the subject matter and the quality of the supporting argument, I tend to be met with the response from the Attorney-General that I and members of the Opposition who share these views are blindly besotted by the reports of the Australian Law Reform Commission, that we are always urging the Government to implement such reports without the Government exercising any significant independent judgment at all.

It is true that I and the Opposition hold the reports of the Commission and the efforts in particular of its Chairman, Mr Justice Kirby, in far higher regard than obviously do the Attorney-General and this Government. The reports are the product, as has been said many times before, of enormous industry, of a very wide consultation, of many public hearings and of a great deal of input from all the relevant experts in the subject areas around the country. The reports are invariably well and lucidly written and they are certainly held in very high international regard. What I certainly have never said, however-nor to my knowledge has anyone else on the Opposition side-is that these reports should be implemented without any consideration or input from the Government of the day at all. Of course it is the case that reports of this kind from the Law Reform Commission, however carefully formulated and drafted, may well have a political dimension to them which it is entirely legitimate for the Government of the day to consider in the light of its own political priorities. I acknowledge that and I have never said anything different.

But what is not tolerable is the endlessly recurring situation, with which we have become so familiar, of the reference back to these reports once they are in fact brought down by the Law Reform Commission to the Government departments relevant to them in order that there might be a complete de novo re-evaluation of everything contained in such reports, as if the reports in fact had not been the product of the enormously lengthy process of consultation both with experts and the community or of the enormously careful input of the Commission itself that such reports invariably have. It seems to me that we have a situation of the endless reinvention of the wheel so far as these Law Reform Commission reports are concerned. Our view is simply that much greater respect and regard should be had to the process which underlies the preparation of those reports by the Government-a much greater respect than the Government has been in the habit of giving them. The Government's attitude should be that reports coming from the Law Reform Commission under these circumstances should be implemented. There is a very strong prima facie case for their implementation unless there is some overwhelming and obvious political reason for the Government of the day not doing so. That is not an attitude which the Government has taken in the past. But it is an attitude which may well be encouraged by the machinery establised in this reference. For those reasons we warmly support it.
Question resolved in the affirmative.

DEBATE.TITLE: AUSTRALIAN CAPITAL TERRITORY STAMP DUTY AMENDMENT BILL 1981AUSTRALIAN CAPITAL TERRITORY TAX (INSURANCE BUSINESS) AMENDMENT BILL 1981AUSTRALIAN CAPITAL TERRITORY TAX (CHEQUES) AMENDMENT BILL 1981

PROCTEXT.PARA: Debate resumed from 22 September, on motion by Senator Peter Baume:
That the Bills be now read a first time.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Mason Sen C.V.J.

TALKER.NAME: Senator MASON
TALKER.ROLE: Acting Leader of the Australian Democrats)

TALK.START.PARA: —I wish to refer to another chapter in the murky serial story of the razor gang which concerns an important facility in my area of New South Wales. The Government announced in its Review of Commonwealth Functions, so called, that the Experimental Building Station at Ryde, Sydney, was to be disposed of. The station which is located on land which is mostly undeveloped is in a prime real estate area of Sydney. Maybe we can expect a real estate developer to submit the highest bid if the station actually goes for sale. That would seem to me to be a logical result of the Government's cynicism and lack of concern for the public interest in seeking to dispose of this highly important and useful public facility which has been established for many decades and without which the cost of building would have been much higher in this country. The station has had an enormous influence in respect of the revision of building standards. Such things as the lowering of the height of ceiling studs were experimented with and researched by that organisation and have had a fundamental effect on the cost of houses. Houses are expensive enough but without the station they would be very much more expensive, and they can be expected to be very much more expensive in the future.

SPEECH.PARA: The Government announced that the station simply would be disposed of. This is charming terminology. It is as though one were simply to take the lid off the rubbish can and drop the station in. However, we now have a little more information about this matter. An advertisement which appeared in the Australian Financial Review of 11 September 1981 is headed: 'Commonwealth of Australia, Sale or Lease of Experiment Building Station'. This is where the dirty deed is provided for in detail. The advertisement states:

The Commonwealth's aim is for the EBS to be taken over as a going concern. The successor organisation would be required to demonstrate that it could maintain the EBS's reputation for impartiality and technical excellence and that it would be prepared to continue its role . . .

I would have been much happier, the Australian Democrats would have been much happier and the people of New South Wales would have been much happier if we had seen a situation in which the Government's set intention had been for the EBS to be taken over as a going concern so that we could be reassured that this organisation would be allowed to continue on its set course and continue the work for which it has been so much noted in the past. But the Government has not done that. It has said that it has an aim. This means nothing. All the rest of this advertisement that is supposed to indicate that the Government is going to maintain the standards of the station, of course, is nonsense because the Government has kept its options open; it has allowed itself an out on the actual means of disposal.

Basically one would have thought that the valuable and vital work that is being done at the EBS would have been very expensive to undertake, but in fact that is not the case. This establishment costs a modest $1.75m a year which is a mere drop in the bucket in any fiscal or financial terms. We could run this experimental building station for a decade on what the Commonwealth Heads of Government Meeting is costing. That is the truth of the matter. We have to look at this situation in the light of that comparison. The Australian Democrats believe that the expenditure of less than $2m is very well justified by the scope and success of the work of the station. The running costs could be reduced if fees for certain work done for industry were raised to a more realistic level. I have raised in the Senate before the question of the cost to industry for work done at this facility. A year or two ago I raised a question of what the Atomic Energy Commission was charging for its services. I am glad to see that, perhaps partly as a result of my raising the question, the Government has taken that into account and the Commission will be charging more reasonable fees to organisations which are well able to afford to pay for the services rendered. The same could be done for the EBS. The EBS could probably be put in a situation in which it was running at virtually no cost to the community. I think that would be the ideal situation.

It might be said that the disposal of the station, as proposed, will have no perceptible effect on the national economy. It will once again merely serve, as with so many of these razor gang cuts, to destroy a useful facility, a valuable and honoured facility. It has done useful things for this country and is respected throughout the world. I will shortly describe some of the work that is done at the station. I spent a day at the station because I thought it was worthwhile. I asked some fairly searching questions of the staff. My impression was that this station is not, with respect to any other area of the Public Service, dragging the chain. It is an extremely hard-working place; a very useful facility with a highly dedicated group of professional people who, for the reasons I shall describe, will not be able to carry out their work with any responsibility if the station is purely put to private enterprise.

Some of the work at risk includes research into earth walled pise and adobe buildings. This research work is being used all over the world. Third World countries regularly seek information from this station on research into these building materials. Research is being done which the Third World countries cannot do themselves because the research continues over a number of years. Australia's standing in the eyes of Third World countries has been greatly enhanced by this work. The testing has taken decades to set up and it will take decades more before it can be completed. This work is being smashed completely by the Federal Government. I can see no way any private enterprise organisation could possibly finance it. There is no question of charges being made to Third World countries. The Australian Democrats do not believe there should be any charges to them. This is a proper, sensible and useful form of foreign aid which has been of tremendous assistance at the grass roots in many Asian countries in the provision of information to enable people to house themselves.

The station has also provided a useful general information service to council building departments and students. Virtually every architectural student in Australia has had recourse to its circulars. Presumably that service will be discontinued in the future. I would like assurances from the Government that it is not going to be discontinued. In fact, I would like assurances from the Government that everything going on at this station somehow will be continued.

There is also an excellent acoustics laboratory where much vital and painstaking work has been done into the sound transmission properties of Australian building materials. Valuable research is conducted into the means of preserving historic buildings. Almost every aspect of building has been investigated and researched by this estimable, highly professional organisation. One of the more unusual aspects of its work, but one of some value which the staff at this station did not think was beneath their responsibilities, was discovering some way of removing spray painted graffiti from the sandstone walls of historic buildings in Sydney which were being defaced by irresponsible persons. That work in itself is of very considerable value because it has led to a means of protecting and restoring, without damaging the original structure, buildings which are of inestimable and irreplaceable value to this country.

The cost of housing has become such a critical factor in the lives of millions of Australians that it is absurd effectively to cripple an organisation which for four decades-I repeat, four decades-has played such an important and innovative part in revising housing standards, very often in ways which have reduced costs. More than the $1.75m a year it costs to run gets back to the community. For four decades we have been getting a very good thing out of that place. It has been saving us hundreds of millions of dollars in building costs. It has saved us far more than it has cost to run it ever since it was established. I am interested in the advertisement which states that it is to be sold or leased because I cannot see any conceivable way it could be leased. I think the Government is again just letting itself off the hook. If it had merely said the station would be leased under certain conditions we might have been able to understand its reasoning a little better but the option for the sale of the station must indeed create a situation in which it will be cynically destroyed. No doubt the land around it will be seen to be a high rise area and somebody or other with close association with the Liberal Party will seek to make several hundred million dollars out of it. We will be watching for that sort of situation to develop and if it happens we will not overlook it; we will be raising it perpetually in this place. So the Government can be warned that that situation of exploitation for its friends will not have any opportunity of being achieved.

The point is that if the station is sold, no matter to whom, the appreciable influence the work of the station has had on holding down building costs will no longer be available. If it does carry on its research programs, which is debatable, in any case under a new owner the fruits of that research will have to be paid for at far higher rates than apply now. Perhaps we could accept that, but the point is that once the station is put in the situation in which it has to cope with the profit motive it is unlikely that research will be carried out in the same effective way that it has been in the past. I think it has been proven by organisations all over the world that innovative research organisations which want to go into speculative, innovative and important research which do not immediately make a profit cannot expect a business to take them over and run them at a profit. That is not a criticism of business. It is just irresponsible of the Government to expect that it could work. Business is out to make a profit, and that is reasonable. The Government is wholly to blame for this irrational idea that this station should be disposed of.

One of the most serious aspects of the effect of this decision, I suggest, for the Australian community in the future is the interruption of the very important work that is going on at the EBS into fire hazards of large city buildings and especially the control of lethal smoke movement. If the Government disposes of the EBS and this work is ended-I spent some time waching the complex and painstaking way in which this work was being carried out with the use of quite large equipment-and this country is faced with a Towering Inferno type fire in which people are overcome by smoke or killed in large numbers then the health and lives of those people will indeed be on the conscience of every member of the Government. I think that is not too much to state because the Government has been told plainly that this work is vital, the work is not being done anywhere else and the results of the work could save the lives of hundreds of Australians in the future. I think to destroy that research is an evil thing. It was made obvious to me by the people I spoke to while at the EBS that that kind of fire is only too likely now because of the nature of modern buildings which are a higher fire risk than the older buildings because of their relatively open structure, which enables draughts to go through them quickly, and the extensive use of certain plastics. It is the smoke from those plastics which causes most of the loss of life. As far as I know no other place in Australia can do the work that is going on at this station and I cannot see that any private enterprise organisation could make money out of this research because it is research into the general principles of fire proofing and the movement of smoke. This is most important work. The work that is being done will provide the guidelines-it will take a number of years yet to complete-for how people should move around in buildings where there is a fire, where windows should be located in order to get the smoke out of the building quickly and vital basic matters of that kind.

The Australian Democrats and I particularly, as a senator for New South Wales, feel that the decision to end the work of this station is a very unpleasant, stupid and unproductive action. It is one of many taken by this Government which in its closing years or months in office in this country has reached the stage at which it is almost crippled or impotent and is unable to distinguish right from wrong and good from bad. That is the most charitable interpretation I can put on it. The Government truly has reached the stage at which frankly it does not know what it is doing. It is despairing at its own infighting It is despairing at its own lack of ideas. It has reached the stage at which it can no longer discriminate between what is good and what is not good for the Australian community and perhaps that is as serious an indictment of it as anybody could make. Perhaps that is the best reason the Government should either smarten itself up or surrender its mandate. I think it has no other alternative.

It as essential that the Experimental Building Station should be free to carry out the kind of innovative research it has traditionally engaged in and is engaged in now. Its disposal to private enterprise would mean its aims will be reshaped, at best to suit the profit motive, and it will probably be reduced to a mere testing station. At worst, it will be dismembered, undoubtedly sold and disposed of cynically, as I said, to the profit of the Government's friends.
Question resolved in the affirmative.
Bills read a first time.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Guilfoyle Sen The Hon Dame M.G.C.

TALK.START.PARA: —I move:

SPEECH.PARA: That the Bills be now read a second time.
I seek leave to have the second reading speeches incorporated in Hansard.
Leave granted.
The speeches read as follows-
AUSTRALIAN CAPITAL TERRITORY STAMP DUTY AMENDMENT BILL 1981

This Bill is the first of three Bills needed to give effect to the proposal announced by the Treasurer in his Budget Speech to increase the rates of stamp duty and similar tax payable in respect of certain instruments and transactions connected with the Australian Capital Territory, including the Jervis Bay Territory.
Mr President, by way of background I mention that stamp duty was introduced in 1969 on a range of instruments and transactions in the Australian Capital Territory.
At that time, the rates of duty were set at levels comparable with rates imposed by the States on similar instruments and transactions.
In the intervening years the rates of duty applying to the majority of instruments and transactions dutiable in the Territory have fallen significantly behind those imposed by the States.
The Government believes that there is no justification for maintaining this advantage for residents of the Australian Capital Territory over residents of the various States.

For this reason, and taking into account also the marked growth of Canberra both as a city and as a centre of business, the Government has decided to take steps that ensure that residents of the Territory bear stamp duty comparable to those levied on residents of the States. This Bill and the Bills that follow give effect to this decision.
I refer now to the various instruments that are to be subject to an increased rate of duty.
Cheques drawn or made on a banker at a branch of the banker in the Territory, and other bills of exchange or promissory notes drawn or paid in the Territory, are the first category.
The present rate of stamp duty on this category of instrument is five cents.
The rate proposed by this Bill is ten cents per instrument.

The new rate will apply in respect of cheques drawn on or after 19 August 1981 and to any other bill of exchange or promissory note that has not been duly stamped by reason of having been drawn or paid before 19 August 1981.
Transitional arrangements included in the Bill will, however, enable bank customers to continue to draw cheques on forms supplied to them before 19 August 1981 without incurring the higher duty.

It is also proposed that conveyances of freehold land in the Territory and agreements for the granting, transfer or assignment of leases of land in the Territory executed on or after 19 August 1981 will be subject to increased rates of duty.
The increase will not apply in respect of conveyancing transactions for which an agreement for transfer had been executed by the parties before 19 August 1981.
For a transfer of freehold land, the present rate of duty is at the flat rate of $1 for each $100, or part thereof, of the value of the interest transferred.
This basis of duty also applies in respect of a transfer of a crown lease granted for more than five years.

For other transfers of leases, including crown leases granted for periods of five years or less, the existing rate of duty is the same as I have just mentioned, but it is imposed on the value of the consideration given by the transferee.
The remaining dutiable transaction dealt with by the Bill is the grant of a lease, other than by the Commonwealth.
On the granting of such a lease, duty is presently payable at the general rate I have mentioned but is applied to the value of the consideration given by the lessee otherwise than by way of rent.
For consideration given in the form of rent, duty is imposed at the rate of 30 cents for each $100, or part thereof, in the total rent payable for the specified period for which the lease is granted.
It is proposed that the general rate of stamp duty in respect of all of these classes or instruments be increased, as follows:
For every $100, or part thereof, of the freehold value or lease premium the rate is to be-
$1.25 for amounts up to $14,000;
$2.50 for amounts in excess of $250,000.
It is also proposed that the duty payable in respect of the rental component of a lease be increased from 30 cents to 35 cents per $100, or part thereof.
A memorandum containing more detailed explanations of the technical aspects of this Bill and the other two Bills to which I have referred is being circulated to honourable senators.
I mention that legislation to introduce a Territory Stamp Duty on new and transferred vehicle registrations and on life insurance policies will be brought before parliament later in the sittings.
I commend the present Bill to the Senate.
AUSTRALIAN CAPITAL TERRITORY TAX (CHEQUES) AMENDMENT BILL 1981
This Bill deals with the rate of stamp tax payable in respect of cheque forms supplied or used by authorised banks in the Australian Capital Territory.
The present rate of tax payable in respect of cheque forms supplied or used by a banker in the Territory is five cents per form. It is proposed to increase the rate to ten cents per form.

The increased tax will apply in respect of all cheque forms supplied or used by a banker in the Territory on or after 19 August 1981. Existing unused cheque forms held by bank customers will not bear the increase.
I commend the Bill to the Senate.
AUSTRALIAN CAPITAL TERRITORY TAX (INSURANCE BUSINESS) AMENDMENT BILL 1981

This further Bill relates to the rate of stamp tax payable on premiums received by a registered insurer in the Australian Capital Territory, again including Jervis Bay, in respect of certain classes of general insurance business, broadly, insurance other than workers' compensation and third party insurance on motor vehicles.
The existing rate of tax is five per cent of the premiums received in the Territory on Insurance effected in the Territory.
It is proposed to increase that rate to seven per cent in relation to premiums received by an insurer in respect of insurance effected by the insurer on or after 19 August 1981.
I commend the Bill to the Senate.
Debate (on motion by Senator Sibraa) adjourned.

PROCTEXT.PARA: Consideration resumed from 22 September, on motion by Senator Carrick:
That the Bills now read a first time.
Question resolved in the affirmative.
Bills read a first time.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Guilfoyle Sen The Hon Dame M.G.C.

TALK.START.PARA: —I move:

SPEECH.PARA: That the Bills be now read a second time.
I seek leave to have the second reading speeches incorporated in Hansard.
Leave granted.
The speeches read as follows-
AUSTRALIAN CAPITAL TERRITORY TAXATION (ADMINISTRATION) AMENDMENT BILL 1981

This Bill is the first of four Bills to implement further proposals relating to stamp duties and taxes imposed in the Australian Capital Territory, including Jervis Bay, that the Treasurer announced in his Budget Speech on 18 August 1981.

Mr President, in the statements accompanying the Treasurer's Budget speech it was indicated that following a review of the level and scope of the stamp duties and taxes imposed in the Australian Capital Territory, the Government had decided to impose two new duties in the Territory. The first is to be imposed on new life insurance effected in the Territory and the other on new and transferred motor vehicle registrations in the Territory.
This Bill and three associated Bills that I shall introduce shortly, contain the provision necessary for the imposition and collection of the two new charges.
In announcing the new taxing measures the Treasurer indicated that they would apply from 1 October 1981.
That remains the Government's intention and it is hoped that passage of the Bills will occur in time for the Bills to come into operation on that date.
Following approval of the Bills by the Parliament they are to come into operation on the date fixed by proclamation.
I turn now to the substance of the present Bill.
It will amend the Australian Capital Territory Taxation (Administration) Act 1969 to incorporate machinery provisions for the assessment. Collection and recovery of the two new taxes.

The scheme to be implemented to impose and collect tax on new life insurance effected in the Territory is modelled largely on the existing scheme relating to the tax on general insurance effected in the Territory.

Persons who carry on a business of life insurance in the Territory will be required to register with the Commissioner of Taxation and lodge monthly returns of premiums received in respect of taxable life insurance business.
Insurers will pay the amount of the tax payable in respect of that insurance but will be authorised to pass on the tax by recovering it from the persons liable for payment of premiums.
For the purposes of the new tax, life insurance falls into two broad categories.
The first category relates to temporary and term life insurance.

With this type of insurance, the term of the insurance is limited to a specified period and the sum insured is payable only in the event of death, within that period, of the person whose life is insured.
If the person does not die in that period, no amount becomes payable under the policy.
Tax is to be imposed in respect of this category of life insurance at the rate of 5 per cent of the amount of the premium payable in the first year of the insurance.
The second category is life insurance other than temporary or term insurance.
Included in this category is whole of life and endowment insurance and the amount of the tax is to be calculated by reference to the sum insured.
For life insurance with a sum insured greater than $2,000 the amount of tax is to be $1 plus 20 cents for each $200, or part thereof, of the amount of the sum insured that exceeds $2,000.
Where the sum insured is between $100 and $2,000, the rate of tax will be 10 cents for each $200, or part thereof, of the sum insured.

Tax on life insurance will not be payable if the person whose life is insured is domiciled outside the territory and stamp duty or other similar tax imposed by a state or other territory has been paid in relation to that insurance.

This exemption is to avoid the possibility of double taxation where a person who takes out life insurance in the ACT is required to pay stamp duty in a state or territory because, for example, he or she lives in that state or other territory.
An exemption will also be provided for personnel of diplomatic missions of other countries where the other country provides a reciprocal exemption for Australian diplomatic personnel.
I turn now to the new tax to be imposed on new and transferred vehicle registrations effected in the territory.
The tax is to be imposed on the registration of all classes of vehicles, including trailers, that are registered by the registrar of motor vehicles.
The tax will not be imposed where the vehicle to be registered in the name of a person was last registered in that person's name in the Australian Capital Territory or elsewhere in Australia.
The amount of the tax is to be calculated at the rate of $2 for each $100, or part thereof, of the market value of the vehicle.

Persons seeking registrations on which tax is to be imposed will be required to state to the registrar of motor vehicles the market value of the vehicle and to tender payment to the registrar of the amount of the tax payable on the basis of that value.
The registrar will not register a vehicle if these requirements are not complied with, unless the registration sought is exempt from tax.
Exemptions from the tax will broadly follow existing exemptions from other classes of ACT stamp duties and taxes.

Thus, vehicles registered to public hospitals, public benevolent institutions, religious institutions, public educational institutions and to diplomatic missions and their personnel of reciprocating countries will not attract tax.
In addition, exemption will apply to licensed motor vehicle dealers in the ACT in respect of vehicles held by them as trading stock for resale.
Mr President, it has been decided to provide an exemption for certain disabled persons.
Disabled persons who will be eligible for exemption are those who would qualify for exemption from sales tax in respect of the purchase of a new vehicle.
The exemptions from stamp tax will, however, apply to both new and secondhand vehicles.
A memorandum containing more detailed explanations of the technical aspects of this Bill and the three other Bills to which I have referred is being made available to honourable senators.
I commend the present Bill to the Senate.
AUSTRALIAN CAPITAL TERRITORY TAX (LIFE INSURANCE BUSINESS) BILL 1981
This is a further Bill associated with the Australian Capital Territory Taxation (Administration) Amendment Bill 1981, which I introduced a short time ago.

As I indicated in speaking to that Bill, tax is to be imposed on life insurance effected in the ACT and the purpose of this Bill is to impose the tax, at the rates declared in the Bill, on two categories of life insurance.
Tax payable in respect of temporary or term life insurance is to be calculated at the rate of 5 per cent of the premium payable for the first year of cover.
In the case of life insurance other than temporary or term insurance, the Bill will impose tax calculated by reference to the amount of the sum insured.
For sums insured greater than $2,000, tax will be at the rate of $1 plus 20 cents for each $200, or part thereof, of the amount of the sum insured in excess of $2,000.
For sums insured between $100 and $2,000, tax will be at the rate of 10 cents for each $200, or part thereof, of the sum insured.
The Bill also makes provision for the exemptions from tax which I referred to earlier.
I commend the Bill to the Senate.
AUSTRALIAN CAPITAL TERRITORY TAX (VEHICLE REGISTRATION) BILL 1981

The purpose of this Bill, in association with the Australian Capital Territory Taxation (Administration) Amendment Bill 1981 which I have just introduced, is to impose a tax, at the rate declared in the Bill, on new and transferred registrations of motor vehicles and trailers in the ACT.

The tax will apply to all classes of vehicles required to be registered, other than those registered to persons or institutions eligible for exemptions that I have already referred to in relation to the previous Bill.
The rate of tax is to be $2 for each $100, or part thereof, of the market value of the motor vehicle or trailer to be registered.
The Bill also provides for the exemptions to which I have referred.
I commend the Bill to the Senate.
AUSTRALIAN CAPITAL TERRITORY TAX(INSURANCE BUSINESS) AMENDMENT BILL(No. 2) 1981
This Bill is the last of the budget package of bills in relation to stamp duties and taxes in the Australian Capital Territory.
It is in consequence of the proposal to tax new life insurance effected in the Territory and its purpose is to withdraw an existing exemption from the tax on general insurance.

The exemption I refer to is in respect of personal accident and sickness insurance which is undertaken solely in connection with life insurance. There is, however, no exemption for personal accident and sickness insurance not connected with life insurance.
Now that it is proposed to tax life insurance effected in the Territory, there is no longer any case for retaining the limited exemption of life insurance-related accident and sickness insurance.
All accident and sickness insurance effected in the Territory will now bear the tax rate that applies to general insurance.
I commend the Bill to the Senate.

TALK.START.PARA: — I suggest to the Senate that it should proceed with a cognate debate on the second readings of these Bills and the Australian Capital Territory Stamp Duty Amendment Bill and associated Bills.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Gietzelt Sen A.T.

TALK.START.PARA: —It would be easy for the Opposition to take a negative position in regard to this legislation because it has some misgivings about the various tax Bills which are now being dealt with in a cognate way. They do pose some difficulties for us, but because they also have some positive features the Opposition does not intend to oppose the Bills. However, the Opposition will move an amendment because it has some differences of opinion with the Government in regard to the Bills under discussion. In general, we see the Bills as going a small way towards regularising the situation of revenue collection in the Australian Capital Territory. We are very conscious that the residents of the Australian Capital Territory have expressed in a number of ways their opposition to the Government's proposals. Nevertheless, we see the current system of revenue raising and distribution in the Territory as being ad hoc and iniquitous, and to that extent we agree with the locals. I will therefore be moving an amendment to the Australian Capital Territory Taxation (Administration) Amendment Bill 1981 and, in regard to the Australian Capital Territory Stamp Duty Amendment Bill, I foreshadow the following amendment:

SPEECH.PARA: At end of motion, add ', but the Senate-
(1) is of the opinion that-

(A) it is not appropriate to consider increases or changes in the rates of stamp duty and similar tax in the Australian Capital Territory until the financial arrangements for the Territory have been inquired into and reported on by the Grants Commission, and

(B) the operation of the Principal Act should cease on 1 July 1982 prior to which all rates of stamp duty and similar State and municipal type taxes in the Australian Capital Territory should be reviewed in accordance with recommendations of the Grants Commission,
(2) notes that the reference to the Grants Commission promised over 2 years ago has not been initiated, and
(3) calls on the Government to refer the matter to the Grants Commission immediately for early report'.

I make it clear that this amendment is not an attempt to defeat the Bill, for a number of reasons. Because the location of the Australian Capital Territory and the relative rates of stamp duty and other charges, such action, if successful, would mean that the Australian Capital Territory would continue to be a tax haven for the signing of documents and the avoidance of stamp duties which normally would be paid in other areas. Of course, we agree with the Government that that has been a loophole which has been exploited particularly by a range of people who are in a position to take advantage of that current tax haven arrangements. The Opposition agrees wholeheartedly with the Government about the problems of tax collection in this country and the endeavours that have been made, albeit to small, to overcome the poblems of tax evasion and organised tax avoidance. The Opposition does not want to encourage a tax haven situation to continue any longer in the Australian Capital Territory.

If our amendment is carried it will in no way affect the passage of the Bill. It would be very easy for us to bang the drum and make a lot of noise and express sympathy with those who do not wish to see further charges levied on Australian Capital Territory residents. However, that is not a responsible position to take because we do not have the empirical evidence that ought to be available to us to see whether the increased charges proposed are justified, having regard to a number of factors. The Treasurer, Mr Howard, tells us that the rationale for this latest levy on Canberra people is the need to bring the Australian Capital Territory into line with the States. That is a reasonable argument and we do not quibble with it. However, it is strange that that rationale is not used in regard to other aspects of the Canberra economy. For example, recently Canberra's air fares were increased by 38 per cent when there was a national increase of only 7 per cent. That must be a real burden on the residents of Canberra. If they want to visit Sydney by first class air travel they now have to pay $88 for that privilege. Likewise, Canberra's petrol prices are considerably higher than those just outside the Territory's boundary. I am informed that over the border in New South Wales there is a great difference in the price of petrol, which is an important commodity to the residents of Canberra.

The Government says that it wants to treat Canberra equally with the States, and that is fair enough, it needs to be treated equally with the States on all levels. That is not happening, and that is what causes the Opposition's misgivings about the legislation. The same argument the Government has used is being used to increase rates by an average of 13 per cent, despite the fact that there is an accumulated surplus in the municipal accounts of $6.8m. I remind the Senate that in New South Wales the State Government policy, which local government is obliged to carry out unless there are special circumstances, is that local government rates are limited to annual increases of no more than 10 per cent. An increased burden is being imposed on Canberra people and it is being imposed by the Fraser Government. All of this is happening before the Commonwealth Grants Commission can get down to examining the finances of the Australian Capital Territory. One can say only that a great measure of incompetence is involved in bringing forward this legislation in respect of the charges and levies that are suggested. The Government has failed to give to the Grants Commission the very desirable objective of examining the whole tax structure and income and expenditure structure of the national capital, and the residents who live in it will suffer as a result of the failure of the Government to provide such a reference to the Grants Commission.

As a matter of urgency we clearly need to have the Grants Commission examine funding in the Australian Capital Territory. I would hope that the Minister for Finance (Senator Dame Margaret Guilfoyle) would give serious consideration to this suggestion, particularly if the Senate supports the amendment which we are proposing. The Opposition and the people of the Australian Capital Territory are concerned about this anomalous position. The point of our amendment is to prod the Government, to force it to accept its responsibilities and get about its business of carrying out a proper economic survey of the funding arrangements for the Australian Capital Territory. These extra charges will add to the cost of daily expenses for most Australian Capital Territory dwellers. Soon they will be demanding to know where this publicly raised revenue is being expended. On the basis of the propositions and views being expressed to honourable senators and to their local representatives, they certainly feel that the revenue is not being collected and spent in an equitable way.

The maintenance of a tax haven-we hope that question will be resolved by this legislation-is only one aspect of the Bills that we are considering. The maintenance of a tax haven in the Australian Capital Territory will not solve the problems with respect to revenue collection and expenditure to which I am referring. It will not benefit the average resident in the Australian Capital Territory. The closing of the tax haven, which I hope and trust will be the result of this legislation, will put an end to the dealings of unscrupulous business people, speculators, and those who seek to avoid their social and taxation responsibilities. If the Government was being fair to Canberra rather than ripping money from it, it would be doing something more positive to see that we have a proper formula to ensure that we in Canberra get a reasonable share of the revenue that we pay to the Commonwealth of Australia. I hope that the Government will pay attention to these demands.

The Bills that have had their first reading today and which are now the subject of a cognate debate, that is the Australian Capital Territory Tax (Life Insurance Business) Bill and the Australian Capital Territory Taxation (Administration) Bill, are related. That is why we did not object to them being debated cognately. However, some important points ought to be made. We believe that the Commonwealth Grants Commission has a responsibility to meet and consider promises made in relation to the Australian Capital Territory by the Government. It has not done so and we do not know when it will. We are of the view that there has been a dereliction of duty in this regard. The residents of the Australian Capital Territory should not be treated unfairly, as may be the case in respect of these latter Bills with which we are dealing. They should not be worse off because of being governed by the Commonwealth. We should establish equity and equality of administration throughout the Commonwealth. Revenue is raised from Australian Capital Territory residents but they have no say in how it is distributed. Indeed, they have no idea of how it is distributed. I think this raises the very pertinent question of no taxation without representation.

We know already that in the Australian Capital Territory there is a rising demand for the residents to have a much greater say in the way in which revenue is collected and expended. We think that that is a fair proposition. It ought to have support of the Senate majority. We hope that the views we have expressed, and our misgivings and criticisms, will prod the Government into taking the essential steps which certainly would resolve the difficulties in the minds of the Opposition. It certainly would help in preparing a case that I am sure all reasonable residents of Canberra would subsequently be prepared to support.

I am a little concerned that in yesterday's Canberra Times there was an article quoting a speech made by Senator Reid in this place about these very Bills. I have looked through Tuesday's copy of Hansard and I cannot find any such speech. I do not know how these things happen. I find it somewhat disturbing that speeches made in this place are not reported in the newspapers but speeches that are not made here are subsequently reported. So we have a most unusual situation which I hope will be rectified by those people who have the responsibility of reporting the events of the Parliament. We want the Opposition's position clearly understood by the residents of the Australian Capital Territory, and I am sure that that would be the view of the majority of the members of the Senate.
I move the following amendment to the motion for the second reading of the Australian Capital Territory Taxation (Administration) Amendment Bill.

Leave out all words after ''That'', insert: 'consideration of the Bill be deferred until (a) the Senate is provided with detailed comparisons with overall localised taxes and revenue measures applied in the States and the Northern Territory, and (b) the Australian Capital Territory House of Assembly is consulted on the application in the Australian Capital Territory of State related taxes and that the Assembly be requested to provide a list of priorities for concessions from State type fees and taxes, in order that the ACT will have comparable rights to choose its own priorities as enjoyed by the States and the Northern Territory'.

TALK.START.PARA: —I second the amendment.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Macklin Sen M.J.

TALK.START.PARA: —These Bills concern basically the State-like activities of the Commonwealth Government in relation to the Australian Capital Territory. The Australian Democrats' position is quite clear-that the sooner the Australian Capital Territory moves towards self-government in terms of control over its own domestic affairs, the better. We hold this view for two reasons. First, we believe very strongly that the full notion of taxation without representation can certainly be brought forward in relation to these Bills. That phrase 'no taxation without representation' has caused revolutions in other parts of the world. It probably would not do so here, given the response to the referendum held a couple of years ago. Nevertheless, I think that since then there has been considerable discussion within the Australian Capital Territory. There is a growing acceptance on the part of people in the community of the view that they need a direct say in their own affairs and control over the revenue raising that is undertaken.

SPEECH.PARA: The Minister for Finance (Senator Dame Margaret Guilfoyle) relied in her second reading speech almost entirely on the notion that these Bills bring the Australian Capital Territory into line with the circumstances in the States. By and large, if one goes through the Bills in detail, that indeed is the case. The charges and the increases in charges to a large extent meet that criterion. Of course honourable senators are aware that States differ in the amount of taxes that they apply: but by and large the Minister's comment that these charges bring the Australian Capital Territory into line with other States is correct.

However, it does seem a rather odd type of justification for a government which many times-as short a period as eight months ago when on the election trail-has proclaimed that it is a low tax party. If the Liberal Party and the National Country Party are low tax parties I cannot see how they can rely on a claim that they are bringing these taxes into line with States as reasonable support for increasing charges. One would have thought that the Federal Government may very well have taken up the cudgels in support of its proclaimed low taxation stance; that it would have said that it would not increase charges in the Australian Capital Territory, as a forerunner and as a signal to the states that they should also lower charges in these areas. I think that these Bills, and the reliance of the Minister upon that particular idea, show the rhetoric that goes on so often in this country during election campaigns. What is said is simply rhetoric. It does not correspond to the governance of the country. The sooner those types of slogans that are bandied around are dispensed with the better. At least people would then have a surer base on which to make a decision at the election.

We are indebted to Senator Gietzelt for raising in the terms of his amendment matters which greatly concern people in the Australian Capital Territory. The Australian Democrats will certainly support the motion that has been moved by Senator Gietzelt that the Senate express the opinion that the Commonwealth Grants Commission's inquiry into the finances of the Australian Capital Territory is long overdue. Once it has completed its inquiry, the citizens of Australia who live here may have the advantage of finding out how much they pay and how much they get back. That ability and privilege is the privilege of every other citizen in this country. The citizens of the Australian Capital Territory alone are deprived of actually knowing what happens with their money and whether they are getting value for the dollars that they pay.

As we know, the taxes that are raised in these seven Bills will go straight into Consolidated Revenue and that is where they will disappear. They are not marked specifically for the citizens of the Australian Capital Territory. As Senator Gietzelt has argued, unless the Grants Commission actually gets to work on the finances of the Australian Capital Territory we will never know whether the Territory is paying its way. I believe on the evidence, contrary to popular opinion, that the ACT is paying its way and probably paying more into the national coffers than it gets back. I am dispensing with the notional amounts that we find in the accounts that go into other Federal activities in the ACT in the same way as they would not be counted against a State Budget for Federal activities in other States in the Commonwealth. That is my belief, and when the Grants Commission has finally done its homework on ACT finances it will be possible to show that to the rest of Australia. The people of Canberra would probably then not have to put up with claims that they are leeches on the rest of the country's taxpayers. It is for those reasons that one would support the amendment moved by Senator Gietzelt. Given the speech of the Liberal Party Senator for the ACT, I hope that she also will be supporting that opinion of the Senate. From what she said about the report and from what I remember of her speech in the House, I presume that she supports that idea. I expect that she will vote with us in any division which may be called.

Another matter that I think needs to be raised in relation to these Bills is that in them are a number of charges corresponding to States charges. I also point to the fact that this Parliament has a responsibility, in the same way that a State parliament has a responsibility, to promote the growth of the Territory in relation to these charges. For example, in my State of Queensland, the Government is looking at this whole notion of stamp duty and associated charges with the idea of lowering or possibly even abolishing such charges and thereby making the State an attraction to industry.

I think we are all very much aware that the ACT has grown basically on finances from the operations of the Public Service. However, there is a growing body of people in private enterprise in the ACT who wish to promote private enterprise here and promote the growth of industries which would then give a diversified base to the economy and would not make the Territory so vulnerable to shifts in policies by this Parliament. At present if the Federal Government sneezes then the whole of the Australian Capital Territory comes down with a very bad attack of influenza. I think the people in private enterprise in the Australian Capital Territory are hoping, in the short term, to reduce that bout to at least a cold. At the moment they are struggling up hill to establish such a thing.

As I had to mention again last night, one would imagine that a government committed to the notion of private enterprise would be seeking to support that diversification of the economy within the Australian Capital Territory, as it is the duty of this Parliament to do, so that the private enterprise sector can grow and flourish here. However, instead of taking that far sighted view, and a view that we should act in the same way as a State government should act and therefore look at developing a private enterprise base in the Australian Capital Territory, we have an imposition of charges to make the Australian Capital Territory as uninsteresting a prospect to come to as any of the other States. I imagine that when my State of Queensland quite shortly moves in regard to stamp duty it will be necessary to introduce another Bill in to this House removing the stamp duties now being imposed or we will lose the little private enterprise that has been attracted so far to the Australian Capital Territory.

I hope that the Government will look again at its rhetoric in this regard and bring that into line to give some additional incentive to attract to the Australian Capital Territory particularly technological industries, which could be very well based in this Territory and developed. I point of course to the growing problem in the Australian Capital Territory of unemployed youth and the very high percentage of unemployment. Therefore, there is a very obvious need to look at a further diversification of the industry base. I speak in the same way as I would if I were in a State parliament. I believe that unless the Australian Capital Territory can get to the stage of being independent, that is where we are stuck. We have to look at the problem in that way and we have to work on it in that way.

The House of Assembly has been elected by the people of the Australian Capital Territory to be the democratic voice of the people of the Territory, at least insofar as advice going to the Minister for the Capital Territory. That is enshrined in the Act that set up the assembly. I think we are all very much aware of the political realities in this context. The Australian Labor Party has a majority of members in the Assembly and therefore the Liberal-National Country Party Government has constantly ignored and humiliated the Assembly in its dealings. I suggest that it would be far better if the Government took a broader and a democratic view that, regardless of the political composition of the House of Assembly, it is in fact the democratic voice of the people of the Australian Capital Territory. In the last election the people of the Australian Capital Territory chose a majority of ALP members to express their points of views. That is their democratic right and it should be respected. But all we have had since that election is a denigration of that democratic voice expressed on the part of the people of the Australian Capital Territory. When we come to these Bills we find exactly the same thing occurring-again a denigration of the voice of the Assembly. The Assembly is not consulted. No dialogue takes place with it. The reason given is: 'We know the type of thing it would come back with because there is no clear majority'. I suggest that to take such a view is to take an anti-democratic view and is in fact an insult to the people who voted in members who are in a majority.

TALK.START.PARA: —In fact it increases our majority.

—Yes. Finally, we accept these Bills but we do not accept their rationale. We accept that all they do is bring the Australian Capital Territory into line with the States. We thought that the Government may have been more adventuresome, more committed to private enterprise, and more committed to the democratic principle, and may have sought to do something other than what it is doing in the Bills, which is simply increasing charges. The Government, should have been innovative and made some attempt to attract to the Australian Capital Territory the industry that it so badly needs.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Guilfoyle Sen The Hon Dame M.G.C.

TALK.START.PARA: — I thank the Senate. I need to deal with the approach that these Bills ought to be deferred until the Senate receives some information relating to the comparisons of the taxes in the Australian Capital Territory compared with those in the States and the Northern Territory. As far as the foreshadowed amendment is concerned, it seeks some deferral of the measures until there can be consideration by the Commonwealth Grants Commission. The Commonwealth Grants Commission has before it a number of inquiries, including the revue of tax sharing arrangements and health grants, as was decided at the June 1981 Premiers Conference. The Commission also has continuing inquiries in respect of special grants apart from the inquiry into the Australian Capital Territory finances. The Government has not taken a decision as to whether the tax sharing inquiry or the inquiry into the Australian Capital Territory finances should have the Commission's first priority. It seems unlikely that the Commission will be able to report on the inquiry into the Australian Capital Territory finances this fiscal year. I want the Opposition and the Australian Democrats to note that: It seems unlikely that the Commission will be able to report on the inquiry into the Australian Capital Territory finances this fiscal year.

SPEECH.PARA: Therefore, the foreshadowed amendment to the proposals which are before us-that is, that we ought to defer consideration of the Bill, believing that we will receive some instant solution from the Grants Commission to the position of the financing of the Australian Capital Territory-is not a realistic proposal in the context of this year's Budget. The Bills before us are Bills arising from the Budget for the 1981-82 year. Certainly, this is an opportune time to talk of the need for an inquiry into the Australian Capital Territory finances. But to suggest that we could defer these Bills, which properly raise revenue and place the Australian Capital Territory into a far sounder comparison with the other States and the Northern Territory, seems to me to ignore the fact that these are Budget Bills of 1981-82 which raise the revenue for the Budget of this year. There is a strong case for increasing stamp duties in the Australian Capital Territory this year. Most of the rates which apply in the Territory have not been changed since they were introduced in 1969. They are generally lower than those which apply in the States.

I think Senator Gietzelt said that the Australian Labor Party would not support a proposal that would allow the Australian Capital Territory to become a stamp duty haven for the rest of Australia. That would be quite contrary to anyone's attitude with regard to how the stamp duties and other charges in the States and Territories should operate. The stamp duties in the Australian Capital Territory at present apply to a narrower range of instruments and transactions than those which apply in the States. Lower rates of stamp duties in the Territory tend to encourage transactions to take place in the Australian Capital Territory when they would otherwise properly take place in the States to which those companies or instruments ought properly be referred. That is-I think the Opposition said that we should not support this measure-the Australian Capital Territory is a stamp duty haven. Any State that had not increased its normal charges from 1969 certainly would not be regarded as one that was paying its way in relation to the charges which are the subjects of these Bills. To suggest that we ought to defer these Bills until we have considered the comparisons ignores the facts that since 1969 the States have raised their revenue properly from increases in many of the charges that we now apply to the Australian Capital Territory.

There have been representations from the States of Australia that they are against permitting the lower rates of stamp duties to continue since they diminish the States' own ability to raise taxes. Those who want to talk about democracy and all the rest of it would have to take into account the argument that the six States and the Northern Territory have the capacity to deal with instruments, the conveyancing of property, insurance and other matters which are the subject of these Bills. The States raise their charges. To have the Australian Capital Territory as a stamp duty haven would seem to me to be a quite improper suggestion that ought not to be allowed to continue. The States have made strong representations against the Australian Capital Territory continuing at the present level of taxes and charges-or the lack of them, in some cases-that do apply. I think it would be far preferable to accept that there are a number of ways of adjusting the Australian Capital Territory finances, apart from stamp duty charges, that would be available to the Government for consideration when the report of the Grants Commission into Australian Capital Territory finances is received. When we have a report which looks comprehensively at the capacity to raise funds in this Territory we will be looking at the whole range of options. We will not be suggesting that we will not raise taxes and charges that have not been raised since 1969 and regard that as an absolute solution. We will say that the stamp duty charges for the Australian Capital Territory, properly raised in 1981-82 year, will not prejudice any action that might be appropriate once the Commission's report is received.

It would seem to me that if the Senate were to embark upon that course, it should take note of the fact that a report from an inquiry into the Australian Capital Territory finances would be an appropriate way to deal with future funding of the requirements of the Australian Capital Territory, and it should recognise that the proposals in the Budget of this year to raise the charges and taxes in the Australian Capital Territory are broadly comparable with the State of New South Wales. I cannot see why there ought to be this approach which has been taken by the Opposition and the Australian Democrats. They suggest that in some way we can ignore the fact that these measures are part of this year's Budget and that they are money raising Bills for this year's Budget, and that we should with some gay abandon say that we can delay the Bills until such time as we get a report which is most unlikely to be received this fiscal year. It certainly will not be received in time for these taxes to be applied from the Budget date as was announced by the Treasurer (Mr Howard).

I have information also with regard to the Grants Commission inquiry. The proposal ought to be resisted for these reasons: The resources of the Grants Commission are limited and, as presently constituted, the Commission will probably not be able to undertake a review of its 1981 report on State tax sharing entitlements and inquire into the health grants while, at the same time, undertaking an inquiry into Australian Capital Territory finances. Therefore, it is a question of priorities. The Government will need to consider which of the inquiries should take precedence. Although the inquiry into Australian Capital Territory finances is a matter of importance and the review of State tax sharing entitlements is a matter of major importance, affecting as it does the six State governments, the comparative priorities that arise when considering these two factors need to be looked at. At this time the Government is stressing that it will welcome a Grants Commission inquiry into Australian Capital Territory finances, however, with the resources of the Grants Commission and the very specialised work that needs to be undertaken with regard to the State tax sharing entitlements and the health grants, it is unlikely that the report into Australian Capital Territory finances would be available this fiscal year.

Therefore, I most strenuously need to say to the Senate that to deal with this matter in the way in which the amendments propose is to refuse to pass the Bills of this year's Budget. I wish those who embark upon that course to recognise the realities of the course on which they embarked. If they want to go out and tear up some statutory declarations perhaps they had better do so because to embark upon the carriage of an amendment that refuses to pass essential money raising Bills of the 1981-82 Budget has consequences for those who have asserted some of the things we have heard over recent months. I commend the Bills to the Senate.
Question put.
That the amendment (Senator Gietzelt's) to the Australian Capital Territory Taxation (Administration) Amendment Bill 1981 be agreed to.
