SPEECH.SPEAKER: Gietzelt Sen A.T.

TALK.START.PARA: —I wish to take advantage of the first reading of these departure tax Bills to raise fairly briefly a number of matters. I have been persuaded to do so by the contribution made in this place yesterday by Senator Withers about partisan politics and what it is doing to the political debate generally in Australia. I remind Senator Withers that he was the hatchet man for the partisan politics of 1974 and 1975. However, leaving that aside, I wish to refer to certain incidents during the New South Wales elections which show the depths to which the Liberal Party is prepared to go in order to win votes in an hysterical campaign against the Labor Government in New South Wales, and in particular against three candidates that I know personally. It was a campaign of vilification; one that can only be described as despicable, contemptible and the lowest form of dirty partisan politics. I refer to the electorates of Woronora, Miranda and Manly, in which the Liberal Party quite deliberately and carefully set about a fear campaign associated with public housing to try to panic the electors into voting against the Labor candidates in those electorates.

SPEECH.PARA: I refer first to a campaign, which honourable senators will remember hit the New South Wales newspapers fairly prominently, about a New South Wales Labor Government proposition to erect public housing in the suburb of Menai, and the very callous and subversive way in which the Liberal Party organisation, including its Leader and the shadow Minister for Housing, were brought into the campaign in the hope that they would panic electors in that area about welfare housing. Some 12 years ago the Sutherland Shire Council, in preparing the local planning scheme, set aside land in the Menai area for the purpose of public housing. That scheme was approved by the Council and by the State Government, but following representations made by two large development companies, Stocks and Holdings and Parkes Development, to the then Liberal Minister for Housing, the section of the plan which provided for public housing in the Menai region was withdrawn. I am prepared to assert that that was done on the basis of donations to the Liberal Party.

The reason the Sutherland Shire Council sought to provide a social mix for the 50,000 people who will live in the township of Menai was that sociologists, town planners, welfare organisations generally and, properly so, local government took the view that it was essential to stop the creation of ghetto and segregation types of housing policies. It was felt that working class people, particularly those on low incomes and those who were not able to provide housing from their own means-and therefore needed the assistance of the Commonwealth and State governments in the form of welfare housing-should not be segregated in certain areas of Sydney but should be spread appropriately throughout the various suburbs of Sydney. In other words, having regard to the balloting system of the Housing Commission in my State of New South Wales, it was felt that they should have an opportunity to live in what can be said to be more salubrious areas, better types of areas, and not be sent out 30 or 40 miles away from the city proper. When the Wran Government resurrected the public housing proposition, the Liberal Party of New South Wales, in a calculated, partisan, political way attempted to panic the people in the Menai region into opposing the proposition. That was done in a chauvinistic, racist, divisive way. Liberal Party organisers, together with some local real estate agents, went about and stirred the locals in that area by suggesting that immigrants, blacks, deserted wives, all the so-called welfare bludgers who normally congregate in the far western suburbs of Sydney, would be put into that delightful area of Menai among all the upper-middle-class types of homes to be erected.

A similar situation arose in the Miranda electorate where, some 20-odd years ago, the Housing Commission of New South Wales purchased land for the purpose of erecting homes. That was part of a correct planning concept. But the Housing Commission was not able to carry it into effect because the area did not have proper sewerage facilities. The Housing Commission took the view that the development should wait until the area had been properly serviced by the Metropolitan Water, Sewerage and Drainage Board and had been provided with sewerage and water facilities.

In the electorate of Miranda in the 1950s and 1960s the Labor Government acquired very large tracts of land for the southern expressway. From the north-east to the south-west a large amount of land is publicly owned for expressway development. In that area also the Liberal Party distributed leaflets and conducted a whispering campaign against the Labor candidate, suggesting that the same 'undesirable' type of people would be housed in the area. That was not true. It was known that for the past dozen years under the local councils planning scheme sites had been set aside for public housing and other land had been set aside for future extensions to the southern expressway. What is most alarming about this is that the Liberal candidate, Mr Laurie Power, who is a member of the staff of the Leader of the Government in the Senate (Senator Carrick), was primarily responsible for that despicable campaign in an attempt to win votes for the seat of Miranda.

I find it dirty, partisan politics of the type to which Senator Withers referred, when people are aroused on an emotional issue, a racist issue, a chauvinist issue, a divisive issue, an issue that ought not to be raised-an issue concerning the incomes of people who cannot meet housing costs. Housing costs are as high as they are as a result of the economic policies pursued deliberately by the Fraser Government over a considerable period of years and pursued prior to that by the Menzies and McMahon administrations. There has been a deliberate policy of restricting public sector activity in both housing and public works throughout Australia. We know from the debates we have had in this place just how much this Fraser Government has cut back State funding for public housing in the current Budget.

I refer now to the electoral seat of Manly, with which one of my colleagues is intimately associated, and to the same type of slanderous statements made in that area. The Liberal Party candidate for that seat said that slum-type housing developments would take place in Manly if the Labor Government were returned to office in the State election. That sort of propaganda, that sort of calumny, that sort of attempt to play on the emotions of people I regard as despicable and ill-becoming a person acting in a representative capacity in our country. In addition to that, I have had handed to me a copy of a letter which was sent out by the Minister for Health, the honourable member for Warringah, Mr MacKellar, to every elector in the electorate of Manly-some 32,000 of them.

TALK.START.PARA: —But they don't accept public funding.
—No. That is the party that does not believe in public funding. This letter is written on parliamentary stationery of the Honourable M.J.R. MacKellar, the honourable member for Warringah, and reads:

SPEECH.PARA: Dear Elector,
On the 19th September the State Elections will be held.
Here in Manly, Nelson Meers is the candidate who has proved his ability.

His record of service to the public is a long one. Firstly as an Alderman, then Deputy Lord Mayor, and finally as Lord Mayor of Sydney he assisted and then guided the development of one of the great cities of the world. None of the other candidates for Manly can match that service. None of them can claim a similar capacity to handle the big jobs.

He is a man who served in local government. He ought to know something about the importance of a social mix in our society. He ought not to be associated with divisive statements and tactics in order to win votes in an election. Mr MacKellar goes on to state:
Nelson Meers has taken the time and made the real personal effort needed to properly represent Manly.

Does that mean that he does not believe that people on low incomes, deserted wives and widows perhaps even our parents who do not have the capacity to live in a home of their own should constantly have their names on the New South Wales housing list, which presently contains 45,000 names? I remind honourable senators that the fact that the list is as long as that is not an indictment of the New South Wales Government, irrespective of its political complexion. All the other States have a similarly long list. That is why all the State housing commissions were so caustic about the cut-back in funding for welfare housing in the present Budget. The Minister goes on to state in his letter:
He has not only attended meetings and functions of a multitude of community groups, he has also slogged it out, day by day-door-knocking all over the electorate.

Lately, Mr Wran and the Labor Government have been trying to ''buy'' the Manly electorate with all sorts of promises. This has happened as a result of the pressure applied by the fact that Mr Meers is such a good strong candidate.
Manly needs such a representative in the State Parliament. I urge you to support Nelson Meers and vote for him on the 19th September.
M. J. R. MacKELLAR Member for Warringah
Coupled with that is a letter from the Manly Liberal Campaign Committee, signed personally by Nelson Meers. It states:
Dear Resident,

A number of people have expressed their concern to me about the pollution problem on Manly's beaches. Summer is not that far away and it will bring with it our concern about swimming in a polluted surf.
I know this is a matter which is of vital importance and it is not good enough for us to have to wait another ten years before sewage is taken out to sea.
There are quicker and more effective solutions and at the coming election I will be standing on a policy of getting immediate action on this matter for you.
Yours sincerely,
NELSON MEERS

They illustrate attempts made by candidates for public office to play upon the fears of people. Yesterday we saw a bipartisan approach adopted in a debate in this chamber. You yourself, Mr Acting Deputy President, participated in it. Senator Withers expressed a view which is commonly expressed in many parts of our country. The fact is that, whilst he expressed those sentiments, at the same time ignoring the performance of his party and the partisan political dogfights of 1974-75, in Sydney in the weeks immediately preceding the New South Wales election we witnessed the playing of gutter-type politics, politics of the lowest level, politics which ought to be rejected by any decent, right-thinking person. Statements were made at the expense of people who cannot help themselves with housing. People would have to earn an income of about $300 a week to provide themselves with housing. People who could not provide their own housing were placed in a category and regarded by the organisers of Liberal candidates in the New South Wales election as being second class citizens. I believe that that sort of gutter-type politics, partisan-type politics, ought to be deplored by anybody worthy of being a representative in this Parliament or, for that matter, anybody wanting to stand for political office, representing any political party in Australia.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Colston Sen M.A.

TALK.START.PARA: -After listening to the speech of Senator Gietzelt I am not sure whether the comments I am about to make are really appropriate. But I want to use the opportunity afforded at the first reading stage of the legislation before us to draw attention to one of our national sports in Australia, namely, the national sport of attacking members of parliament. It was put very plainly and succinctly to me recently by one of my colleagues that Australians love to hate their politicians. When I hear disparaging comments about members of parliament-those disparaging comments are often made by the media, especially the print media-I become concerned. I become concerned not for myself or for my parliamentary colleagues but for those who make the comments.

SPEECH.PARA: If critical comments about members of parliament happen to be correct, they reflect on those who make the comments because it is they who elect their representatives to State and Federal legislatures. If they are not satisfied with the quality of their elected representatives, the remedy is in their hands. At the time of an election they can do whatever they can within the law to have the candidate of their choice elected. When I mention that to some people they bring back what is perhaps an obvious rejoiner. They say: 'The choice we are given at election time is not really an acceptable choice'. If that is so and if some people are interested in having members of parliament whom they can respect, it is their duty to join a political party of their choice so that, through that political party, they can choose a candidate who can represent himself or herself to the electorate. Of course, people need not join a political party; they could stand for election themselves as independents or they could support an independent. I reiterate for those who are dissatisfied that the remedy is in their hands. They would be far better taking some positive action than engaging in continual harping criticism of members of parliament.

Before proceeding any further I wish to emphasise that I regard most of the criticism of members of parliament as unfounded. All in all, the quality and dedication of the nation's parliamentary representatives is first class. We may disagree with one another in this chamber and members of the House of Representatives may disagree with each other, but the quality of representation is in fact good. I do not usually react to unfounded criticism of this nature because I do not like to give it the dignity of being recognised. Like most members of parliament I accept criticism without complaint. But as an aside, I question why our spouses and children should have to accept the unfounded criticism about members of parliament when they, the spouses and children, have to put up with what is virtually a single parent family status. Perhaps more importantly, however, I do not see why the institution of parliament should be, by inference, subjected to unfounded criticism. But I should not disgress on that matter.

What I intend to raise this afternoon is a current television advertisement which deliberately belittles members of parliament in an effort to boost the sales of a particular company. This advertisement was shown this week on Canberra commercial television. I do not know whether it is still being shown, but it certainly could be. This morning and this afternoon I tried to obtain a transcript of the advertisement, but my efforts were to no avail. I just mention some of the steps that I took to try to obtain the transcript because I am sure that if I do not the company concerned will criticise me for not having done as much as I possibly could to make sure that what I put before the Senate this afternoon is correct.

As the advertisement was shown on Channel 7 in Canberra I first of all contacted that television station which told me that it could not give me any further information, that in fact, because of the way television commercials are scheduled, it was not possible to pull out the exact advertisement I was interested in. Channel 7 suggested that I contact a certain agency in Wagga which handled the account of the company that I will talk about shortly. I contacted that agency which referred me to RVN2, a Wagga television station, which apparently produced this advertisement. It was suggested to me by RVN2 that the transcript of the television advertisement could not be made available unless it was cleared with the client-the company concerned. That is when I ran into a dead end because the manager of this company was on holidays and his telephone in Wagga did not answer. So at that stage I decided that it would not be of any use trying to pursue the matter further.

I neglected to mention that at one stage I contacted the Federation of Australian Commercial Television Stations which told me that it had not heard of this advertisement, that the advertisement had not been cleared through it. I have not actually seen the advertisement but I have been reliably informed about it by members of my family who saw the advertisement on Channel 7 during the week. The advertisement-again I mention that I do not have a transcript-goes something like this: 'When Laurie Oakes broke the story about politicians not working hard, he forgot to report the real reason-they are overfed on Tancred meats'. Some of us may look a little overfed. But perhaps it is going a little too far to refer in a television commercial to a matter which is currently before the House of Representatives Privileges Committee and then to say that politicians are not working hard because they happen to be overfed on Tancred meats. The advertisement mentioned the Tancred specials for the week and what the prices would be. It then made the final statement: 'You don't need a politician's salary to afford this'. Again I mention that I do not have the transcript and I would be pleased to receive one in due course. However, I have given a broad outline of this advertisement.

The advertisement belittles members of parliament in an attempt to boost the sales of Tancred meat. I must admit that I have not heard of the firm before; it is not a firm that operates in the area where I live. I have certainly heard of it now and probably I am giving it some free advertising. But the company uses the devise of attacking members of parliament for its own commercial purposes. As I outlined earlier, we should accept the fact that members of the Parliament will be criticised. But I do not think we should accept criticism which is put forward to try to boost the sales of a company such as Tancred meats. This advertisement may appear slick to the particular advertising agency which wrote the copy, but I think the copy is really a reflection on the advertising industry. I will certainly be contacting Tancreds-I am not able to do so at the moment because the manager is still on holidays-to suggest that it withdraws this corny and inappropriate advertisement immediately.
Question resolved in the affirmative.
Bills read a first time.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Baume Sen The Hon P.E.

TALK.START.PARA: —I move:

SPEECH.PARA: That the Bills be now read a second time.

The speeches read as follows-

DEPARTURE TAX AMENDMENT BILL 1981 The purpose of the Bill is to increase the rate of departure tax from $10 to $20 with effect from 1 October 1981. Honourable senators will recall that the rate of departure tax has not been varied since 1978 when the departure tax legislation was enacted. I commend the Bill to honourable senators.
DEPARTURE TAX COLLECTION AMENDMENT BILL 1981

The purpose of the Bill is to bring down the taxable age from 18 to 12 years with effect from 1 October 1981. The age limit has been varied to bring it into line with that applying to child fares under the rules of the International Air Transport Association. I commend the Bill to honourable senators.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Sibraa Sen K.W.

TALK.START.PARA: —The Opposition opposes the Departure Tax Amendment Bill 1981 and the Departure Tax Collection Amendment Bill 1981. This increase in the rate of departure tax is one that one would expect in a banana republic. In fact, it is a very popular tax in a number of the Third World nations where there is no tourism, where people think it is legitimate to sock visitors to the country-businessmen and government officials who are passing through. If one examines the financial position of a number of these countries one may find that it is a legitimate tax but in a country such as Australia it is not a legitimate tax. In fact, in Australia it is a tax on tourists. The Government has given no reason for this increase. It is a straight out tax grab for revenue reasons only. I believe if the Government were sincere about imposing a departure tax that meant something for the tourist industry the receipts from such a tax would go towards promoting tourism in Australia and also towards improving our tourist attractions.

SPEECH.PARA: The situation is that $9m has been set aside in the Budget for tourist promotion-and although that is a paltry enough sum, it is an increase of $1m on last year's appropriation-but this new departure tax will generate an additional $18m in revenue. In 1978 when the departure tax was first introduced in Australia we joined 111 other nations which had some sort of departure tax. But in many of those countries, and especially in some of the countries more comparable to Australia, the receipts from that tax are used on the promotion of tourism and the development of tourist attractions. As many honourable senators would be aware, the Australian travel industry opposes the increase. I think all of us have received a copy of the advertisement entitled 'Leaving Australia wasn't meant to be Easy.' in which the Australian Federation of Travel Agents set out in detail its objections to the departure tax increase. I will not go through the whole of the advertisement but I think some parts of its are worth while quoting. The section headed 'The Lucky Country?' reads:
From October 1 Australia will claim the dubious distinction of having the highest departure tax in the world.
This isn't just a levy to hit the big tax dodgers and smart-money men. Every Australian over 12 who has saved enough for an overseas trip will pay for the privilege of leaving the lucky country.
That means an extra $100 on the cost of a simple holiday for a family with three children.
The section under the heading 'Why make enemies for Australia?' reads:
The Government campaign 'Make friends for Australia' was a great idea. Now it's probably just an empty shell.
Instead of sending Australians overseas as happy, smiling ambassadors, today they'll probably scowl. Would you smile if it cost you and your family $100 before you even got on the plane?
And more's the point, those overseas visitors who do come here will react in exactly the same way when they come to leave. Is this how we're going to make friends for Australia.
The advertisement pointed out many other arguments that I will not quote, and in conclusion it states:
Why not ask the Prime Minister and the Treasurer to drop this restrictive tax?
Or at least exempt our international visitors from having to pay it.
It's only going to raise 0.0005% of Budget revenue.
Is it worth it, to have everyone else sniggering at Australia-the most expensive country in the world to get out of.

Since the inception of this tax in 1978 it has applied to all people over the age of 18 leaving Australia. It now will apply to people 12 years of ago and over who leave Australia. Why? I think we can legitimately ask why has the age come down from 18 to 12 years. We have got no answer from the Government. I think the answer would be what I said at the start of my speech; that is, this is just another tax grab, another way of raising revenue. The departure tax, since its inception, has raised $49m in three years. Now, in one year, $34m will be raised from this revenue source. Let us look at the position of an Australian family taking perhaps its first trip overseas. It will probably go to New Zealand, the South Pacific or to one of the member countries of the Association of South East Asian Nations because it is cheaper to go to those places than it is to have a holiday in some parts of Australia. I think the position was well summed up in an article in the Sydney Daily Mirror on 21 August which stated:
FAMILIES HIT, MAY CANCEL HOLIDAYS
Families wanting their first overseas holiday will be hit with federal charges of at least $100 and probably $150 before reaching their plane or ship.
The penalty for leaving the country was increased in the Budget, with families being hardest hit, and many are sure to cancel their trips.
Parents with two children, one aged more than 12, will have to pay $120 in new passport fees and departure taxes.
Two teenagers with their parents will be charged $140 if the children travel on one parent's passport.
The hidden extras almost equal the lowest air fare from Australia-
This is where the joke comes in-
an Apex low season return trip to New Zealand for $236.
One only has to compare the cost of the trip with the cost of the new charges that travellers have to meet to realise what a farcical situation this is. The article states:
New charges announced in the Budget are $30 for a passport, up $5, and $20 for the departure tax, up $10.

This departure tax increase will not hurt businessmen who can claim legitimate expenses. They will go on claiming it and the charge can be passed on to their consumers. It will not hurt people who usually travel first class, people who are used to taking trips to Europe, or the regular business class traveller. It will not hurt people who can afford to travel regularly; it will hurt only those people who are struggling to find the money to go on a holiday, and most of all it will affect those people with large families. The departure tax has been increased by 100 per cent but we do not see the same sort of logic being applied to increases in family allowances. As I said before, if the Government were serious about helping tourism it would probably look at introducing a system whereby if there is to be a departure tax that fee could be included in the charge for the ticket when it is sold and the fee would be earmarked for tourism. We could then do away with the wasteful expenses which are incurred by having collection agencies at Australian airports as we have now.

In summary, the Opposition believes it is a discriminatory tax which hits those travellers who can least afford to pay it. It has now made Australia the country with the highest cash departure tax in the world. It makes us look like a banana republic. I ask the Australian Democrats, Senator Harradine and those Government senators who are serious about tourism in Australia to join with the Opposition in opposing the legislation.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Rae Sen P.E.

TALK.START.PARA: —I wish to speak briefly to register my concern in relation to this legislation. Senator Sibraa has raised a number of matters and I do not propose to deal with them at length. Significant sections of the tourist industry in Australia are concerned about the implications of this tax. It is claimed that it is now one of the highest charged by any country. I do believe it is extremely important in Australia's interests and in the interests of the tourist industry that everything possible be done to encourage international visitors to Australia. We have until recently had a declining share of the tourism in the Pacific region.

SPEECH.PARA: Considerable effort has been undertaken by the Government, by the Australian Tourist Commission and by people involved in the industry to build up confidence, to build up interest and to build up the numbers of international visitors. In that respect there has been, I believe, a very successful campaign. Numbers have been very significantly built up but they are starting to taper off again. I think there are very large markets in some parts of the world which have not yet been fully exploited. The South East Asian market, including Taiwan, is one. As a result of rising prosperity, which enables people to afford to travel and to have an interest in travelling, there is an increasing number of people in that market. Australia is a relatively close destination to those countries. With the prospect of having one of the highest departure taxes of any country Australia is not likely to enhance its developing tourist industry.

I am also concerned about whether the mode of collection of the departure tax, by having permanent officers stationed at airports is the most efficient means. Other means are used in other countries. Again, Australia is one of the few countries, if not the only one, to use this method of collection. I understand from the Minister for Industry and Commerce, Sir Phillip Lynch, that there has been an interdepartmental committee investigation in relation to the efficiency of this mode of collection and whether there could be cost savings by the introduction of other methods which could result in the tax being reduced. I can only say at this stage that the Government members tourism committee, of which I am chairman, will be exploring those questions further with the appropriate officers from the department involved in that investigation to ascertain whether it is possible to make some change such as that which was suggested by Senator Sibraa and to assess the desirability of adopting some of the other suggestions that have been made from various sections of the tourist industry with a view to relieving the Commonwealth purse of the costs of collection and thereby reducing the tax. I support the legislation with a degree of reservation but in the knowledge and belief that the matter is not finished; it will be further explored.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Baume Sen The Hon P.E.

TALK.START.PARA: —in reply-I thank the Senate for the debate that has occurred on the departure tax Bills. I understand that the Opposition is opposing the legislation. The Government wishes to see these Bills passed. They are part of the Government's revenue package and part of the Budget. We believe that the additional revenue which will result from these measures will be $14m this year and about $18.7m in a full year. Of course, that is the kind of revenue we require to put into a whole range of social services and other Government activities. There is no doubt that we simply have to raise revenue if we are to spend money on the kinds of services we are being asked daily in this place to support.

SPEECH.PARA: Representation about the increases have been received from the travel industry, but there is no evidence that tourism has suffered or will suffer from the departure tax or from the higher rate. The tax, which is $20 per person for those aged 12 years and over, is only a small component of total travel costs, by the time one takes into account the cost of fares, accommodation, et cetera. I will say a little more about that in a moment. There is an obvious logic in bringing down the age to 12 years. That is the age for adult ticketing in accordance with airline policy and with the rules of the International Air Transport Association, which puts the adult cut-off point at 12 years. The change has been made to bring the legislation into line.

I think honourable senators who have expressed concern on behalf of the tourist industry and on behalf of tourism in Australia have made some points that the Minister for Transport (Mr Hunt) would want to take on board. One point that has not come out and which should be made is that the direct comparison of the departure tax in Australia and in some other countries may not be a valid comparison in each case.

TALK.START.PARA: —That is why I qualified what I said.

—I accept that my colleague is aware of this point. Not all countries identify the departure tax as such, and that is a valid point which needs to be emphasised. Some countries hide their departure tax from people, and some of the amounts involved are quite significant. For example, New Zealand has a departure tax of $35 per adult ticket which the traveller does not know about. He does not know about it because it is included in the ticket price, and that is not made clear. Of course, New Zealand travellers think they are paying a $2 departure tax when in fact they are paying $37 in total.
—Might not that be one of the alternative ways we could do it so that it is not quite so counter-productive to good will?
—That is so.

—I hear from both sides of the chamber some endorsement of that practice, and I will pass that on to the Minister. Another way in which some countries move is to apply airport charges to each ticket purchased. The obvious example that comes to mind is at Heathrow airport, where #8.50 per departing adult is included as an airport charge. I thank honourable senators for their contributions to the debate. The points they raised which do require further attention will be passed on to the Minister and will be put under study. Apart from that, I commend the Bills to the Senate.

SPEECH.PARA: Question put.
That the Bills be now read a second time.
Bills read a second time, and passed through their remaining stages without requests or debate.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Durack Sen The Hon P.D.

TALK.START.PARA: —by leave-Mr President, I wish to make a statement on Constitutional Review. There is a resurgence of interest in the possibilities of constitutional reform. The Governor-General touched on this matter in a widely reported address in Canberra on 1 September. Constitutional review has also been brought into focus by the results of the two referendums held in conjunction with the elections in New South Wales last weekend. Each referendum was carried by a very large majority. One dealt with requiring members of State Parliament to disclose certain pecuniary interests and other matters. The other will extend the maximum period between general elections for the lower House in New South Wales from three to four years. The topic of four year terms is one that has aroused considerable interest in this Parliament. Another subject of discussion has been the possibility of allotting a fixed term to the lower House, so that the Parliament would always run its full term. Some would join the two ideas together, so as to have a fixed four year term for the lower House. However, as I reminded the Senate recently, the two ideas are quite distinct, and they have quite different implications and effects. The Senate Standing Committee on Constitutional and Legal Affairs has made an examination of the topic of the constitutional qualifications of senators and members. Its 18 recommendations are at present being studied by the Government. Two of the recommendations deal with the topic of pecuniary interests as it affects members of the Federal Parliament. Many of the Committee's recommendations would require amendment of the Constitution if they were to be implemented. The recent public discussion has thrown up a number of issues on which I want to comment. I welcome the renewed debate and the resurgence of interest that lies behind it.

SPEECH.PARA: Constitutional reform is a matter that must concern everyone who thinks seriously about the future of Australia. The Constitution has been in operation now for over 80 years. In the life of a nation, that is not a very long time. We have to frame our thinking on that basis that the Constitution will regulate the affairs of our country into the 21st century. A number of aspects of our Constitution need to be reviewed. There is the position of the Senate and Supply. At the moment, the Senate has the power to refuse Supply without itself being required to go to the people. In 1975, the situation was able to be resolved by a dissolution of both Houses, under which the people of Australia had an opportunity of expressing their views at a general election. At the Perth meeting of the Australian Constitutional Convention in 1978, a resolution was passed, by a majority of 49 votes to 39, to amend the Constitution so that if the Senate fails to pass Supply within 30 days, there is to be an automatic double dissolution. If the Government is re-elected, it is only necessary for the House of Representatives to pass Supply. The Senate would be by-passed. Interim provision would be made for expenditure of funds to maintain government in the meantime.

I have dwelt a little on the question of the Senate and Supply, because it is still, in the minds of many, a most significant matter for constitutional review. There are other matters that need review, including those I will enumerate later in referring to the work of Standing Committee D of the Australian Constitutional Convention. However, having made it clear that I think that the Constitution continues to need review, I want to make it equally clear that I completely reject the wild assertions recently made that our existing Constitution is 'unreadable' and that our founding fathers bequeathed to us a federal system that is-and I quote-'at best irrational and at worst unworkable'.

TALK.START.PARA: —Who was that extravagant person?

—Well, I did not want to attribute that to anybody. Such an exaggerated verdict is demonstrably false. It is also a slur upon those great Australians who drew up our Constitution-Deakin of Victoria, Barton of New South Wales, Griffith of Queensland, Kingston of South Australia, Forrest of Western Australia, and Braddon of Tasmania, to mention just a few. I believe that their work has been crowned with singular success. The constitution they drew up was the birth certificate of a nation. It gave reality to the sentiment of 'a nation for a continent and a continent for a nation'. For example, they ensured that the Constitution could be amended by the Australian people, voting on a federal basis. We take that for granted. By contrast, the present difficulties in Canada in relation to amending the Canadian Constitution show us what a problem this can be. The Constitution-for all the stresses and strains it has undergone from time to time-was a remarkably accomplished document when it was drawn up, and it has served the nation well.

SPEECH.PARA: The next issue I wish to raise is the feasibility of a completely new Constitution. The hope has been expressed that this could be done by 1988, the year of the Australian Bicentenary. That is a very optimistic assessment, having regard to all that would be involved in formulating, discussing, and seeking to get agreement on a completely new Constitution. Many people will think the aim of completely remaking the Constitution is quite unrealistic, and also as more calculated to cause divisions and dissensions within the community than to confirm national solidarity. The fact of the matter is that the case for 'scrapping' the present Constitution cannot be sustained. The Constitution has shown itself capable of being adapted to suit changing social, political, and international circumstances. I mention some of the major developments that have taken place:
The watershed decision of the High Court in the Engineers case in 1920 upheld the power of the national Parliament to apply its laws to the States.
The decision in 1942 in the first Uniform Tax Case showed that the national Parliament was able in a time of national crisis to place the finances and revenues of the country on a national footing.

The Concrete Pipes case in 1971 revived the corporations power of the Commonwealth as a basis for regulating the trading and financial activities of trading and financial corporations and also the activities in Australia of foreign corporations.
The Seas and Submerged Lands decision in 1975 laid down the respective constitutional responsibilities of the Commonwealth and the States in respect of off-shore jurisdiction.

I think it is nonsense to assert, as some people do, that there is general agreement that the Constitution is an inadequate instrument for the type of democratic government desired by Australians. The High Court has referred more than once to the silent operation of constitutional principles in the light of which the Constitution can be moulded to serve the nation as it lives, grows and expands. It proved completely adequate, for example, to accommodate Australia's emergence as a sovereign and independent State in the international community. The proper course, and the only practicable course, in my view, is to work for amendments to our existing Constitution. I think we should take some heart from our recent experiences apart altogether from the overwhelming majority in favour of the referendum proposals in New South Wales last weekend. The success rate for national constitutional referendums went from 5 out of 32 to 8 out of 36 as a result of the success of three out of the four proposals that were submitted to electors in 1977.

The Australian Constitutional Convention, which was established in 1973, has shown that reforms that have been well thought out are possible. The reforms need, however, to be widely understood and to enjoy general support. It is in this connection that I particularly welcome the initiative of the Law Foundation of New South Wales in establishing a project aimed at initiating a serious national debate on the need for constitutional change. Also, I particularly welcome the following statement by the Director of the Law Foundation, Mr Terry Purcell. He said:

I should emphasise that by backing this project, the Foundation seeks to complement the steps politicans have been taking since the establishment of the Parliamentarians' Constitutional Convention in 1973.

The Convention also included members of the then Australian Capital Territory Legislative Assembly. There has been some criticism of the role of the politicians and of the so-called Parliamentarians Convention. The Australian Constitutional Convention held its first meeting in Sydney in 1973. It has since held plenary sessions in Melbourne in 1975, in Hobart in 1976 and in Perth in 1978. It is composed of delegates and representatives chosen by and from Federal, State and Northern Territory parliamentarians and by and from local government representatives and, I think, not just Northern Territory parliamentarians but also ACT Assembly members. One suggestion seems to be that a popular convention might replace the Parliamentarians Convention. The simple fact of the matter is that proposals for constitutional reform can be put to referendum only by an enactment of this national Parliament. I cannot see popular conventions replacing the Parliamentarians Convention.

Much has been made of the popularly elected convention that gave impetus to the drawing up of the Australian Constitution in the 1890s. It is instructive to note that the persons actually elected to that convention were almost invariably parliamentarians, including Ministers. That, I suggest, is why the Australian Constitutional Convention of the late 1890s ultimately succeeded. On the other hand, any assistance from initiatives and discussions outside Parliament can only be to the good. I would not rule out the possibility of interested organisations which undertake such initiatives participating at future meetings of the Australian Constitutional Convention with some kind of special observer status.

On 2 June last, I told the Senate that the Government would be considering the matter of the next plenary session of the Australian Constitutional Convention. The Government believes that a plenary session of the Convention should take place only when there are substantial proposals which have been sufficiently developed and digested to form the basis of a successful meeting. There is also the need to discuss the matter with State governments. An appropriate opportunity to do so will be taken at an early date.

I cannot emphasise too much that proposals need to be properly developed and digested. In this regard the work currently being carried out by Standing Committee D of the Constitutional Convention, of which I am Chairman, has a direct bearing. The work which was referred to the Committee by the full Convention is not yet complete but I believe it is timely to refer to the various papers that have been commissioned by Committee D. I confirm that that Committee will be meeting in Melbourne on 2 October. I have already mentioned that the Perth session resolved in favour of an automatic double dissolution procedure following the rejection of Supply. Committee D was asked to give the resolution detailed drafting consideration and, on the basis of its discussions and resolutions, a revised draft has been prepared but not yet settled.

The main features of the revised draft can be briefly summarised as follows: An automatic double dissolution would occur if a Supply Bill is not passed by the Senate within 30 days; if there is a positive rejection by the Senate the Governor-General would have discretionary power to dissolve both Houses. The existing provision for requests to be made by the Senate in relation to money Bills would be retained; passage by the House of Representatives after a double dissolution would be sufficient for presentation of the Bill to the Governor-General for the royal assent; and interim Supply to cover the period of the election would be assured. In addition, the revised draft deals with a number of incidental problems identified in an earlier Standing Committee D report. The suggestion that Supply for more than one year could be obtained at the start of a government's term of office is precluded and the Senate's right to object to the inclusion of extraneous matters in money Bills is strengthened by a procedure which would allow challenges to offending Bills to be instituted in the High Court.

The proposal that the maximum term of a parliament be extended to four years is the subject of a paper by Professor Joan Rydon of La Trobe University, in which the historical background of existing terms of Commonwealth and State parliaments, arguments for their extension and the implications of such action are examined. Chief among these in relation to the Commonwealth Parliament is, of course, the question of a change to the term of senators. Also under examination by Committee D is the related proposal for a fixed term for parliaments. The conventions applicable to the operation of the Australian Constitution are also under examination by Committee D in accordance with a request by the Perth Convention. A number of papers have been commissioned on different aspects of this question and honourable senators will be aware that one has already been made publicly available. This is a paper prepared by Dr Cheryl Saunders of Melbourne University and Mr Ewart Smith, formerly a deputy secretary of my Department. That paper sought to identify some of the conventions associated with the Constitution.

Other papers have been obtained from Professor Kevin Ryan of Queensland University on the power of the Governor-General to dissolve the House of Representatives and both Houses of Parliament, from Professor Geoffrey Sawer of the Australian National University on conventions governing the appointment and dismissal of Ministers and from Mr Ewart Smith on conventions regulating the relationship between the two Houses of the Commonwealth Parliament.

As part of its task, Committee D was asked to formulate conventions suitable for inclusion in the Commonwealth Constitution. However, I think it is apparent from these papers that that task may need to be modified since many of the practices and principles that are discussed are clearly not suitable for such treatment. In other cases the problem is really one that demands political resolution before any convention could be formulated.

Considerable work has also been carried out on a number of other matters. By a majority of 54 to 36 the Perth Convention approved a draft constitutional amendment to confer an advisory jurisdiction on the High Court. Quite independently, the Senate Standing Committee on Constitutional and Legal Affairs made a similar recommendation in its report entitled 'Advisory Opinions by the High Court' dated October 1977. Since the Perth Convention adjourned, further discussions have been carried out between representatives of Committee D and the Senate Committee to attempt to reconcile minor differences between the two recommendations. As a result, a revised proposal has been formulated for consideration by Committee D.

The representation of Territories and new States in the Commonwealth Parliament was not debated at the Perth sessions Convention but was referred to Committee D for further consideration. A paper by Professor Zines of the Australian National University discusses the proposal that was put forward by the present Minister for Home Affairs and Environment, Mr Ian Wilson, and the proposed amendments that were foreshadowed at Perth. A paper has also been obtained on Admiralty and maritime jurisdiction of the High Court from Mr Geoffrey Lindell of the ANU as part of the Committee's consideration of the judicial power of the Commonwealth.
In conclusion, I refer to what a previous Governor-General, Sir Paul Hasluck, said at the opening of the Australian Constitutional Convention in Sydney in 1973. Sir Paul said:

'You are to try to find ways in which the Australia of today and tomorrow can best be governed and how the national interest of Australia can best be advanced. I suggest that means finding a way in which one people in one continent will live in harmony, using their skills and resources for the greatest common good and for the strength of the nation . . . You make a constitution or you amend a constitution not for the sense of the document but for the good of a people and the best possible government of a nation. Constitutions are not, themselves, so sacred as to be worthy of worship, but the principles they serve can command continuing reverence. The practical wisdom of the provisions they make can earn abiding respect. Let us be clear about the principles on which we base any proposals for amendment. Let us seek for practical wisdom in shaping them.'

I respectfully adopt those words of Sir Paul Hasluck. There are no easy solutions. If we expect the Australian people to approve changes to the Constitution, those changes have to be well thought out and properly developed. It is our responsibility, as members of the national Parliament, to do much of the work needed to make those changes possible. It means that we should strive to reach maximum agreement between ourselves on the nature of proposed changes particularly when we are all agreed that some change is necessary. We must consult with State governments and parliaments about the need for such changes, and the proposals need to be widely discussed and understood by the people of Australia.

Finally, the Constitution will be successfully amended only if there is an agreed view in this Parliament that will give leadership to the people. The experience of 1977 indicates that, where there is substantial agreement between political parties and between the Commonwealth and the States, and especially where the proposals have been endorsed by the Australian Constitutional Convention, there is a better than even chance of these proposals being carried. I seek the support of all senators and members of parliament in helping to carry out our responsibilities for constitutional review. I seek leave to move a motion.
Leave granted.

TALK.START.PARA: —I move:

SPEECH.PARA: That the Senate take note of the statement.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Evans Sen G.J.

TALK.START.PARA: —The process of constitutional reform is so notoriously hard to move forward, and the task of securing the necessary consensus between major parties and interest groups is so obviously difficult that one is grateful for any crumb or skerrick of interest that falls from the Government's table. This statement made this afternoon by the Attorney-General (Senator Durack) is, I suppose, to that extent, to be welcomed by the Opposition. It does indicate some kind of continuing interest by the Government in the process of constitutional reform. It indicates a particular interest in some matters of lively interest currently, including that of four-year and fixed term parliaments. It does acknowledge the desirability of non-government efforts presently taking place, especially through the Law Foundation of New South Wales project, to try to generate a serious national debate on the question of constitutional renewal. It does indicate in a roundabout kind of way that the Government will support the holding of another meeting of the Australian Constitutional Convention in due course at some considerable support for continuing activity by the committees and the other functioning units of the existing Australian Constitutional Convention in order to achieve a preparatory foundation for that proposed further meeting of the Convention proper.

SPEECH.PARA: All that said, it must be stated that the Attorney-General's statement really is a bit of a damp squib. It demonstrates only a crumb or skerrick of interest by the Government in constitutional reform. No sense of enthusiasm or excitement was conveyed by the Attorney-General's statement or the way in which it was delivered. Certainly, there was no sense that the 1988 bicentenary year of this nation really does offer a wonderful opportunity for a major national exercise in constitutional renewal. The Attorney-General gives the appearance of someone who is rather profoundly uninterested in the process of constitutional reform or renewal, not to mention law reform of any other kind, and someone who is being reluctantly dragged to the barrier because the Government does not want to be seen to be lagging too hopelessly behind the momentum which is obviously being generated elsewhere in the community.

There are a number of negative, churlish, unconstructive and occasionally just plain silly features of the statement. Let me focus briefly on five of them to satisfy one or other of those descriptions. The first point I mention is the attack made by the statement on my own description of the present Constitution-the Attorney-General did not have the courtesy to acknowledge it as such, although he did put it between inverted commas in the text of his statement-as being 'unreadable' and its operation as being 'at best irrational and at worst unworkable'. I am a fairly robust kind of a soul and I certainly do not mind my arguments being summarised, as they were in the recent issue of the Australian from which the Attorney-General quoted, or being subjected to rational counter-argument, but I really object to them being matched with sentimental platitudes of the kind that emanated from the Attorney when he dealt with this matter because it does not advance the process of debate very far. As much as it hurts all of us-I do not exclude myself from this-if we are to be serious about generating a really significant momentum towards constitutional reform in the years ahead, we will have to bury some of our party political hatchets. We will have to treat each other on this matter, if no other matter in this chamber, with perhaps a little more respect than we are inclined to do.

The second point I make, in pursuance, no doubt, of treating my opponent with respect, relates to the smug rejection by the Attorney's statement, again without rational argument, of the feasibility of there being any possibility of achieving a completely new Constitution by 1988. As to that, I acknowledge the difficulties. One would have to be a pretty heroic kind of optimist to believe there would be any massive re-writing of that kind of the Constitution, but I remind the Attorney, who I take it does have an historical sense, if no other, of the circumstances which prevailed in 1893, seven years before the turn of the century. That in itself amounted to another watershed date of the kind that 1988 now represents to us. If a brand new Constitution was able to be generated out of the atmosphere of apathy which existed in 1893 and in the context of the waring colonial fiefdoms, all with their own local prides and prejudices, then it ought not to be beyond us now, with all the sophistication and experience of this century behind us, to do the same thing.

The third point I wish to make relates to the rather breathtakingly cheeky claim by the Attorney that the 1975 seas and submerged lands case was one of the great demonstrations of the effective adjustment through the High Court of Australia of the Constitution to the realities of social and economic change. It was looked at as a purely judicial exercise as matters stood after the determination of that case. What has happened subsequently is that this Government has been party to an unprecedented collusive sell-out in company with the States during 1978, which has had the effect of completely undermining the whole effect of that off-shore sovereignty decision by the High Court.

Fourthly, I issue a cry of protest again about the patronising rejection by the Attorney of the concept of a popular convention as a useful vehicle towards constitutional change-the concept of there being not just a kind of indirectly established representative parliamentarians' convention of the kind we have had limping along since 1973 but rather a notion of having a convention directly elected by the people, on a directly representative rather than an indirectly representative basis.

Two things need to be said about the Attorney's apparent rejection out of hand of this concept. One is that it seems to overlook the utility of a convention being established on the basis, even if it does turn out to be constituted, as is probably likely, mainly by professional politicians, of acting as a vehicle for the capturing of the popular imagination through direct participation in the process of establishing the thing-getting it set in train and determining who the people's representatives will be. This is an inherent and integral part of that notion.

The other point I make about the Attorney's rejection of the popular conventions model is the more technical one. Of course, it is true that as the present Constitution remains it is the job, and will remain the job, of this Commonwealth Parliament actually to set in train the process of implementing constitutional amendment proposals. The ultimate mode of implementation is the referendum. In order for a matter to be put to referendum there has to be, as things stand at the moment, a Bill passed through the present Commonwealth Parliament. What the Attorney seems to have failed to address himself to in rejecting the utility of a popularly elected convention in this process is the really significant role that such a convention can play, not in the actual implementation stage of constitutional reform but at the stage of initiating proposals and generating widespread acceptance for them.

In the past a whole variety of mechanisms have been tried as a way of generating proposals for constitutional reform. There has been the existing representative parliamentarians convention. Before that there were royal commissions and joint parliamentary committees; I think at one stage there was a Premiers Conference from which proposals arose, and so on, with other models rearing their heads from time to time. The joy of the proposal for a popular convention-in outline its detail needs much more discussion and refinement before the idea can possibly take shape-is that it does offer a vehicle, as I have said, for capturing a much more widespread community sense of involvement and participation in the process of generating initially those proposals for change.

The fifth and final negative point in the Attorney-General's statement to which I draw attention is what seems to me to be its rather inappropriate enthusiasm-it is the one bit of enthusiasm which does seep through the statement-for implementing in its newly drafted form the Liberal proposal for solving in the future a very vexed problem of Supply deadlocks. That proposal in its newly drafted form was successfully moved by Sir Charles Court at the 1978 Perth Convention. The recommendation that was passed by that 1978 Convention on the Supply deadlock, after a long debate which the Attorney-General will no doubt remember as well as I do, was to endorse the Charles Court version rather than the Whitlam version. That version was, of course, passed by a very narrow majority-on my recollection something like 49 to 39-with a vote on purely party lines. Of course, it is obvious that this issue will continue to be a divisive one within the community. There is no prospect of a hard-line amendment of that kind or of the kind that has been now redrafted in a more precise form in the terms that were mentioned by the Attorney.

TALK.START.PARA: —Where did you get the redraft from?

—I was party to the redraft as a member of Standing Committee D. It was a purely technical exercise done by Standing Committee D because it was directed to do that by the Constitutional Convention and to resubmit the draft which tidies up a few loose ends of the Court proposal and improves the Court proposal, technically. That is then for the Convention-or its constituent units-to do what it likes with. I am not objecting to that process having taken place because that was something that was required to happen by the Convention. What I am objecting to is the emphasis that this matter has been given in the Attorney's statement. It rather suggests that that is one of the proposals that the Attorney really does think has some kind of momentum behind it.

SPEECH.PARA: My point is simply that if that is the kind of proposal that the Attorney is going to get enthusiastic about and if that is what he means by constitutional review being likely to be successful, we really are destined for a hard, bleak and barren time ahead because that is the kind of proposal about which obviously there will be continued confrontation and divisivness in the future. Our responsibility, on the other side and on my side, is to try to find a way through that impasse, to try to find some possible kind of half-way house with which we can solve the acute constitutional dilemmas that we confronted in 1975 and ensure they are not repeated. The half-way house that I will be suggesting to the Senate that it might take seriously in this respect is the concept of the fixed term parliament. I will be moving a private member's Bill within the next few weeks to that effect. In that context we can no doubt have a more protracted debate on this issue than is possible today.

I believe there is a strong case for rethinking, not just a handful of particular provisions in the present Constitution, which the Attorney seems to acknowledge might be a useful exercise, but rather the whole document, root and branch. I think we need to rethink the institutions of national government in this country as they exist at the moment and the relationships between them. I think we need to rethink the relations of Australia, legally and symbolically, with the United Kingdom and with the monarchy. I think we need to rethink the whole question of our present Federal structure and the division of financial and functional responsibilities between the different levels of government that will no doubt continue to exist in this country in the future. I think we need to rethink the question of whether the Constitution should contain limitations on the power of government at all levels; in particular, of course, in the form of a Bill of Rights to protect the rights and liberties universially acknowledged to be enjoyed, at least in principle, by the citizenry. Finally, I think we ought to rethink the whole question of the machinery of constitutional change, not just as a one-off exercise but to enable a more systematic, thorough-going and flexible process of constitutional change in the future to ensure that we adapt rather more effectively to continuing social and economic changes in the community at large than our Constitution has been able to accept so far.

I conclude by referring to one matter in the Attorney-General's statement which the Attorney mentioned in order to endorse, but I fear only in a rather faint praise kind of way; the reference he made to the project recently announced on 10 August by the New South Wales Law Foundation. With the very substantial financial support of that Foundation there is to be set in train-it is now off and running-a major action oriented research project over the next year. It will have two stages. The first is the preparation of a report in book form to be prepared on behalf of the Foundation and the supervising committees by Mr John McMillan, who is in the chamber I am delighted to see. The second stage of the project will be a series of seminars to be held on a national basis in each capital city around the country to launch that book and to present to discussion, at least in rudimentary terms, in initial exploratory terms, the findings and suggestions arising from it. The seminars will be attended by 100 or so, we hope, of the leading opinion makers in this community. The object of setting this project in train is to shift the whole question of constitutional reform back into the square centrepiece of the public stage so that it will, in fact, once again become part of the political agenda in this country. The object of it is to set in train a serious national debate on the possibilities of systematic constitutional renewal, in particular in the context of the target date of 1988.

The support that this project-and others that are growing up around it-is generating in the community at large is perhaps demonstrated, if I can take another moment or so to show this, by the kind of people who have, in fact, demonstrated their support for it. None of them necessarily agrees yet about the substantive reforms the Constitution needs. What they agree about is the necessity, the desirability of this kind of serious national debate being instituted. The project is to be supervised by a small committee, the convenor of which is Mr Terence Purcell, the Director of the Law Foundation of New South Wales. Constituting that committee will be Sir Clarrie Harders, a former Secretary of the Commonwealth Attorney-General's Department; Professor Ronald Sackville, Chairman of the New South Wales Law Reform Commission and not a party figure in any sense; Haddon Storey, Q.C., the Victorian Liberal Attorney-General; and me as a Federal Labor Party spokesman on legal affairs. Other members of the consultative committee that were announced when the project was set in train on 10 August are, from the political arena, Neal Blewett, Don Chipp, Bob Hawke, John Hyde, Senators Kathy Martin, Alan Missen and Peter Rae and Frank Walker from New South Wales-a fairly carefully devised balance between State and Federal people and also between both sides of politics. From the universities there is Professor Gordon Reid, a former Sergeant-at-Arms in the House of Representatives and now Professor of Political Science in Perth, and Geoffrey Sawer, whom everyone will recognise as the doyen of constitutional lawyers-now unfortunately retired-in this country. From the law reform-public policy area there is Donald Horne; John Maddison, Q.C., a former Liberal Attorney-General of New South Wales; Professor Jack Richardson, the Commonwealth Ombudsman; and John Valder, the Chairman of the Institute of Public Affairs in New South Wales and a former Chairman of the Sydney Stock Exchange. From the area of business and trade unions there is Paul Munro, now Federal Secretary of the Administrative and Clerical Officers Association, and Robert Holmes a'Court, who scarcely needs further introduction. I am pleased to announce today that the process of adding names to that consultative panel continues. Since that list was announced on 10 August we have had agreeing to participate in the project Sir John Moore, the President of the Australian Conciliation and Arbitration Commission; Ella Stack, the former Mayor of Darwin and a very well-known lady in her own right; Franca Arena, a New South Wales activist who has just been elected to the New South Wales Legislative Council; and Sir Laurence Muir, well known both in Melbourne and in the national business community. With this kind of support-not that any of the people I have identified at this stage can be relied upon to agree as yet about anything very much when it comes to substantive reforms, but it is to be hoped that they can agree about the kind of mechanism for change in the future that should proceed-it is clear that there is a very real developing momentum for change at work in the community of the kind that could obviously be no longer ignored by the Government. It is obvious that the matters raised by the Minister's statement require a full scale debate at some stage in this Parliament. I look forward to an early opportunity being arranged between both sides of this chamber for what I hope will be a constructive and full debate to take place.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Macklin Sen M.J.

TALK.START.PARA: —I will make only a few brief comments on the ministerial statement of the Attorney-General (Senator Durack), and I will refer also to some of the points raised by Senator Evans. The Australian Democrats welcome what we see as at least a start to the whole notion of constitutional change within this country. I think probably it is politically appropriate that such a statement should be made at this time, given that yesterday the Senate was involved in exercising certain of its constitutional powers and was debating what and which powers it ought properly to make use of, which powers it has, and how far it is willing to go in exercising them. Since the Budget was brought down the Australian Democrats have attempted to spell out what we consider should be the proper functions of an upper House, and we have tried to delineate how far we are willing to go in relation to those powers. I think we have made a fairly clear statement about our attitude to one of the main items raised by the Attorney-General, that is, the notion of Supply and the role of the Upper House in relation to that.

SPEECH.PARA: I shall take up some other matters before I come to that. One matter raised by Senator Evans related to the rejection in the statement of the notion of a popular convention. It is the Australian Democrats voted policy that such a convention ought to replace the parliamentary convention. We believe that the parliamentary convention, while exercising itself greatly, tends to be yet another party forum. It would be far better if we could have a popularly elected convention. No doubt its members would be involved also in party politics, but at least those people would not be holding positions within Parliament. In fact, we hope that parliamentarians would refrain from standing for membership of such a convention so that it could go about its task of seeking wider and more popularly based views about what the Constitution ultimately ought to be.

TALK.START.PARA: —Would you exclude all members of parliament?

—We would not deliberately set about excluding members of parliament but we think it would be better if members of parliament did not stand for membership of such a convention. As we see the situation, parliamentarians have plenty of opportunities to exercise the right to speak to the electorate and to make their points of view heard in this chamber and other chambers within Australia, at both Federal and State levels. There ought to be an attempt, I think, to have a popularly based convention to seek constitutional renewal, to use that rather felicituous phrase. As a consequence of the statement of the rejection of the notion of a popular convention, there is a point on page 7 of the ministerial statement which again attributes to parliamentarians some rather nice things. It would be nice if they were the case, but I do not believe they are. The Attorney-General said:

SPEECH.PARA: It is instructive to note that persons actually elected to that convention were almost invariably parliamentarians, including Ministers.

He suggested that this was why the conventions were ultimately successful. While it is certainly accepted that politicians and parliamentarians may have a certain range of expertise, that statement almost suggests that politicians and parliamentarians have a monopoly on common sense, and concern about the convention and that they have all the practical experience available in the nation. I suggest that there is a whole range of people within the community, in business, government, the Public Service, and in universities, all of whom have practical experience. I am quite sure that any honourable senators who belong to organisations know that almost every organisation in this land, when it gets itself going, becomes involved in the establishment of its own constitution, and that is always a basis for lively discussion. It is always a discussion in which people in any organisation wish to be involved and to participate.

I suggest that to say some type of observer system will be provided is worse than not talking about it at all. Citizens in this land should never be considered mere observers of the Constitutional Convention. These are the basic rules which govern our democracy and they are so important and fundamental that citizens should never be considered to be observers but should be active participants in the formulation, in the debate, and even in the eventual drawing up of proposals for rules. That is why the Australian Democrats in this House and outside have pushed the notion of having a citizens initiative brought forward in this country to allow citizens to intrude themselves into the political arena at whatever time they choose, whether that is acceptable to politicians or not. We will continue to support that notion of the intrusion of citizens into the political arena when they so choose and on whatever basis they wish to come in.

The Australian Democrats being a party in the liberal tradition and having a relationship at the moment with other parties around the world as a member of Liberal International-possibly this weekend at our national convention that position will be taken a step further-we have had a continuing interest in the notion of constitutional and electoral change. As a reformist party in that radical tradition, in the correct sense of the word, we will continue to push very strongly those notions of constitutional and electoral change to make sure that the democratic base of this society is as fair and as representative as it can possibly be at this time.

I agree with Senator Evans that there appears to be an attitude in the ministerial statement that the whole thing may bumble on somewhat and that if it gets somewhere then it gets somewhere, but if it does not it does not really matter. I believe that is to throw cold water on what should be an exciting debate which should continually exercise our minds. While there is some faint praise for the suggestion that we ought to look at 1988 not as a target for the final thing but for some type of renewal, nevertheless there is not much in the statement which suggests that the Government is going to take any action whatsoever to bring that about. I believe that is unfortunate. Surely constitutional changes are of continuing importance to a democracy and must be very close to the top of the agenda of a States' House in a federation.

Rather interestingly, on page 9 of the statement a point is raised on a matter that was brought up last night and will probably come up again and again in the next month or two. I refer to the suggestion that Supply may be obtained for more than one year and also the possibility of strengthening the Senate's right to object to the inclusion of extraneous matters in money Bills. Obviously, the point raised last night by Senator Harradine, which he has given notice he will raise again, is a central point and cannot be ignored in the context of the debate. At the end of the statement there is a point that may not be meant to be an elitist view but certainly reads like one. It is stated:
Finally, the Constitution will be successfully amended only if there is an agreed view in this Parliament that will give leadership to the people.

While I certainly accept that the possibility of a constitutional change of any magnitude passing through Parliament unless it has support on both sides of politics, is almost nil, given the result of previous referenda in this country, to suggest that it would be successful only if this Parliament got itself organised and gave leadership to the people turns everything on its head. With the exception of countries where constitutional change takes place under dictatorships, when nobody gets a look in anyway, the whole history of constitutional change in other countries is that almost invariably it comes from the people. It has to be supported and argued through by the people. It is suggested that this Parliament give leadership. To suggest that this document is to be taken as an example of leadership is to suggest that no leadership will be given and therefore no change will be undertaken. The Attorney-General is seeking the support of all senators and members of the Parliament in discharging the responsibility in regard to constitutional change. We certainly pledge our support and hope that in the interim the Attorney-General will make some suggestions, other than those contained in this paper, as to what in fact we are to support, and as to the moves that hopefully he is about to make in exercising the leadership role which, according to his statement, he believes is so important.

Finally, I wish to refer to the only constitutional matter that has actually been raised. That is the reference to Standing Committee D of the Australian Constitution Convention and the work that it has done, subsequent to the submission of the special report on the Senate and Supply since 1978. The Australian Constitutional Convention report by Standing Committee D makes extremely interesting reading in the light of what is occurring at present in the Senate. At a meeting in Perth on 28 July 1978 Mr Lionel Bowen said:

When a government wins at an election and it has a majority, at all times we say that that Government is entitled to govern, it has a mandate. Are we to leave it to the vagaries of what the people think of a Government from month to month or from week to week? You well know that public opinion fluctuates . . . Let us remember the position in 1972; we were faced with the threat of Supply, it was suggested in 1973, virtually warned in 1974, so we had our double dissolution. It was again threatened in 1975-another double dissolution. We lived from year to year since 1972 with the continual threat of a Government never being able to maintain the situation unless it had a majority in the Senate.

That expresses very clearly our view that we have no intention of allowing a government to be under that threat from year to year, whether it be a Liberal or Labor government; that it cannot operate effectively as a government if year after year it is under the threat of having Supply cut off. Mr Bowen went on to say:

What about the position in the future, from 1980, where an election can take place for the House of Representatives, certainly would mean, of course, a Senate of a different colour because only half the Senate would be retiring . . .

In other words, Mr Bowen, in his forward-thinking speech at that convention, pointed out that the type of problem that occurred in 1972, 1973, 1974 and 1975 could in fact continue to be encountered from 1981 onwards. The Australian Democrats are pledged to make sure that that does not happen while the nation and its Parliament are in a position to discuss altering the Constitution.
