I look forward very much to Senator Evans's private member's Bill on the notion of having fixed-term parliaments. I believe that that is a possible solution which could gain support from both sides and would, through its technical operation, remove the whole problem of Supply being blocked in the Upper House.

The moves made by Mr Whitlam and Mr Hamer are so obviously based on the 1972 reminiscences that they have very little chance of success. Therefore, I look forward to Senator Evans's private member's Bill so that we can have discussion on that subject. I wish to quote again what Mr Whitlam said at a convention in 1976, the substance of which was raised in the ministerial statement by the Attorney-General. He said:
It means that no Government-
He is referring to the threat from the Upper House-
without control in the Senate can afford to take unpopular measures which may be necessary for good government for fear of being forced to an election at a time when its popularity is low.

The Australian Democrats certainly, as part of their policy, support the notion of a fixed-term of office and believe that a government should complete the term in respect of which it pledged itself at an election. For instance, this Government was re-elected by the people eight months ago and should carry through its program. We will not obstruct Supply or money Bills. We will allow the Government to govern and in due course, in three years time, present itself to the people. We believe that at that time the Government will be defeated on the types of decisions it has made in regard to this Budget. We have no doubt that it will be defeated on that ground. But until such time as the people again have the chance to express their views, this Government will remain the Government of this country. There will not be a premature election while we hold the position that we do in this Senate. The Government itself would have to choose to have a double dissolution on other Bills that we will be scrutinising. Indeed, some of the Bills that the Government has already suggested it will bring forward will not receive our support. If these Bills do not receive the support of the Australian Labor Party they will be defeated. If the Government had the courage of its convictions, it would be bringing forward legislation for us to debate. I wish to quote again from Mr Whitlam, who said:
It means that we must now ignore-
He was referring to the matter raised by the Attorney-General in his statement about Supply-
the experience of 75 years, and literally hundreds of precedents in our own system alone, that a hostile Senate does not deny Supply . . .

We believe that our stance, is one that ultimately will receive the acceptance of the Australian people. We would hope that it would be in a form that would not only deal with the Supply issue but also be developmental and innovative for the future. While we hold the position that we do, we will ensure that the issue of Supply ceases to be an item on the political agenda of this country. We hope that it can be put aside, discussed in quieter places than this chamber and a resolution on it can be adopted by the people of this country. Until such time as that occurs we will not allow the Senate to use the powers which it probably has to bring down a government by blocking its Supply.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Missen Sen A.J.

TALK.START.PARA: —The paper before us is entitled 'Constitutional Review'. As has been pointed out, in its last paragraph the Attorney-General (Senator Durack) seeks the support of all senators and members of parliament to help carry out the responsibility for constitutional review. I can only say that the Attorney-General is going about obtaining that support in a funny way, having in mind the way in which this paper comes before the Senate today. The first I knew that this statement was to be made in the Senate was when the Attorney-General sought leave to make a statement and started to read it this afternoon. I think that, as Chairman of the Senate Standing Committee on Constitutional and Legal Affairs, I might have been expected to have an interest in the matter. I know that those honourable senators in the Op- position who have responsibility for these matters have had an hour or so in which to study the paper and to prepare their comments on it. I was asked by Senator Evans when I planned to speak on the statement. I told him that at that stage I did not know what the statement was about but, from its heading, it would appear that I would be interested in it and I would decide when I heard it.

SPEECH.PARA: I think I should make some comments on this paper which has come before us today but I ask why it was not listed on the daily business sheet. Presumably it was prepared over a period. Why was it not listed on today's business sheet? Why is it that once again something on which it is intended that a debate will ensue is sprung upon the Senate? Even in the statement it is claimed that the Government wants to encourage debate and discussion on the matters covered in it.

Senator Peter Rae is not here; I do not know whether he knows anything about the presentation of this statement. Both he and I represented the Senate in part of the 1978 Constitutional Convention. I would have thought that I had shown sufficient interest in those subjects to have been given warning that this matter was coming on for debate today. Therefore when the matter was first raised I had no knowledge of it. Despite the fact that the Whips are a little jaundiced by the fact that a further speaker has come into this debate, I think it is important to say a few things about the statement before us.

I will refer briefly to four points in the statement because they are significant. I regret that the statement does not come to more positive conclusions on constitutional reform, does not tell us that constitutional referenda proposals are to be put forward in the near future, but of course the statement does indicate some good work which has been carried out by the Australian Constitutional Convention. The first of those matters is the Attorney-General's statement that he thinks it is nonsense to assert, as some people do, that there is general agreement that the Constitution is an inadequate instrument for the type of democratic government desired by Australians. I think that that was a very mild expression. I believe that there is clear agreement among the people in this country who are taking an interest in the matter that it is an inadequate instrument. It is true that it has managed, with the assistance of the courts, to develop a number of powers so that the disjunctive nature of our Constitution has not been felt as much as it might have been.

It is quite right to say, as the Attorney-General said, that the proper course is to work towards amending our existing Constitution. I certainly agree that it is beyond the realm of possibility to expect a new Constitution, but to expect a Constitution which is substantially amended is not beyond the realm of possibility. I applaud the efforts being made by the committee to which Senator Evans referred and of which he is a member. As a member of the consultative committee attached to that committee, I certainly want to work hard to develop further interest in constitutional reform, to look at the hard questions and to try to find solutions to the problems posed by those questions. I agree with Senator Evans's comment today that we must try to find a way through the constitutional dilemmas. That is one of the major tasks for us in Australia. There is inadequate interest in constitutional reform. That is evi- denced to some extent by the relatively poor attendance in this chamber today during a debate on a subject such as this.

TALK.START.PARA: —Perhaps they do not know it is on.

—My colleague from South Australia has pointed out that perhaps honourable senators do not know it is on. Of course, it should have occurred to me that that is an obvious reason, but perhaps he is a little more idealistic now than he will be after further experience of this place. He may find that on many occasions honourable senators will know that events are taking place in the chamber but they still, regrettably, will not turn up. However, I believe that it is necessary for us to develop an interest in constitutional reform and to ensure that a more adequate instrument is produced by us through reforms and amendments to the Constitution.

SPEECH.PARA: The second point raised in this statement to which I refer-this point has been developed at some length by two other speakers in this debate-is the suggestion of a popular conven- tion, which the Attorney-General regards as not likely to be a goer. He claims it will not replace the Parliamentarians Convention. I am of the opinion that the Parliamentarians Convention, which is mostly a collection of State members, has done a considerable amount of good work. It has developed quite a climate of opinion in favour of some constitutional amendments that have succeeded. I think that others which have been the result of their deliberations may well succeed also. At the same time, I think it is time for us to move on to a popular convention.

I do not believe that a popular convention should, as Senator Macklin would have it, somehow exclude politicians-that by a self-denying ordinance politicians would not be part of the convention. That would be foolish because the practitioners, the people who work with the Constitution and very often see the most rusty of its joints are the ones who ought also to be attending the convention. However, I likewise agree with Senator Macklin that parliamentarians should not have a monopoly. They have no monopoly of knowledge or common sense. Such a convention would, I believe, be one in which politicians would constitute but a relatively small minority of those who are elected by popular vote. I believe it would need to be a convention which met not once every three or four years, as the present convention is doing, and be a weekend away for a number of politicians; it would need to be one which met over a considerable period in a year and which got down to the problems before us.

I do not find any conviction in the argument that we cannot have such a popular convention because proposals for constitutional reform can be put to a referendum only by an enactment of the national Parliament. We know that, but the fact is that if such a convention got behind it a very substantial body of opinion, as was the case at the original convention which formed the Constitution, of course those proposals could be swept through the Parliament. There has to be public demand and, following that, one can expect that the Parliament may well operate in that regard.

I was disappointed to read in the statement that we are only now speaking of the next convention. If we are going to go ahead with the Parliamentarians Convention, and at this stage that course of action obviously seems to be necessary, one wonders why we have waited three years before holding the next one. One wonders why, as was said earlier, the Government is only now considering the next plenary session and is to have discussions with the State governments. The Attorney-General stated: 'An appropriate opportunity to do so will be taken at an early date'. One wonders why discussions have not taken place with the State governments well before this time so that in the current period of the Parliament and before we move into the next election we can contemplate further meetings of the Constitutional Convention and further constitutional changes being introduced in the Parliament. It is disappointing that this matter is taking such a slow course.

The last matter I refer to with regard to this statement is the Attorney-General's strong support for a proposal of the Constitutional Convention, adopted largely on party lines, to institute an automatic double dissolution procedure, popularly known as the 'Court procedure'. I hold the same view on that as does Senator Evans. I believe that it is a matter on which hardened views are held generally on party lines. In addition, there is so much opposition to such a one-sided solution to the problem of the conflict between the two Houses that I have no doubt that such a proposal would not be carried by a constitutional convention. I find the solution to the problem quite implausible and I believe it would not be acceptable to the broad range of Australian people. Therefore I think we must look still at finding solutions to the problems to stop a recurrence of what occurred in 1975.

I welcome the statement in the sense that it shows a continuing interest in matters of constitutional reform. I regret that it does not indicate urgent activity in that area and that it rejects so many of what I believe are the more hopeful signs for the continuation of parliamentary reform by popular convention. Finally, I hope there will be further debate on this subject-I realise that time is short at present-but I hope that urgent action will be taken to get ahead with constitutional reform. Mr Acting Deputy President, I seek leave to continue my remarks later.
Leave granted; debate adjourned.

DEBATE.TITLE: QUEENSLAND ABORIGINALS AND TORRES STRAIT ISLANDERS (SELF-MANAGEMENT AND LAND RIGHTS) BILL 1981

PROCTEXT.PARA: Debate resumed from 16 September, on motion by Senator Ryan:
That the Bill be now read a second time.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Evans Sen G.J.

TALK.START.PARA: —A few weeks ago the Aboriginal people of Cherbourg Aboriginal Reserve in south-east Queensland, in Mr Bjelke-Petersen's own electorate, prepared a petition to the Premier calling for freehold title to their reserve. As is reported in the National Times of 4 September, 300 people signed that petition which was handed to Senator Bjelke-Petersen's husband at the opening of a new wing of the Murgon primary school by Charlie Renouf, a field officer of the Aboriginal Legal Service. A couple of days later, on the following Monday, a school groundsman found that petition in a rubbish bin. This is the attitude of the Premier. That is the attitude of the Queensland Government to land rights in that State. This is why it is necessary for the Commonwealth to act now in discharge of the constitutional responsibilities in this area vested in it by the referendum of 1967. This is why it is necessary for the Senate and the Opposition within the Senate to act now by way of the hitherto unusual course of a private members Bill because this Government has made it abundantly clear that it will not act, that it will, unless it is forced to do otherwise, continue to kowtow, to genuflect and to pay obeisance to the kind of redneck racism which continues to parade as State rights north of the Tweed.

SPEECH.PARA: The Fraser Government simply will not react in a protective way against the announced intention of the Queensland Government to abolish Aboriginal reserves in Queensland. This Government has shown that it will not react to counter the kind of attitude evidenced again by the failure of the Queensland Government to transfer title to land being purchased on behalf of Aboriginals in the Archer River area, the matter which is now, of course, the subject of challenge in the High Court by Queensland, putting at risk the whole constitutionality or the whole existence of the Racial Discrimination Act as a result.

The Bill before us today embodies principles which are themselves embodied in existing legislation which has been passed by the Fraser Government-the 1976 Aboriginal Land Rights (Northern Territory) Act and the 1978 Aboriginal and Torres Strait Islanders (Queensland Reserves and Communities Self-management) Act. It ought to be, as a result, capable of accommodation by this Government if its word means anything. If it ever wants to be believed again when it claims through the mouth of Senator Baume or anyone else commitment to Aboriginal land rights, it ought to give support to this measure which has come back into the Parliament today.

The basic elements of this Bill were outlined by Senator Ryan during her second reading speech. I think perhaps they need to be recapitulated to have the foundations or the bearings before us for the remarks that I later want to make. Part I of the Bill deals with the question of self-management of reserves. It creates an optional system of self-management which will not be able to be circumvented by the Queensland Government. Part II of the Bill, which is rather more complicated, deals with the question of the grants of land to Aboriginal land trusts in respect of particular Aboriginal reserves. This Part of the Bill makes provision for first the ability to make a land rights claim in respect of reserves; secondly, power for the Federal Minister to acquire the claimed land compulsorily from the Queensland Government; thirdly, the setting up of an Aboriginal land trust in respect of each reserve so acquired; fourthly, minerals to remain the property of the State but mining to be allowed in the event that either the land trust agrees on the one hand or both Houses of the National Parliament pass a resolution on the other hand that mining must go ahead in the national interest. Finally, this Part of the Bill makes provision where mining does proceed for Aboriginal owners of the land to be entitled to compensation.

My task, as I see it in this debate, is essentially to reply to the speech on this Bill that was made by the Minister for Aboriginal Affairs, Senator Baume, and in particular to endeavour to deal with the series of what I fear are quite technical points that were made by the Minister by way really of endeavouring to support the proposition that this Bill was ill-drafted, ill-prepared and inappropriate as a result to be further dealt with at this stage by the Senate. I want to contest--

TALK.START.PARA: —They were only examples too; there were more.

—If the Minister throws up any more examples I will be only too delighted to deal with them on the run because so far it has not proved to be an insuperable task to deal with any of the matters that have been produced by the Minister and his team of bush lawyers who have been grinding away so assiduously in preparation for this debate. The basic comment I make about Senator Baume's contribution to this debate is that it is, to be fair, something of a curate's egg: It does have some good points, some suggestions that we should adopt in this Bill and can, of course, at the Committee stage. It does contain some reasonable points on which reasonable men and women may well differ. It certainly, however, contains some bad points which we cannot accept, and I will give some instances of those. It contains some misunderstandings and it contains some propositions which are simply inaccurate or based on a complete misreading of what we are endeavouring to do.

SPEECH.PARA: The opening salvo fired by Senator Baume proved to be a very damp squib in that he gave as his initial demonstration that the Bill was badly drafted the fact that it was even so incompetent as to confuse in at least one section-he instanced clause 37 (3)-a land trust with a land council. The reference to 'trusts' should have been a reference to 'council'. I am afraid in that respect that Senator Baume got it wrong because he was reading, in preparing his remarks, from an earlier and subsequently proof corrected draft of the Bill. In fact, all he served to do by making that point was to demonstrate the fact that he had not read the Bill very carefully at all because in fact he missed a similar proof reading error in clause 24 (3) of the Bill which was not in fact corrected in the final printed version. So maybe the rest of his speech is based on what we can only regard as not a terribly close reading of the Bill at all.

Let me move straight to the series of substantial points made by Senator Baume. I do not know whether these points were made by way of example but certainly he seemed anxious to put before the Parliament a pretty systematic set of examples. In any event let me deal with all the ones that appeared in the speech he made in this second reading debate. The first point I want to refer to appears on page 769 of Hansard where the Minister said:
If the Aboriginal Land Rights (Northern Territory) Act applied in Queensland many of the communities there would not be able to claim . . .
He went on to say:
The Northern Territory land rights model-
That is clearly embodied, as I have said and as Senator Ryan has said, in this Bill-
is inappropriate for Queensland.

That is a general point that is being made but it is one that falls to the ground as soon as one looks at the terms of clause 18 of the Bill and the definition therein of traditional Aboriginal owners, because what is added to that definition is a third description which in fact is quite different from the description of traditional Aboriginal owners that appears in the Northern Territory Bill. I acknowledge that there has been a drafting error: The word 'and' which links (b) and (c) should have read 'or'. That correction will be made at the Committee stage. But there is an alternative description of traditional Aboriginal owners which will be able to be relied upon by the Queensland Aboriginals, and that is local groups of Aboriginals or Islanders who 'are entitled to land ownership by virtue of prior residence on a reserve'. I should point out that we propose to add further to that in the Committee stage 'or by virtue of having been born on a reserve' to make further accommodation for the particular circumstances of the Aboriginal people. So here, as elsewhere, I will indicate in passing that there may well have been some legitimate misunderstanding of errors in the draft of the Bill as can only be expected when something is done in this fashion. But the basic point that was made as a second reading point and not as a Committee stage point by the Minister was in fact ill-founded.
The next point that the Minister raised-this was the first of a whole series of them which now appear in the next part of his speech-is on page 770 of Hansard. The Minister stated:

The Bill empowers councils to make any law for conduct, discipline and well-being of members without outside involvement or parliamentary scrutiny and in any manner the councils decide. This could allow extreme penalties for trivial conduct without the right of appeal.

That is a fair point and that is readily acknowledged by the Opposition. It is a point that really should have been accommodated in the draft of the Bill. It was initially put forward, I think, with a slightly too cavalier disregard for the utility of having a mechanism of disallowance. It is proposed to meet the Minister's point by incorporating at the Committee stage a modification of clause 10 of the present self-management Bill which will provide for disallowance by the Parli- ament of by-laws so promulgated by the mechanism elsewhere in the Bill. It also provides for a maximum penalty of $50 to apply in respect of any such by-laws. Also a defence of ignorance of the by-law in question is to be available. To clarify that for the record, I seek leave to incorporate in Hansard the proposed new sub-clauses which we will be endeavouring to incorporate at the Committee stage.
Leave granted.
The document read as follows-
Page 6, clause 10, after sub-clause (3), insert the following new sub-clauses:
(4) insert ''Where a Council makes by-laws under sub-section (1) the Council shall cause a copy of the by-laws to be received by the Minister.''

(5) insert ''Where the Minister receives a copy of any by-laws, he shall cause a copy of the by-laws to be laid before each House of the Parliament within 15 sitting days of that House after the day on which he received a copy of those by-laws.''

(6) insert ''Where a copy of any by-laws has been laid before a House of the Parliament in accordance with sub-section (5) of this section, sub-sections 48 (5), (5A) and (6) of the Acts Interpretation Act 1901 apply to and in relation to those by-laws as if references in those sub-sections to regulations were references to such by-laws.''

(7) insert ''The Council for a Reserve to which this Act applies, or for a Community to which this Act applies, shall use its best endeavours to ensure that the by-laws of the Council are made known to Aboriginals or Islanders who reside on the Reserve or are members of the Community.''
(8) insert ''The by-laws may provide that any contravention of a by-law is an offence punishable, upon conviction, by a fine not exceeding $50.''
(9) insert ''In proceedings for an offence referred to in sub-section (10), it is a defence if the person charged proves that he was not aware of the by-laws to which the offence relates.''

TALK.START.PARA: —It is a standard draft?
—It is a standard draft clause and so too are the other provisions about which I propose to seek leave. I apologise for not having made them available to the Minister before.
—Do you have any copies, just as a matter of interest?
—I am sorry, I do not. I left them in my room. The next point made-it follows straight on from the previous one-by the Minister is this:

SPEECH.PARA: The Bill exempts councils, under clauses 10 and 14, from application of Queensland laws and inserts no Commonwealth laws to fill the void.

It is true that no Commonwealth laws are inserted to fill the void but it is simply not true that the Queensland laws are completely excluded from the provisions of the legislation. In Part I of the Bill there is clause 14 and in Part II of the Bill there is clause 43, both of which as presently drafted do preserve those Queensland laws which are capable of operating concurrently with the by-laws in question.

TALK.START.PARA: —That is subject to clause 14 (1).

—The language 'capable of operating concurrently' might be thought to be vague and it seems to be so acclaimed by Senator Missen but that is a matter that has been checked rather carefully by the Opposition to see what the drafting practice elsewhere has been. We have discovered that that language which was utilised by us in these clauses is in fact thoroughly familiar, standard form, drafting language. It appears, for example, if Senator Missen would like to check just some fairly randomly chosen examples, in section 41 of the Atomic Energy Act, section 19 of the National Parks and Wildlife Act, section 19, I think, of the Financial Corporations Act and section 25 of the notorious Public Order (Protection of Persons and Property) Act, which I know is dear to Senator Missen's heart.
—I'll bet it does not exclude it from clause 14 (1).

—I do not think that is right but that is the kind of point that clearly we can argue out further in more nit-picking and tedious detail in the Committee stage. I am simply endeavouring to meet in a second reading contribution the kind of points that were made by the Minister, to acknowledge fault where fault exists but also to indicate where there is not really fault in drafting. Perhaps there was a reaction based on a misunderstanding or a too hasty reading of what we were endeavouring to do. The basic object of the exercise, of course, is to demonstrate to the Senate that we have before us a Bill which, whatever the need for further refinement of it in the Committee stage may be nonetheless is basically sound in its structure and has basically anticipated all the key things that have to be in a piece of legislation of this kind and that will in fact be perfectly workable subject to the Committee stage attention to detail. It is also of course appropriate to be supported now in the second reading debate. The next point that is made by the Minister again appears on page 770 of Hansard and is in the following terms:

SPEECH.PARA: Under clause 18 the Bill imports a new and peculiar definition of 'traditional Aboriginal owner' which is certainly inappropriate to many of the Queensland reserves.

That is a point that I have already endeavoured to cover in indicating to the Senate how and why the definition in clause 18 of 'traditional Aboriginal owners' is drafted as it is. I have also indicated to the Senate that it is proposed to modify in the Committee stage the existing draft of clause 18 by converting the word 'and' to the word 'or' and making paragraph (c) of clause 18 in its entirety read as follows:
are entitled to land ownership by virtue of prior residence on a Reserve, or by virtue of having been born on a reserve.

I think that particular formulation will be seen, new and peculiar as it may be in the sense that it is not in the Northern Territory Act or in any other legislation, to be still perfectly appropriate to meet the needs of the Queensland situation, which of course is the nub of the criticism that was earlier advanced.

Motion (by Senator Peter Baume) agreed to:

That unless otherwise ordered intervening General Business be postponed until after further consideration of General Business Order of the Day No. 139, Queensland Aboriginals and Torres Strait Islanders (Self-Management and Lands Right) Bill 1981.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Evans Sen G.J.

TALK.START.PARA: —Before the suspension of the sitting I was discussing a series of objections to the Bill that had been raised by the Minister for Aboriginal Affairs (Senator Peter Baume)-I was endeavouring to deal with them as briskly as the technicalities allowed-in order to indicate that the Bill is in fact acceptable, at least for a vote on the second reading, in its present terms. It contains no fundamental flaws; certainly none of the kind that cannot be easily corrected in the Committee stage. Indeed, we have anticipated most of the objections that have been made and which have any substance. Let me proceed to the next item mentioned by the Minister. On page 770 of Hansard he is reported as having said:

SPEECH.PARA: Clause 28 reserves minerals to the Crown in right of Queensland but limits Queensland's access to them.

Let me simply say that we do not read the Bill as having the complete effect that is claimed, especially if the clause in question is read in the context of clause 33 relating to grants of mining interest, and clause 40 (2), associated with that, which allows the grantee of such an interest an automatic right of entry into the land in question.
The next point relates to clause 28 (5) in respect of which the Minister said:
Clause 28 (5) of the Bill purports to impose an obligation on a State officer to register a title granted by the Commonwealth.

What the honourable senator may not know but should have known is that the High Court of Australia has previously held such provisions to be invalid. I presume the reference there is to the case of the Commonwealth and New South Wales, decided in 1923 and reported in volume 33 of the Commonwealth Law Reports at page 1, wherein there was a four to one majority holding that section 20, as it then was, of the Lands Acquisition Act 1920, drafted in similar terms to this, as beyond Commonwealth power. It was not the acquisition itself that was rubbed out by that particular decision but simply the mandatory requirement that it be registerd by the State property officer. That case has not been much cited subsequently and it may well be that the High Court would now take a different view as to how the law in question in that case should be resolved, especially in the light of the quite powerfully argued dissenting judgment from Mr Justice Higgins, which made clear, among other things, that the point was not really very fully argued.

Another point to make about that is that the case was decided in the immediate aftermath of the famous engineers case, and the question as to the possible reach of Commonwealth power into State areas was perhaps less settled then than it is today. In any event, even if this particular clause was struck down by the application of the case that the Minister has referred to, we do not see that that is in fact fatal to the basic scheme of the Act to the extent that the acquisitions and purchase of land for and on behalf of the trusts in question could certainly survive.
The next point related to clause 40 of the Bill, in respect of which the Minister said:
Clause 40 would preclude a State officer-for example, a policeman-who was acting in the performance of his duty from entering upon land vested in a land trust without the consent of the trust.

We simply do not accept that interpretation of that particular clause as having that effect. Might I draw the Minister's attention in particular to sub-clause 1 of that clause which uses the expression 'or otherwise in accordance with this Act', which I think, when he reads carefully what we have in mind and have already referred to so far as clauses 14 and 43 are concerned, he would acknowledge is a legal environment in which such entries could in fact be made. But we do acknowledge that the clause and the right in question could perhaps be a little clearer. We have accordingly in fact proposed an amendment to clause 40 in the Committee stage. For the record I simply indicate that that amendment would read, by way of an insertion after the word 'Act' in clause 40 (1), 'or by a law which by virtue of section 43 applies to Aboriginal land'. That should clarify the matter beyond doubt, but we see that particular amendment as being an abundance of caution.
The next matter referred to-it appears in Hansard at the bottom of page 770 and goes over to page 771-is the claim by the Minister in the following terms:
The Bill makes no alternative provision for the preservation of law and order on land held by a trust.

As to that, we say yet again that this overlooks the effect of clause 43 which will allow the Queensland laws of general application to continue, for better or worse, to actually operate. If the Minister is really making a different point than that, if he is claiming that there is no legal framework for the continued self-management by law-making power, and so on, to operate in the hands of councils, this is a point that I will address again in another context in a moment. The Minister then quoted a provision from a report of the Senate Standing Committee on Constitutional and Legal Affairs. He said that we on the Committee did 'not consider that a single general statute . . . provides the best means' of achieving Aboriginal self-management of reserves.

TALK.START.PARA: —In advance of knowing what specific situation you will have to deal with. That is the point.

—The answer to that point, having stated and understood the problem, is simply that our Bill does allow for a flexibility of response as to the kind of self-management in the first place, and, secondly, the kind of proprietary interest in the context of land rights that is appropriate to the needs and demands and interests of each particular community. The other point to make, I suppose, is that the Senate Committee report was brought down in the context not as a general attack on Aboriginal reserve status being then contemplated but rather a question of maximising the opportunities of Aboriginal communities to get self-management status on a case by case basis in particular reserve situations. That was the context of that report. All that was being done there was to identify the kind of options and possibilities that were available in respect of each group of Aboriginals around Queensland, in respect of each community in which they happened then to reside, with a differing situation so far as mineral right demands and so on.

SPEECH.PARA: Here we are confronting a situation-this is the nub of the point that I want to make-of a generalised across-the-board attack on the status, simultaneously, of all the reserves in Queensland. For that reason it is necessary to produce at the moment a statutory solution which will in fact anticipate that attack and make provision for its force and effect being overcome, again on a case by case basis. It ought not to be misunderstood that what is being provided for here is again simply a framework piece of legislation which will, at the threshold, enable different kinds of self-management solutions to be created for each community. Then, when each such community wants to proceed beyond the self-management situation into a land rights proprietary possession situation through a land trust, this Bill allows for the creation of such a trust, again on a case by case basis. This is something we obviously need to argue about in more detail in the Committee stage. This is not the occasion to pursue it. But it seems to me that the general thrust of the Minister's objection is a little misconceived.

The next point argued out is in respect of clause 42. It is said that there is in effect an inconsistency between the self-management provisions of the Bill on the one hand and the lands acquisition provisions on the other which makes the operation of this Bill in practice unworkable because, it is argued, clause 42 operates in such a way as to mean that Part I, the self-management Part of our Bill, ceases to apply when the land in question ceases to be a reserve. Again, I try to keep the answer short. We do not agree that there are inconsistencies between the two Parts of the Bill in the way that has been suggested. There is a rational interrelationship between the different parts of the Bill and there does not seem to be any necessary reason why the continuation of the council or councils and the self-management powers associated with their operation could not be maintained.

However, we acknowledge that it is probably desirable to make explicit provision for this transition from self-management status of a Commonwealth acquired reserve on the one hand to the self-management of land held in trust by a land trust on the other. It seems to us desirable to make that explicit and to make precise provision in enabling form for a continuation of the self-management framework. That is the point of the proposed new clause 28A which we will be seeking to move at the Committee stage and which I have made available to the Minister.

TALK.START.PARA: —But not to the Senate.

—No, I am sorry. I am just building this into a second reading speech at this stage. I am not asking anyone to vote on the detail of the proposed new clause. I seek leave for the incorporation of draft clause 28A in Hansard.

SPEECH.PARA: Leave granted.
The document read as follows-
''Self-Management of Aboriginal Land
28A (1) Where a Land Trust has been established in respect of an area of land, the Governor-General may make regulations in accordance with this section.
(2) The regulations may provide that:
(a) a Council established under Part I in respect of an area of land held under Part II by a Land Trust;
(b) an Aboriginal Council;
(c) an Incorporated Aboriginal Association;
(d) a Land Trust; or
(e) a body established by the regulations constituted by Aboriginals who are traditional Aboriginal owners and are elected by the traditional Aboriginal owners;
shall be responsible for the management and control of the affairs of the Aboriginals for whose benefit a Land Trust is established under sub-section 22(1).
(3) Regulations made under this section shall provide for-
(a) the services to be provided or made available, or arranged to be provided or made available by a body specified in sub-section (2);
(b) the functions of a body specified in sub-section (2), being functions in relation to Aboriginals and Islanders for whose benefit a Land Trust is established under sub-section 22(1);
(c) powers in respect of the making of by-laws by a body specified in sub-section (2) in respect of its functions.

(4) Sub-section 48 (4), (5), (5A), and (6) of the Acts Interpretation Act 1901 apply to and in relation to by-laws made under regulations made in accordance with this section as if references to in those sub-sections to regulations were references to such by-laws.

(5) Until the making of regulations under this section, Part I applies to Aboriginal land as if such Aboriginal land were an Aboriginal or Islander Reserve and any Council established under Part I shall continue in existence with the powers specified in Part I until the regulations otherwise provide.

(6) The Executive Council shall not offer advice to the Governor-General with respect to the making of regulations under this section unless the Minister has certified that the traditional Aboriginal owners understand the nature and purpose of the proposed regulations and as a group consent to the proposed regulations.''

TALK.START.PARA: —At the bottom of page 770 and running on to the top of page 771 the Minister referred to the just terms provision of the Constitution which, of course, govern any acquisition and proprietary interests and simply asked: 'Where is the money coming from to pay for land so acquired?' Of course it is true that compensation is payable ultimately by someone. It is in the nature of any land rights exercise of this kind. I took it the Minister was not so much making a technical objection to the operation of the Bill but rather a more political one. Might I remind him again that that after all was intended to be the utility and value of the Senate Committee report to which I referred, insofar as it pointed out that acquisition situations are not all or nothing situations; that there are different gradations of proprietary interest that can be purchased, ranging from a licence or lease situation at one end of the scale through to a complete freehold interest, with the full range of mineral rights, I suppose, at the other end of the scale. The amount that will be payable on acquisition-this is a potentially much lengthier discussion but I will keep it to just another sentence-will depend upon the nature of the proprietary interest that is in fact acquired.

SPEECH.PARA: There will be a cost ultimately to the nation somewhere along the line of this exercise. It is even conceivable that there could be a cost right at the threshold with the Part I self-management Part of the Bill, to the extent that a court might be moved to construe the Part I clauses as in themselves amounting, as they do, merely to a granting of self-management status but nonetheless amounting to a acquisition of some of proprietary interest and diverting that proprietary interest away from the Queensland Government, where it presently resides. I acknowledge that it is possible, although I think unlikely, that it could be construed as meaning that a licence type of proprietary interest had been acquired, in which case it would demand that some kind of compensation be paid to Queensland as a result.

I think to dress that up as a significant objection to the Bill really rather misses the basic point of what this Bill is all about and what I have taken the Minister, in his more enlightened moments, to acknowledge the Bill to be about. It is not a question of worrying here about the bill that is ultimately to be payable by someone, but really it is a matter of ensuring essentially that justice is done to those who so manifestly deserve it. Of course the compensation amounts that are ultimately to be payable cannot simply be dismissed as mere bagatelle or something that is not relevant at all to the basic consideration of this Bill, but they must be kept in their proper perspective and it cannot possibly count as a knock-out blow at the second reading stage against this Bill, that there is an uncertainty about what precise degree of compensation is to be paid at the various stages of operation of this kind of legislation.

I believe that that deals as systematically and as completely as is possible in any reasonable time with the points raised by the Minister. But there is one other point that has been raised, certainly outside the chamber, with me by Senator Missen which I do not think has been covered by any of the points I have mentioned. That is the question of the resolution of conflicts in the operation of the land trusts, especially with the councils continuing, as they may well do-in fact are likely to do-to exercise self-management functions. It is possible that the councils and the trusts will be constituted by different people with technically different powers, but nonetheless operating in an area where there is a possibility of conflict arising. We accept that the existing clause 32, as it is drafted, which is intended to deal with the conciliation of disputes, may not have a sufficiently wide reaching operation to deal with the kinds of disputes which I have understood Senator Missen to have in mind. So may I again simply foreshadow at this stage the intention of Senator Ryan to move in the Committee stage a new clause 32, the terms of which I seek leave to incorporate in Hansard.
Leave granted.
The document read as follows-
''32 (1) The Minister may appoint persons to act as Commissioners in accordance with this section.
(2) Disputes Commissioners shall be persons familiar with Aboriginal or Islander tradition.

(3) Before the appointment of any person to act as a Disputes Commissioner, the Minister shall consult as widely as possible with those bodies or groups who may be affected by decisions of the Disputes Commissioner.
(4) The terms of appointment of a Disputes Commissioner shall specify the Land Trust or Land Trusts in respect of which the Disputes Commissioner has jurisdiction.
(5) The terms and conditions upon which Disputes Commissioners hold office shall be determined by the Minister.

TALK.START.PARA: —I have aimed to demonstrate-inevitably, I fear, in a very technical way, but that is the nature of the exercise-that the Bill is a credible exercise technically. It is not full of the kind of holes that, as I have said, the Minister and his hastily assembled team of deparmental lawyers have sought to find through it. I am not suggesting that the drafting and enactment of this kind of legislation is a simple exercise. Nor, of course, am I suggesting-and I have taken pains to make this clear in everything I have said-that the Bill is incapable of further improvement at the Committee stage. Indeed, I have foreshadowed a number of improvements which we will be seeking to make. There are at least another 20-odd smaller amendments which are presently in an advanced stage of drafting but which do not really go to significant questions of principle but certainly improve the drafting in a number of ways. The real point I have been endeavouring to get across on behalf of the Opposition is that the Bill is in a condition in which it can and it should be guaranteed a second reading by this chamber. To give this Bill any less than a second reading tonight, in the circumstances of crisis-it is no less than that-that we are facing in Queensland, would be to abdicate all the responsiblity which we, as Australians, share for the 200 years of humiliation, annihilation, neglect and contempt with which our Aboriginal brothers and sisters, the first and the rightful inhabitants of this land, have so unfairly borne.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Missen Sen A.J.

TALK.START.PARA: —Tonight we are discussing a very important Bill and a very important proposed initiative for the Senate and for the Parliament of this country. This Bill, the Queensland Aboriginals and Torres Strait Islanders (Self-Management and Land Rights) Bill 1981, is an initiative for which I pay tribute to Senator Ryan and Senator Evans for the careful way in which they have explained their views. The speech which Senator Ryan has made, I think, sets out a great deal of the grievous treatment which the Aboriginal people of this country have received over a long period and the claims which they have on this Parliament for better treatment and for some recognition of the justice of their claims, in particular claims for land rights. I believe that we in this Parliament have made some attempts in the past, by legislation, which have not been very successful. We must ensure that any attempts we make now are more successful and that we are not met by the ingenuity which has been seen in past occasions to have frustrated the will of the Australian people expressed through the Australian Parliament.

SPEECH.PARA: I desire in the speech I make tonight, and through an amendment which I will move in the course of this speech, to maintain three particular points. I refer, first, to the need for stronger Commonwealth action and make an analysis of what demands are made on the community for action, and the way in which we ought to proceed. Secondly, we must consider the strategy of the Bill proposed, it being a private member's Bill. We must consider very carefully the way in which it is handled, taking into account the way in which people who are hostile to the purposes of that Bill may well be able to use it to advantage if we travel in an overzealous but careless direction. Thirdly, I will talk about the weaknesses or defective aspects of the Bill, some of which have been referred to by Senator Evans and some of which have not. If the Bill is to proceed these aspects must be considered very carefully and repaired before we embark on what is a very vigorous and difficult fight with a State government.

As I have said, this is a Bill which sets out-the second reading speech does also-much about the obligations we have to the Australian Aboriginal people. What is claimed by the people who are residents on the reserves in Queensland, bearing in mind that those reserves are threatened with termination, is something like 2 per cent or slightly less of the land surface of Queensland. One must recognise that, in economic terms, that land is among the poorer and more distant land; it is not the most valuable in an economic sense but very often is land where Aboriginal people did not originally live. But different clans and tribes have been moved onto reserves and they have developed a particularly strong attachment, which Aboriginal people have always had for land, to this land which they fear might be taken from their control. It is very important that we bear in mind that it is only a small percentage of the land of Queensland that is under question.

I believe four salient actions or facts ought to be mentioned at the beginning, as we consider the need for our taking action. They are actions which involve the Senate, and which have involved it over the last few years, and we ought to remind ourselves of them. In the first place I want to remind the country that we now have unquestioned constitutional power in the Commonwealth Parliament to take action. After all, section 51 (xxvi) of the Constitution says that we may make laws for the good order of the people of Australia in respect of the people of 'any race, for whom it is deemed necessary to make special laws'. What was once an exclusion-the words 'other than the Aboriginal race in any State'-was removed overwhelmingly by vote of the people of this country in 1967. I think it is clear-this is the view of the Senate committee which considered this matter-that unquestionably the Commonwealth has very strong powers to make those special laws that it may deem necessary. That, of course, includes powers in respect of the Aboriginal race and the Torres Strait islanders who are the subject of this Bill.

The second salient fact I want to refer to is the resolution which the Senate adopted in 1975 on the motion of Senator Bonner. I was a member of this chamber on that occasion and one of the people who voted for and accepted that resolution. The resolution was adopted without dissent in the Senate on 20 February 1975, and reads as follows:

That the Senate accepts the fact that the indigenous people of Australia, now known as Aborigines and Torres Strait Islanders, were in possession of this entire nation prior to the 1788 First Fleet landing at Botany Bay, urges the Australian Government to admit prior ownership by the said indigenous people, and introduce legislation to compensate the people now known as Aborigines and Torres Strait Islanders for dispossession of their land.

The terms of that resolution, of course, go further than this question of land rights. It was a resolution carried by the Senate, I believe sincerely, and those of us who voted for it meant it to be not merely a matter of words addressed kindly to the Aboriginal and Torres Strait Islander people but to mean something significant and in due course to be introduced into legislation.

TALK.START.PARA: —Those in Opposition now were in Government then and they buried it at the other end of the ship.

—It was carried only in this chamber. But it was carried by the Senate, and the Senate ought to take initiatives in regard to it. One of the things we ought to do in acknowledging land rights in Queensland surely is to accept this principle as the first essential, thus showing that we are prepared to take some action, to take some stand, to incur some wrath in certain parts of Australia and to fight to ensure that their rights in those areas are protected. That, I think, is an important thing so far as the obligations of this Senate are concerned.

SPEECH.PARA: The third matter arose from the fact that in 1978, the Queensland Government proceeded to abolish the reserves at Aurukun and Mornington Island, we endeavoured by legislation, which one might describe as the self-management Act of that year, to protect those rights. We know that because of the action of the Queensland Government in abolishing the reserves after the legislation went through that legislation was vitiated at that time. Consequently, the decisions of the Parliament then were ineffective. This matter was referred to the Senate Standing Committee on Constitutional and Legal Affairs, of which I was Chairman. The report of that Committee has been quite heavily relied on in the preparation of this Bill and in the matters which Senator Ryan has raised in her second reading speech. I intend to read two extracts from the Committee's report. In addition, the Committee's report does indicate the very strong power the Commonwealth has not only to acquire land but also to acquire lesser interests in land and to take very many other steps that are necessary for the Australian Aboriginal people. In its responses to that report the Government has never challenged in any way the views which the Committee then expressed about the strong power of the Commonwealth in this area. I quote firstly from paragraph 46 of the report. The Committee stated:

The Committee notes the claim made in the submission of the Department of Aboriginal Affairs (Annexure E, at p. 3) that 'since the passage of the legislation led the Queensland Government to legislate for local community self-management under Queensland local government legislation and to grant leasehold title to the Aurukun and Mornington Island communities, it can be argued that the Commonwealth legislation has been most effective'. The Committee cannot agree with this proposition. It seems clear to the Committee that the Commonwealth Act, being incapable of application to Aboriginals at Aurukun and Mornington Island, must be regarded as totally ineffective in dealing with their plight. That the Queensland Parliament may have chosen to confer on the face of it somewhat wider powers of self-management upon Aboriginals at Aurukun and Mornington Island than they enjoyed under the previously applicable Queensland Acts is no more than a fortuitous beneficial side result of the Commonwealth legislation.

So we have to recognise that the Commonwealth legislation dealing with those two particular areas and communities was not successful. I read further from the conclusions of the Committee report. The Committee was referring primarily to Aurukun and Mornington Island, but not entirely; the Committee report ranged much wider. Paragraph 74 of the report states:

The Committee accordingly bases its recommendations regarding Aboriginals and the Torres Strait Islanders in Queensland on the assumption that co-operation between the Commonwealth and Queensland is not necessary to provide a full and sufficient discharge of Commonwealth obligations to Aboriginals and Torres Strait Islanders in Queensland and that some unilateral action by the Commonwealth will therefore be likely to be necessary.

I believe that the facts of the last three years, despite the long and I think genuine negotiations by the Commonwealth Government in endeavouring to obtain better treatment for the Aborigines of Queensland, have proved that there will be a necessity for Commonwealth action. In the fourth of these aspects, I refer to the fact that on 5 April 1979, when that report of the Senate committee was debated and when a resolution was adopted which noted the various actions that the Commonwealth had taken in its negotiations, it was stated in clause (b) of the resolution, as recorded on page 1415 of Hansard of 5 April:

In the event of such agreement, legislative action and negotiations failing to provide satisfactory means for self-management the Senate requests the Commonwealth Government to give urgent consideration to (and advise the Parliament of its intentions in regard to) the amendment of the existing Commonwealth legislation or the introduction of new legislation to ensure effective self-management for the Aurukun and Mornington Island Aboriginal communities, and other Aboriginal communities-
I stress the words 'and other Aboriginal communities'-
pursuant to the substantial powers of the Commonwealth as examined in the Senate Committee's Report.

So indeed it was very much in the mind of the Senate at that time that it may well have to take action to look after the interests of other Aboriginal communities which are now under some challenge. Those are salient actions involving the Senate and they lead us on to consider what we should do now.

I will say something about the slow negotiations and the threatened security which are facing Aboriginal communities in Queensland. In the course of the last three years the Commonwealth has been negotiating-I think not without great difficulty-with the Queensland Government. As expressed by Senator Baume in his speech last week, the Commonwealth has been working sincerely in accordance with the four principles that he mentioned. They are:

That the integrity of the present reserve boundaries should be maintained; that there should be secure tenure for the occupants and preservation of their usufructionary rights, their rights to use the land; that local communities should play a significant role in the management of the reserves; and there should be full consultation with Aboriginal and Torres Strait Islander people before any decisions are made.

I believe those principles are sound ones. Unfortunately they are under some challenge at present. We know that the Queensland Government has threatened, both in the election campaign last year and since, to abolish the reserves and has left the future of the people who live on those reserves at least in a state of great uncertainty. The Commonwealth in its negotiations of course has been conscious of the fact that if it applies the rights which it has to acquire the land then of course there will be further difficulties. We know the situation could arise in which a Queensland government not prepared to recognise facts could well take the view: 'Right, these are your islands. These are your Bantustans. You will have to provide all the services for these areas. We will no longer provide all those services that are normally applicable to all ordinary citizens of Queensland'. We know that a fight may occur. We know the Commonwealth has endeavoured to reach an agreement which does not lead to a situation where it would have to maintain all the services for these people if the Queensland Government were to react in such a way.

The Queensland Government has at times proposed 50-year leases. Frankly, I do not think they are a satisfactory answer for a people who have a deep and abiding feeling for the land and on whom the land has such an influence. To tell them they have rights to land for 50 years, 75 years or even 100 years is insulting in view of the demands which they make and the influence of the land on them. We would have to expect more than that. We have not seen that yet from the State of Queensland. We have heard the examples already-I will not repeat them; Senator Evans spoke of this matter-of areas where Queensland has denied Aboriginals the right to ownership and has denied them leases. The Archer River area is an example of that. The Aboriginal people have been denied the lease of land.

Recently the World Council of Churches presented a report after investigation here. One can be critical of some aspects of that report. Of course there have been criticisms of the people who were involved in its preparation and the extent to which they were able to see what was happening, but I believe it is a substantial report. I would have been happier with it if it had recognised that there is also racial discrimination between black and black in the world, and people of other colours, rather than distinguishing only between black and white. I think there are many salient facts set forward in the report. It states, amongst other things, that there are indeed areas in Queensland where Aborigines have been denied the right to obtain land. The cause of uncertainty which arises as far as the Queensland people are concerned is to be found in the statements made by people such as Mr Bjelke-Petersen, the Premier of Queensland. In a statement on 4 September this year he said:

The radical Left's drive for so-called 'land rights', a misnomer if ever there was one, is just another variation of the old cargo-cult. All Queenslanders now have the right to buy, sell and own land and as such they already have 'land rights'. The process of obtaining land is the same for all, as it should be in a democratic society.

That is gobbledegook and untruth. We know that. The facts are there to show that for Aboriginal people there have been unjust denials of land and rights and that in fact this is not a demand just by people on the radical left. I suppose there are relative conservatives like Senator Bonner and me, religious people and those of other groups who believe that justice must be done to the Australian Aboriginal people and the situation not pushed away in that manner. Uncertainty is being caused by the forked tongue and differing statements of Queensland leaders. In the Age of 18 March this year is a report of what the Premier of Queensland said about his intention to repeal the two Acts covering Aboriginals and Islanders by the end of this year. He did not expect the State government to set up other systems. The report reads:

'We don't want them set aside in some country that becomes black man's country-we want them to live exactly like you do', Mr Bjelke-Petersen told the Press conference. 'We'll make them Queenslanders just like you and I-We won't pass any new law.'
The same day the Queensland Minister for Aboriginal Affairs, Mr Tomkins, said that he believed there would be new legislation to replace the old. A report of his remarks reads:
'I don't think it will be repealed and nothing put in its place,' Mr Tomkins said last night.

Whatever one might say about these things and whatever one believes as to who will win out in such a battle, there is every ground for thinking there is uncertainty on the part of the Queensland Aboriginals, an uncertainty which this Parliament must do its best to resolve.

I now turn to the last of the four points that I previously mentioned. What about the public demand for justice? Is this a matter in which only Queenslanders are interested or are other people interested? I have referred to the report of the World Council of Churches. It pointed out the demands made and what it believes should be done in this case. But to me and to many members of this Parliament, have come demands for immediate action from all different sections of life. I refer in particular to two organisations. One is the Catholic Commission for Justice and Peace. In a letter to me on 21 August 1981 it set out a four-point policy in relation to the Queensland situation as follows:

1. The Queensland Government should consult fully with the Aboriginal and Islander people of Queensland before repealing the Acts. The public service must have ample opportunity to discuss proposed changes.

2. The Queensland Government should vest Aboriginal and Islander reserve lands and lands in the Shires of Aurukun and Mornington Island in a form of direct Aboriginal ownership considered suitable by Aboriginal and Islander people.

3. The Queensland Government should enact legislation to give Aboriginal and Islander people the right to veto mining and other developments on their land: any overriding of that veto should be contingent upon judicial inquiry.

4. In the event of the Queensland Government failing to grant land rights to Aboriginal and Islander communities the Commonwealth should exercise its constitutional powers and provide these rights by Commonwealth legislation.

Honourable senators will note that the action is proposed in the event of the Queensland Government failing itself to act. So far the Queensland Government has failed. The amendment that I propose to move tonight, with the support of Senator Bonner, is designed to ensure that there is no doubt that the Queensland Government has made up its mind; that we know where it stands; that no longer can it be said that that Government has been taken by surprise, that it did not have the opportunity to complete its investigations.
The Uniting Church, at its 2nd Assembly held quite recently, resolved-I shall quote the major recommendation only-as follows:

1. recognise the injustice done to Aboriginal people through the dispossession of their lands, the importance of ties with their land for the maintenance by Aboriginals of their culture, and the economic importance of land; and affirm its support for Aboriginal groups seeking to obtain freehold title to traditional lands or land to be used for housing and economic support, and compensation for land which has been expropriated.

After dealing with other matters, including stating what the resolution was about, they went on to say what the church would do in respect of its own land-that is, pass some of it back to the Aboriginal people. That was expressed as follows:

In pursuance of this policy the Uniting Church is bound to support any political initiative which really seeks to honour the right and need of Aboriginal people for secure land tenure. Furthermore the Uniting Church would want to support positive political action to aid the Aboriginal people of Queensland.
It is our hope that the Federal Government would be more decisive and courageous in facing the issues raised. We do not believe its present actions have been effective.

Furthermore, there is a demand by the Aboriginal people themselves. It is important to recognise that the surveys taken in Queensland have indicated overwhelmingly that the Aboriginal people want land rights. The World Council of Churches referred in its report to the survey that was taken in 1978 of Aboriginal opinion in Queensland. This showed that the overwhelming majority of Aboriginals on reserves, 73.1 per cent, wanted the Commonwealth Government to replace the State government as the body responsible for making laws; that 85 per cent of Aboriginals on reserves wanted the ownership of the reserve land to be in their hands; that the survey revealed a widespread desire for self-determination. I believe that is even stronger today.

The National Campaign for Land Rights and Self-Management in Queensland on 10 July 1981 pointed out that the investigations in 1979 of the Foundation for Aboriginal and Islander Research Action had noted that 85.6 per cent of reserve residents wanted land ownership of reserves to be in the hands of Aboriginal and Islander residents of the reserves; that 78.1 per cent wanted the community councils to control all decision-making relating to housing on reserves; that 86.2 per cent wanted the councils to control access to reserves; and that 80.3 per cent wanted the councils to control mining, waterways and forest reserves. Perhaps even more significantly, the survey found that 69.1 per cent, almost 70 per cent, of Aboriginals and Islanders presently living in Queensland towns, stated that they would return to live on a reserve if it were controlled by the Aboriginal people. So there is also expressed a wish to change their place of living, if that can be done.

We are told that the Queensland Government is undertaking an investigation of what the Aboriginals on the reserve want and that it has not yet got all the results. I have not much doubt as to what that result will be. The results are in so far as the Torres Strait Islander Advisory Council is concerned. According to the figures shown in its report, those who wanted inalienable freehold numbered more than 1,000,-1,047; those who wanted freehold numbered 44; those who wanted perpetual leasehold numbered 10; and that one person wanted leasehold. In regard to control of Islander affairs, 721 wanted control by Islanders and four wanted control by government. One does not need much more than that to indicate their overwhelming desire. Despite all of the propaganda, the Aboriginal people clearly have made up their minds in this way. Thus, there is no doubt about the need and the demand.

I turn now to more difficult questions. Where do we go from here? What strategy should be employed? Should the Bill be passed by the Senate at this time? I believe that to pass it at this time would be a great mistake on the part of honourable senators; that we should give the Queensland Government a last chance.

TALK.START.PARA: —They have had 20 last chances already.

—The honourable senator's logic is infallible; he is quite right. In my opinion the Queensland Government has had far, far more opportunities than one could expect to be given. The answers should be there. But honourable senators know the way in which the Queensland Government has argued in the past; the way in which it will act as a sovereign state if it feels that it can put a case-one that it feels has not been given a hearing. The Queensland Government says that it has legislation coming along; that that legislation will be before Cabinet by about the middle of October. It states also that it is obtaining the views of the Aboriginal and Torres Strait Islander people. That survey apparently has not yet been completed. No stone must be left unturned to ensure that this is right. Also we must be sure that we pass a water-tight Bill, one which, if in fact the Queensland Government indicates that it will not act to meet the needs of the Aboriginal people, will be adequate. We must pass a Bill that does not let down the Aboriginal people again.

SPEECH.PARA: I do not believe there is any value in having some Bill passed on the eve of the Commonwealth Heads of Government Meeting. That argument has been raised by some people. In fact, Senator Ryan has written to me about the amendment that I am about to move, stating that it will delay the Bill until 29 October and that that is quite unacceptable as it undermines the potential effectiveness of the initiative. I say earnestly to her that I do not believe that is right. In fact, it will make water-tight the initiative which is being undertaken. Certainly, if we do as Senator Bonner and I propose in this amendment, and delay the final decision on the second reading until 29 October, so far as I am concerned, if the Queensland Government has not by then come forward with genuine and sensible proposals which cover the needs and desires of the Aboriginal people, I will have no hesitation in voting for a Bill-which one would want to be sure was effective. I know that Senator Bonner is of the same view. I therefore move:
Leave out all words after 'That', insert
(1) the Bill be deferred to enable the Queensland Government to advise the Senate and the Australian people of the specific proposals of that Government on-
(a) its announced intention to repeal the Aboriginal and Torres Islander Acts and to amend the Queensland Lands Act in order to abolish Aboriginal reserves in Queensland;

(b) what consultative processes it has undertaken and completed to ascertain the desires of the Queensland Aboriginal and Torres Strait Islanders, who presently reside on reserve lands, for land rights and self-management of their own communities;

(c) the alternative legislative and/or administrative steps it now proposes to take, in accordance with the expressed wishes of the local communities, to provide Aboriginals and Torres Strait Islanders with land rights or other effective security of tenure of lands now constituting the reserves and of other traditional lands to which they have proper claims;
(d) what legislative and/or administrative steps it proposes to take to provide effective self-management for Aboriginal and Torres Strait Islander communities in Queensland; and
(e) the date or dates on which such legislative and/or administrative action will be completed, and

(2) if no such advice has been received by the Senate by 29 October 1981, the Bill be restored to the Notice Paper, and the second reading be an Order of the Day for the first sitting day after 29 October 1981, and that such Order of the Day take precedence of all other business on the Notice Paper for that day.''.

TALK.START.PARA: —I have great pleasure in seconding the amendment and I reserve my right to speak at a later stage.

—We are proposing to defer the vote on the second reading. In the meantime we ascertain the Queensland Government's intentions, or give it every opportunity to indicate them, in regard to the repealing of the reserves; ascertain the consultative processes it has followed with the Aboriginal people; and ascertain the desires of the Aboriginal people so far as living on reserves is concerned and in respect of land rights and self-management of their community. We would ascertain also the legislative and administrative alternatives or steps that the Queensland Government will take to carry out its proposals in regard to both land rights and self-management, and when this is to be done. If we are not satisfied in that regard we propose that the Bill should be brought back and, before the rising of the Senate at the end of the session, be dealt with.

SPEECH.PARA: One question was raised in the drafting stage with the Clerks to which we could not get a satisfactory solution. I refer to the two situations that may arise if in fact the Senate were to rise before the time specified. We would have some days notice of that. In that event we would have to take steps to ensure that the Bill was brought on for debate earlier than 29 October.

TALK.START.PARA: —We would facilitate that, I think.

—Yes, the Government would facilitate it. The alternative is that the Queensland Government might take precipitate action. It might abolish the reserves and create national parks. I do not intend to put suggestions into the minds of members of the Queensland Government. If any of those steps were to be taken Senator Bonner and I would be prepared to give the undertaking which I now read into the record. Senator Bonner and I have chosen in our amendment the date of 29 October 1981 for receiving advice from the Queensland Government of its legislative and administrative intentions in relation to Aboriginal reserves, land and self-management. From information we have received we believe that that gives more than ample time for the Queensland Government to make its intentions clear. Suggestions have been made but not confirmed that this Parliament may complete its session before that date. We agree with Opposition senators that the vote on this Bill in the Senate should be completed this session. However, we are advised by the Clerks that it is not appropriate to insert an alternate date in an amendment but that our end can be achieved by a vote of the Senate and by undertakings of procedural support. Consequently, Senator Bonner and I assure the Senate that, in the event of a proposed closure of the session before 29 October, or in the event of earlier action being taken by the Queensland Government that might prejudice Aboriginal rights under this Bill, we will support any procedural steps that might be necessary to bring on the Bill for a vote before the closure of the session.
—Do you know that the Premier has advised this Government to close down before that date?

—I am not terribly worried about the Premier's advice; I do not take advice from the Premier and I do not think that the Government does either. Anyone who knows of the integrity of Senator Bonner and me will know that we will not resile from that undertaking. We will not see this Parliament hoodwinked by any action of the Queensland Government. Therefore, in my opinion it would be a fatal mistake if we were to pass this Bill now. As I will point out in a moment, this Bill has defects which need to be cured. If it is to go ahead it must go ahead with those defects cured. I and, I believe, Senator Bonner also, would not vote in favour of this Bill and pass it tonight. That would be a fatal mistake by the Senate. The Bill must neither pre-empt what the Queensland Government may do, nor must it fail in its intention. I urgently appeal to members of the Senate, including members of the Australian Democrats who are present, who I believe are sincerely concerned about this problem, to ensure that we do not falter or make a mistake in relation to timing. Another reason why this Bill should not and could not pass at this stage is that amendments to it have been tabled tonight. We have not seen those amendments. I do not criticise Senator Evans in any way for that. But we do want to see those amendments and to see the defects.
—We do not have to have the Committee stage tonight.

—There is a Committee stage, certainly. But work has to be done. I would like to see work done also by the Parliamentary Counsel. Senator Bonner and I would want their assistance to ensure that some of the faults I have mentioned are cured. Senator Evans said that it is not an insuperable task to prepare those things. I agree; it is not an insuperable task, but there are tasks to be performed. This Bill has been put together in a patchwork quilt way. By that I mean that the Aboriginal Land Rights (Northern Territory) Act 1976 has been used, clause by clause, in many respects in this Bill.
—Half the Bill.

—Roughly half the Bill is that 1976 Act. It is a Bill prepared by a committee. The other half of the Bill is the Aboriginal and Torres Strait Islanders (Queensland Reserves and Communities Self-Management) Act 1978, with some improvements. But unfortunately they do not sit together terribly well. Senator Evans has mentioned only some of the problems in the Bill. For example, let us look briefly at clause 8 (1) of the Bill, that very interesting provision which states:

SPEECH.PARA: The Council for an Aboriginal Reserve to which this Act applies, or for an Islander Reserve to which this Act applies, shall be responsible to, and only to, the Aboriginal community or the Islander community, as the case may be, residing on the Reserve for the conduct, discipline and well-being of the members of the Aboriginal community or the Islander community, as the case may be.
