That is very much a take from the 1978 Act. But I think it probably is unwise to use it in this Bill. I think it is probably too wide. After all even in Queensland there are laws that relate to civil liberties. Such considerations are excluded from this Bill. In this Bill the council is given overwhelming power. Maybe that is intended. Maybe that is what we should have. But I think we should look carefully at that before we decide to exclude aspects of the ordinary common law and statute law of Queensland.

TALK.START.PARA: —They are not excluded.
—I am afraid they are excluded because that clause states that they shall be 'responsible to, and only to' the community--
—That is as far as internal management matters are concerned.

—In my opinion it goes too far and excludes ordinary law. We will have a situation in which someone in Queensland will object that this removes the ordinary laws. It will be said that this provision creates Bantustans or something--
—No.
—Senator Ryan knows that that will be said.
—But we can clarify that in the Committee stage. It is certainly not our intention--

—Everything I say can be clarified in the Committee stage, but work must be done on that aspect before we come to the Committee stage. One of the extraordinary things that Senator Evans said tonight was: 'It is all right because look at sub-clause (2) of clause 14 where it states ''this Parliament does not affect the application to a Reserve of a law of Queensland to the extent that that law is capable of operating concurrently with this Part''.' But that is not what it states. It turns it around. It does not say that sub-section (1) is subject to sub-section (2); it states:

SPEECH.PARA: Subject to sub-section (1) and (3), this Part does not affect the application to a Reserve of a law of Queensland to the extent that that law is capable of operating concurrently with this Part.
Clause 14 (1) takes out the law of Queensland. The second aspect of this is that clause 14 (1) states:

The Council for a Reserve to which this Act applies, or for a Community to which this Act applies, is not subject to control under a law of Queensland and, in particular, is not required to comply with any directions given to it under or by virtue of a law of Queensland.

It removes entirely the effect of the law of Queensland. When we come to laws operating concurrently, referred to in sub-clause (2), we see that they are subject to sub-section (1) and not the other way around. Maybe it is a mistake; maybe it is intended that it be the other way around. Unfortunately, as it stands, it contains a very clear exclusion of the common law. So there are two aspects: The councils are given overwhelming power and common law and statute law are excluded, which is not an effective way in which to operate.

There is another aspect to this. As I said, Part I gives the councils a very strong power to dictate and control communities. In Part II we find that land is placed in the control of trusts. Those trusts are given very strong administrative powers. Senator Evans has acknowledged that indeed there is a danger that the people running the council might be different from the people running the trust. In communities there are people of different tribes and different clans, and one group of people might be in control of the trust and another might be in control of the council. They might disagree on what is to be done. Each of them seems to be given power to control the land under this legislation. Nothing in the Bill really satisfactorily provides for conciliation between them or explains whose will will prevail. There is no provision for appeal. There may be desirably in those situations a right of appeal to the Administrative Appeals Tribunal with on it distinguished Aboriginal citizens who are not members of a particular reserve. That is a possibility. In the interests of the Aboriginal people of Queensland we must find solutions to this problem and not allow those sorts of difficulties to crop up without there being any power of appeal or any resolution of the problems involving the Constitution.

There are other questionable things in terms of the Bill. There are of course the functions relating to management and control. There are differences between those provisions and clause 44 which enables regulations to be made which might vary those functions. Senator Evans referred to clause 10-I merely very quickly refer to those matters-the by-laws power, the exclusion of disallowance which has gone out of the old Act, and I understand he has an amendment which is designed to cover this sort of thing and to overcome some of the constitutional doubt in this area. He has not mentioned clause 29 which deals with missions and land on which missions are located. That clause has some rather curious provisions in it because it provides that whereas a mission may have rights to continue in occupation, if it enters into a lease the land on which it is situated ceases to be land to which the clause applies. There is no right of appeal; there is no right of any further lease. I think that has to be looked at. I do not put it any higher than that. I think there is obscurity in that area.

Clause 36 of the Bill-the arbitration section of the Bill-includes amendments which were defeated in the Senate and the House of Representatives considered the 1976 Aboriginal Land Rights (Northern Territory) Bill. These amendments did not go into that Bill but they have been put into this one. I merely said that we ought to look at them to ascertain whether the Senate was right in rejecting them in 1976 and whether they should be altered and inserted in this Bill. I do not think I need to go any further into those things. I do not want to be nit-picking about this but I do not believe anything that I have referred to is not, with proper advice, capable of being repaired so that the Bill will be successful.

I believe we have to get this Bill right if we have to have this Bill. If we have to have the Bill we will be taking on an enormous fight with the Queensland Government. There is no doubt that that Government will endeavour to thwart the will of the Parliament. The people who we must ensure do not suffer again from any mistakes that we may make are the Queensland Aboriginals and the Torres Strait Islanders. It is for those reasons that Senator Bonner and I have proposed this amendment, and we sincerely hope the Senate will support it. We think the Bill ought to be put aside. The Queensland Government is well aware of the threat of what the Senate is likely to do if it does not in fact come up with proper provisions in the month provided. The Queensland Government will have more than enough time to provide reasons for its decisions and to tell us what it intends to do in accordance with the wishes of the Aboriginal and Torres Strait Island people. I therefore urge support for the amendment and I hope that we do not have to go to the next situation of having to vote on the second reading motion at this stage.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Keeffe Sen J.B.

TALK.START.PARA: —I do not want to speak for quite as long as Senator Missen did. His speech rather amazed me, as a matter of fact. I cannot quite understand how he has got this deep and abiding faith in the Queensland Government because it does not keep promises in any area. I want to say that Australia, and the Aboriginal people of Australia, are on the side of Senator Ryan and the Labor Party in producing this private member's Bill. It is true, as Senator Missen has said, that there might be certain technical weaknesses in the Bill but they can be improved in the Committee stage by appropriate amendments. If there are still weaknesses in it after that there is no reason why this Parliament cannot improve them with further amendments at a later date. The Bill itself has been drafted in circumstances quite different from those in which the original 1975 Aboriginal Land Rights (Northern Territory) Bill was drafted and the 1976 Bill which was enacted to deal with land rights in that part of Australia. Queenslanders are in a unique situation because of the type of government that we have and the type of people who run that government who in fact are not favourable to Aboriginals anyway.

SPEECH.PARA: I want to make my contribution to this debate as short as possible because I agree with Senator Missen when he said that it is a very important Bill. I hope we can deal with the major part of it tonight. I want to quote from a Press statement issued by Senator Susan Ryan on 18 September 1981. I will quote only one paragraph which reads:

Federal Opposition spokesperson on Aboriginal Affairs, Senator Susan Ryan has warmly welcomed today's unanimous decision by the High Court recognising a special interest of the Victorian Aboriginal tribe which sought to prevent the clearing of land at Portland by the Alcoa company.

I repeat that 80 per cent of the population of this country supported the 1967 referendum which gave to the Australian Government the right to take responsibility for Aboriginal affairs in this country. This has now been backed up-I will quote later from other authorities in this regard-by the High Court of Australia in its decision in relation to the Victorian tribe that wanted to preserve this area even though some of it has already been desecrated. I seek leave to incorporate in Hansard this document which I have already shown to you, Mr Acting Deputy President, and to the Minister for Aboriginal Affairs (Senator Peter Baume).
Leave granted.
The document read as follows-
BACKGROUND TO REVIEW OF ABORIGINAL LAND RIGHTS (NORTHERN TERRITORY) ACT 1976

1. Mr Justice Woodward was commissioned to inquire into Aboriginal land rights in the N.T. on 8 February 1973. He presented an interim report on 19 July 1973 and a second and final report on 3 May 1974. He emphasized that the 'Aboriginal people themselves must be fully consulted about all steps proposed to be taken' (par. 48). He foresaw the need for review of the arrangements between the Land Councils and the government after three years and thereafter at seven year intervals to ensure that anomolies are brought to light and that the system does not become rigid and unresponsive to changing needs. He emphasized the need for both flexibility and for the broad basis of arrangements to remain undisturbed. (par. 757-764).
2. In his speech on the second reading of the Aboriginal Land Rights Bill on 4 June 1976 Mr Viner Minister for Aboriginal Affairs said:

This Bill will give traditional Aborigines inalienable freehold title to land or reserves in the Northern Territory and provide machinery for them to obtain title to traditional land outside reserves. The coalition Parties' policy on Aboriginal affairs clearly acknowledges that affinity with the land is fundamental to Aborigines' sense of identity and recognises the right of Aborigines to obtain title to lands located within the reserves in the Northern Territory. The Bill gives effect to that policy and, further, will provide Aborigines in the Northern Territory with the opportunity to claim and receive title to traditional Aboriginal land outside reserves. The Government believes that this Bill will allow and encourage Aborigines in the Northern Territory to give full expression to the affinity with land that characterised their traditional society and gave a unique quality to their life.
The Minister's statement makes clear two fundamental policy intentions of the Government:
(i) the title would be inalienable freehold title, and
(ii) there would be an ongoing process enabling Aboriginals to obtain title to traditional land outside reserves.

Mr Viner emphasized this again later in his speech when he spoke of land claims to be heard by the Commissioner to Wave Hill, Willowra and Kildurk 'and the several other properties recently bought for Aboriginal communities by the Aboriginal Land Fund Commission or now being purchased by the Commission.'

3. Mr Viner emphasised these aspects of the Act again in articles published in the Northern Territory News in the latter half of 1978 and published by the Department of Aboriginal Affairs as a booklet. He said:

'Alienated land bought by the Aboriginal Land Fund Commission for Aboriginals, then being alienated to Aboriginals, can be subject to claim by Aboriginals on traditional grounds. If the claim is upheld, it takes on the status of traditional land and inalienable freehold title passes to the traditional owners.'
There can be no doubt that the intention of the Government was to allow traditional land claims to be made to pastoral lease properties owned by or on behalf of Aboriginals.

4. The Land Rights Act came into operation in January/February 1977. Deeds of grant for reserve lands were prepared, research for traditional land claims began, land claims began to be lodged, negotiations began with mining companies. The Aboriginal Land Rights (NT) Act has been extremely successful. Some justice has at last been done to Aboriginal people in the Northern Territory. Former reserves have become Aboriginal land. Traditional land claims have been heard. Some have been won, some lost. The hearing of claims is proceeding in the careful and orderly process envisaged by Mr Viner in his second reading speech. Agreements are being made with mining companies. Companies are expressing their satisfaction with the good relationships they are establishing with Land Council and are acknowledging Aboriginal interests and aspirations.

5. By the Northern Territory (Self Government) Act 1978, the Northern Territory became a self governing Territory and the interests of the Commonwealth in land vested in the Northern Territory from 1 July 1978.

Thereafter the Northern Territory Government began to complain about alleged problems with the operation of the Land Rights Act. It said that it was making these complaints on behalf of pastoral and mining interests.

6. On 24 August 1978 in a letter the NT Chief Minister Mr Everingham assured the Land Councils that it was 'not the intention of the Northern Territory Government to attempt to avoid the intentions of the provisions of the Aboriginal Land Rights (Northern Territory) Act.' He gave an undertaking on behalf of the Northern Territory Cabinet that 'for unalienated Crown land which is the subject of a claim before the Aboriginal Land Commissioner no action will be taken to process applications for development of that land for a period of two years, except for that land for which action in respect of the land claim has been completed by the Aboriginal Land Commissioner and the Minister for Aboriginal Affairs and which still remains unalienated Crown land. At the end of two years, processing of applications for utilisation of that land for developmental purposes will be considered by the Northern Territory Government in a way which should not be prejudicial to the future use of the land should the Aboriginal land claim be successful.'
This undertaking was restated by the Solicitor General in a letter to Mr Justice Toohey of 15 February 1979.

7. In September 1979 the Aboriginal Land Commissioner began hearing the land claim to Utopia Station owned by the Aboriginal Land Fund Commission. This was without doubt a land claim of the kind mentioned by Mr Viner and intended by the Land Rights Act. Despite this the NTG challenged the jurisdiction of the Commissioner to hear the claim. The Commissioner rejected the NTG argument. After a period of time in which Mr Everingham mounted a public campaign referring to Aboriginal run cattle stations as 'running sores' and 'harbours of disease', the NTG took the matter to the High Court. Again they were unsuccessful. (54ALTR145)

8. In response to the complaints the then Minister for Aboriginal Affairs Senator Chaney in November 1979 appointed Mr B. Rowlands Q.C. to examine the representations he had received regarding 'the practical implementation of the Land Rights Act'. Mr Rowlands terms of reference stated that 'this examination will be without detriment to the basic principles of the Act.'

9. Mr Rowlands made visits to the NT at the end of 1979 and held discussions with various bodies. He also received written submissions. The CLC forwarded a written submission on 5 May 1980. Sometime in 1980 the Land Councils received unofficially a submission to Mr Rowlands on behalf of the NTG. However it is understood that this document was not given to Mr Rowlands as Mr Everingham on 21 April 1980 advised 'that the NTG has decided it will not be making a submission to Mr Rowlands.' So, after complaining of problems with the Land Rights Act, and after preparing a written submission, the NTG chose not to subject its views to the scrutiny of the independant person appointed to examine any difficulties.

10. The report of Mr Rowlands Q.C. to the Minister for Aboriginal Affairs was made 11 August 1980. It examined a number of areas of alleged difficulty, assessed the nature of the problems, and suggested various possible solutions.

11. Mr Rowlands Report was not released by the Minister for Aboriginal Affairs until 18 November 1980. In February 1981 the NTG produced its views on the Land Rights Act in a written document in a submission to the Minister for Aboriginal Affairs. It raised a number of the same matters as the previous NTG document not submitted to Rowlands. The Northern Land Council and the Central Land Council each prepared submissions in response to the matters raised by the NTG.

12. Senator Baume convened a meeting of representatives of the Land Councils and of the NTG in Darwin on 17 March 1981. The meeting began at 9 a.m. and had finished by midday. There was general discussion of the positions of the NTG and that of the Land Councils. The Land Councils saw that the NTG was attempting to whittle away the Land Rights Act, to reduce its effectiveness and value. The meeting concluded with agreement for a working party to examine some of the issues, for written proposals to be exchanged, and for the meeting as a whole to reconvene in six weeks time.

13. The working party chaired by the N.T. Secretary of Mines met once on 7 April 1981. The Central Land Council met at Alice Springs 28 April 1981 and considered the NTG concerns. The CLC's issued a statement saying inter alia:
(i) that land claims over Aboriginal owned pastoral leases should continue;
(ii) that conservation parks should become Aboriginal land subject to management for park purposes;
(iii) that Aboriginal communities on cattle stations should be able to obtain land;
(iv) that mining on land under claim should not proceed without the consent of the traditional owners.

The meeting as a whole chaired by Senator Baume reconvened again on 11 May 1981. Again it was a half day meeting. Mr Everingham began the meeting by declaring that in view of the CLC statement there was no point in talking further. He remained and after some discussion of issues demanded a written statement of what the Land Councils would accept. The meeting adjourned and the Land Council representatives met and produced written proposals which were made available to NTGs representatives in the early evening. The meeting reconvened in the late morning for a short time on 12 May when Mr Everingham presented a written response to the proposals. The Land Council representatives made it clear at all times that they had no authority to act without the consent of the full Land Council. They agreed to take the proposals back to their respective Land Councils.

14. At the same time as the Land Councils were talking to Mr Everingham trying to reach agreement the Minister for Lands Mr Robertson was acting to alienate a substantial portion of the Lake Amedeus land claim by way of lease to two men who wanted it for camels for a tourist enterprise.

The claim had been lodged on 12 June 1980 and was within the period covered by Mr Everingham's undertaking. The CLC members were deeply angered by this breach of faith by the NTG including a promise by the Minister for Mines to alienate land in relation to which the Aboriginal Land Commissioner was hearing a claim. The CLC met 2-3 June 1981 and issued a further statement saying inter alia:
(i) that the Land Rights Act should be strengthened to prevent the alienation of land under claim,
(ii) that the NTG had acted in bad faith,
(iii) that a system for dealing with needs of Aboriginal groups on cattle stations should be established,
(iv) that the right to claim Aboriginal owned cattle stations and stock routes should be maintained.
15. On 10 June 1981 Mr Everingham wrote to the CLC Chairman calling off the meeting that had been arranged for 23 June. He threatened:
'If there is to be no shift in the stance taken by the Central Land Council you leave the Northern Territory Government with no alternative other than to pursue its own remedies in its own way.'

The Chairman of the CLC wrote to the Prime Minister on 17 June about NTG attempts to weaken the Land Rights Act. That letter was inserted as an advertisement in the National Times. On 25 June Mr Everingham wrote to Senator Baume asking for the meetings to be reconvened as soon as possible.

16. Following discussions with Mr Gray of DAA, where it was again made clear that the CLC had no interest in confrontation with the NTG and wished to find solutions to any real problems raised by the NTG, it was arranged for Mr Everingham to attend a full meeting of the Central Land Council on 12 August 1981. He attended with the Minister for Lands Mr Robertson.
The CLC Chairman raised at the outset the acts of bad faith by the NTG. In response:

Mr Everingham told the meeting he was 'sick to death of the Central Land Council'. Mr Everingham told the meeting that after seeing the National Times advertisement the NT Cabinet had decided to go its own way and make its own laws to achieve what it wanted.

Mr Robertson said that not only was a lease granted over part of the Lake Amadeus claim, but the balance had been advertised as being available for claim. He undertook to get the parties together to seek a compromise solution.
Mr Robertson said that Mr Everingham's promise not to deal with land under claim so as to prejudice the claim did not mean what it said.
Mr Everingham remained silent.

Senator Baume attended the meeting in the afternoon. He explained the matters concerning the NTG. Pressed by one Council member in particular as to which Government had the final power in relation to Aboriginal people Senator Baume said the Commonwealth Government but that it would not exercise its powers to disallow legislation of the NTG that weakened the operation of the Land Rights Act. At this meeting Land Council members gave much consideration to claims to Aboriginal owned cattle stations and clearly reaffirmed their commitment to converting leasehold interests to freehold title.

17. Representatives of the Land Councils met with Senator Baume and Mr Everingham on 13 August. Senator Baume began by stating that while the Governor-General had power to disallow NT laws he would not be advised to exercise it unless NT legislation was extremely offensive. CLC representatives stated that the CLC was committed to freehold title as that provided security of title and control over mining. Mr Everingham responded with a proposal for perpetual leases that could not be forfeited. He said this was the NTG's 'last word'. He again emphasised that the NT Cabinet had resolved 'to go its own way' and had prepared a legislative package 'tied up with a ribbon' which it would introduce the following week if the proposal was not accepted by the Land Councils.

18. On 24 August 1981 at a meeting attended by Senator Baume and staff the NLC resolved to accept the principles in the NTG proposal. On 25 August the CLC neither rejected nor accepted the proposals. Senator Baume also attended this meeting. A number of Aboriginal members of the Council spoke to him of how they had been forced off cattle stations and wished to pursue claims to small stock route and stock reserve areas on their traditional country. The CLC said that careful consideration should be given to the wording of the legislation proposed by the NTG and that it would be irresponsible to agree to the proposals without being completely clear what they mean. The CLC committed itself to make a concentrated effort to work on the principles and details of the proposals with senior personnel of the NTG to seek to reach an agreement. Mr Everingham said that the Land Councils approach was acceptable and agreed to the establishment of a working party.

19. The working party met 7, 8, 9 September 1981. The detail of the proposal to provide for community areas was discussed. The CLC submitted proposals that it considered met the NTG express concerns about conversion of Aboriginal owned cattle stations and claims on stock routes. Difficulty arose in relation to the perpetual lease proposal as the N.T. Solicitor-General explained the proposal to mean-
(i) An Aboriginal station owner would have the right to apply for a perpetual lease.
(ii) He would have to fulfil certain criteria e.g. be qualified by experience, have sufficient finance, have taken steps to eradicate TB and brucellosis.
(iii) Both the Land Board and the Minister would have a discretion as to whether the perpetual lease be granted.
(iv) While forfeiture as a sanction would be removed, substantial fines would be introduced, payment of which could be enforced by sale of the land.

It was agreed that the parties would take the issues raised back to their principals and meet again at the end of September. The Chairman of the NLC Jerry Blitner stated towards the close of the working party sessions that the NLC had only agreed to the NTG proposals because they had been threatened.

20. On 10 September 1981 Mr Everingham publicly attacked the CLC for claims on stock routes and stock reserves. The CLC pointed out that these claims were for small areas of Crown land which had not been used for many years, and which were the only areas of land available to be claimed by dispossessed Aboriginals. These areas have never been declared or proclaimed as stock routes. It also agreed to the land being subject to the rights to move stock. In a television interview on 11 September Mr Everingham stated that he wanted the negotiations to continue, but that he would alienate the stock routes to prevent the land claims going ahead.

21. In summary the review of the Land Rights Act has proceeded in an atmosphere of threat by the NTG and expressed reluctance by the Minister for Aboriginal Affairs to act to preserve the rights of Aboriginals under the Land Rights Act. The CLC is seeking:
(i) guaranteed preservation of the rights of Aboriginals under the Land Rights Act by non-alienation of land under claim;
(ii) a system to enable Aboriginals on cattle stations and Aboriginals entitled to be on cattle stations to obtain- title to areas of land for their community needs;

(iii) preservation of the right under the Land Rights Act to make a traditional land claim to land held by or on behalf of Aboriginals, subject to a system of lease back to the Aboriginal community for pastoral purposes;
(iv) preservation of the right to claim areas of Crown land once used as stock routes or stock reserves, subject to the rights of others to move travelling stock across the land;

(v) preservation of the right to claim Crown land which has been declared to be a national park under N.T. law, until agreed N.T. legislatiof whereby the land will become both Aboriginal land and national park subject to a management committee.
September, 1981

TALK.START.PARA: —I can understand why Senator Missen has adopted this attitude of postponement. I understand his sentiments. I know how he feels about land rights. I had the honour of sitting with him on a committee which dealt with the Aurukun and Mornington Island decisions and I know his sentiments. But I cannot quite understand why he wants to defer this legislation. I want to quote from a letter dated 21 September which I received from the chairman of the Central Land Council in the Northern Territory. It reads:

SPEECH.PARA: Dear Senator Keeffe, Thank you for your letter of interest and support concerning the proposed changes to the Aboriginal Land Rights (N.T.) Act 1976.

The Central Land Council has committed itself to negotiations with the Northern Territory Government to identify any problems with the Act and to find solutions to those problems acceptable to all parties. The Central Land Council has put proposals to the Northern Territory Government as to how its concerns can be met.

I am deeply concerned that these negotiations are taking place with the Northern Territory Government threatening 'to go its own way' and pass laws to destroy rights that have accrued to Aboriginals under the Land Rights Act, and the Commonwealth Minister for Aboriginal Affairs expressing his reluctance to act to ensure that the existing rights of Aboriginals are preserved.
I am enclosing for your information a summary of the discussions that have taken place.
Your faithfully,
Stanley Scrutton
Chairman
Central Land Council

My proposition is that the amendment that has been moved tonight by Senator Missen is part of the ongoing process of the Australian Government abdicating the promises that it made in 1975 and 1976. I have a summary of the discussions that have taken place, which summary was mentioned by the chairman of the Central Land Council. If any member on either side of the House wants a photostat copy of it I am prepared to supply it because this document represents a back-off from our obligations to the Northern Territory people. Let me cite one more attitude which I believe substantiates what I have just said. I shall quote again from a Press statement issued on 23 September 1981 by our spokesperson, Senator Ryan. It concerns the Noonkanbah film, which was not for overseas distribution. Paragraph 2 stated:
The Minister for Foreign Affairs has stated that the film will not be distributed to overseas posts, nor will it be for sale to overseas television stations.

What are we frightened of? This is a first-class film. We ought to be proud of it. Perhaps we ought to be ashamed to show it anywhere in the world. Perhaps that is what is wrong-the Government is frightened. We have a Prime Minister who struts world platforms saying, 'I am opposed to apartheid', yet in this country he encourages it. He encourages the separation of blacks and whites and he refuses to--

TALK.START.PARA: —Mr Acting Deputy President, I raise a point of order. I draw your attention to Standing Order 418. I believe that the honourable senator said that the Prime Minister encourages apartheid. That is not in accordance with the provisions of Standing Order 418 and I ask the honourable senator to withdraw it.
—I did not hear what Senator Keeffe said, but if that implication was there perhaps he could reframe his remarks.
—Having heard the words clearly, I ask that they be withdrawn. I believe that they are contrary to the Standing Order.

—I realise that Senator Baume is scared stiff of the Prime Minister. To protect him, I will withdraw the statement. Let me say that the Prime Minister is not doing the right thing by the Aborigines of this country. He tells one story to people overseas and suppresses Aborigines in this country. I hope that that statement is not unacceptable to the Minister; I think that, in his own heart, he believes it himself.

SPEECH.PARA: I now wish to refer to a number of points raised by Senator Missen. I do not know what his reason was for moving the amendment. Perhaps the Commonwealth Heads of Government Meeting has had a big influence on it. Nevertheless, I believe, and I think Senator Missen does too, that if the amendment is carried we will be flying in the face of the views of 80 per cent of the people of this country. If I were a member of the Government for the sake of political expediency, if for nothing else, I would not be prepared to do that. We are playing with the lives of 20,000 people in Queensland. Why should we postpone--

TALK.START.PARA: —That's what I am afraid of. You are playing with them.

—I do not know why Senator Bonner is interjecting. He has always said, both publicly and otherwise, that he believes in land rights. He has criticised the Premier of Queensland and he had criticised that other famous person, the man who is now in charge of police and local government and who is introducing laws that will take us very close to being a fascist dictatorship. Why is Senator Bonner doing this tonight? It is unbelievable.
—I am not ashamed of my record. I question yours, though. At least I would question your motives.

—I am not going to get personal about this. If Senator Bonner wants to get personal, I think he is being idiotic. This is an important Bill. Senator Missen referred to the resolution carried by the Senate, and he was right. The Labor Government of the day made certain alterations, at the suggestion of the then Opposition, including Senator Bonner, so that the motion would be acceptable to both sides of the House. That motion was carried unanimously. We will be repudiating that if we continue to postpone a decision on land rights. It is true that the churches now are coming in and backing the Aboriginal people of Australia. The only problem is that they have come in about 150 years too late. Nevertheless, I am delighted to see that they all doing it, and I congratulate them on their attitude. Two reports were received two or three years ago. One was the report of a commission set up by the Queensland Government and it was a whitewash of the current separate laws. The other was 'Beyond the Act', which was produced by two groups of people, including the Aboriginal Legal Service. It is a very good historical work and is a very clear claim for land rights in Queensland.

SPEECH.PARA: I must again be slightly critical of Senator Missen. He said: 'Let us give them just one last chance'. One last chance in that State has been coming for 20 years. If we give them one more last chance they will keep this situation going for another 20 years.

TALK.START.PARA: —That is up to us.

—If Senator Missen can beat them on one last chance, hear, hear, good luck. Let me trace a little of the history, and then I propose to refer to the amendment clause by clause. That will be my contribution to this debate. Dealing with the abolition of the Acts, I go back to 1884, when there were separate laws in Queensland for blacks and whites. The law introduced at that time, when I think Sir Samuel Griffiths was Premier, was tightened up a little in 1897 by some amendments. There were a number of other amendments, but two Acts covering Torres Strait Islanders and Aborigines were introduced in the late 1930s. Probably the worse Act ever introduced was the one put foward in 1965. Its by-laws and regulations virtually placed Aborigines and Torres Strait Islanders in the position of animals, not human beings. Senator Bonner would know that after the demonstrations and the strike that took place at Yarrabah and Palm Island in 1957 people were banned from both settlements for 20 years. Some of them never got back. In fact, the Yarrabah people were not allowed back until 1972, when a Labor Government was elected.

SPEECH.PARA: Let us look at what the Premier of Queensland has done in relation to land rights. First of all, and I have a copy of this, a Cabinet minute initiated by him and distributed to his Cabinet said that no Commonwealth officer of the Department of Aboriginal Affairs was to speak to any senior person in any of the departments in Queensland unless the permanent head of the Department of Aboriginal and Islander Advancement and/or his nominee was present. That requirement was introduced by the Premier. When we tried to buy Archer River, and the person who owned the pastoral lease was happy to sell it to the Commonwealth Department of Aboriginal Affairs, the sale was blocked by the Premier. No sale was allowed. When a group of Aborigines wanted to buy a very small parcel of land in the Ayr district to set up a caravan park that would have kept at least two or three families in a good living, that too was blocked because the Queensland lands commission happened to be the owner of the land. It is all very well for the Premier to say: 'They can go into the market to buy land.' What Aboriginal family can afford to pay $50,000, $60,000, $70,000, $80,000, $90,000 or $100,000 for a small farming property? With the exception of the Seven Emus property in the Gulf of Carpentaria, what Aboriginal family can afford to pay $250,000 or $500,000 for a pastoral property on a freehold basis? They cannot do it, and the Premier knows they cannot do it. This is his way of locking out the blacks in Queensland.

In the days of the Labor Government there was an ex-Anglican mission station called the Gorge outside Mossman housing a small colony of Aborigines. Some of them were brought there from the old Daintree River area. The old people who were brought there in the 1930s were infested with hookworm and they all died out. However, the policy on the station is one of assimilation. The Queensland policy is to get rid of that reserve-a beautiful 60 acres of mountains and rivers-sell it to a tourist organisation. The dwellings are decrepit, and they are nothing more than huts. I do not know whether Senator Bonner has ever seen them, but they are a disgrace to humanity and a disgrace to any government, national or State. In the days when Senator Cavanagh was Minister for Aboriginal Affairs he wanted to rebuild those houses, but permission was refused by the Queensland Department of Aboriginal and Islander Advancement and the Queensland Government. He then made an approach on behalf of the Australian Government to buy seven acres of an adjoining property and to build houses there. This was agreed to by the farmer concerned, but when my close personal friend, Holy Joh, found out about it he applied pressure to this farmer, who was a member of the National Party. The farmer withdrew his offer to sell the land to the Australian Government. Today, in 1981, it is a disgrace to this country, a disgrace to the State Government, and a disgrace to this Government that those people are still living in huts. When they wanted their homes painted they were forced to buy their own Dulux to tidy them up. It was not until six or seven years ago that they were allowed to have electricity. At that time they were getting it from the one white-owned house in the community. It was distributed through one of those multi-point systems to some of the lights. It is a wonder that somebody was not killed by that unofficial type of electric wiring.

We are not going to tolerate that sort of thing; or are we? If this amendment is carried, yes, we are going to tolerate it. The people in the communities in Queensland want land rights now. They do not want them in the never-never. They do not want them next year or the year after or in 10 years time, and they are no longer sitting back and copping it. I am sorry that when Senator Bonner went to Palm Island he would not talk to a mass meeting because he said it was an unofficial meeting. That is a very great tragedy.

TALK.START.PARA: —That is a complete untruth. I addressed the meeting, despite the fact that the chairman of the council said that it was illegal. You know that is an untruth.

—The chairman of the council was not there. Who cares? I went there and I talked to an illegal meeting, and I will do it again any time I need to do it. What makes it illegal, anyway? If the people want to ask questions, if they want to be told something, they are entitled to have any politician who goes there talk to them. That area is a hotbed of people looking for land rights, and so are Yarrabah and Kowanyama and a number of other settlements, including those in the Torres Strait Islands. They are in ferment, waiting for a lead from this Government to get their land rights. I refer briefly to the clauses of the amendment proposed by Senator Bonner and Senator Missen. I hope that it is not carried. I hope that when the time to determine the motion for the second reading arrives this Senate has enough intestinal political fortitude to support the original Bill introduced by Senator Ryan, legal warts and all. Let us tidy those up with amendments.

SPEECH.PARA: We have to realise that we are not dealing with just one part of Australia. My personal friend, Johannes Bjelke-Petersen, has taken Queensland out of Australia. There is no such thing as the Queen of Australia in Queensland; she is the Queen of Queensland. That is the attitude with which we have to live. There is no such thing as democratic law. Laws are produced in Queensland which enable people to go into any home without a search warrant. When the new legislation is passed there will be no freedom of speech, there will be no freedom of movement and no freedom of congregation. That is the way it will be in the last decade of the twentieth century.
Clause (a) of the proposed amendment states:
its announced intention to repeal the Aboriginal and Torres Strait Islander Acts . . .

I know that Senator Missen has treated this matter very kindly, but there is a very real fear that the Commonwealth Games will be boycotted by African nations because of Queensland's attitude to Aboriginals and Torres Strait Islanders. The games have already been negated because the Queensland Premier sent a telegram to Mr Muldoon congratulating him for letting the Springboks into New Zealand, where approximately 2,000 people were arrested because they opposed that decision. The Springboks are now in America. They played their first match there behind closed fences and only about 250 people turned up to watch. They happened to be trusted people. The black community was insulted. In addition to that, the Queensland Premier sent a telegram to Indonesia when it invaded Timor which meant, in effect: Get into them; clean them up. That is what happened. There were thousands of Indonesians in Timor with guns and bombs and the Timorese were cleaned up. That incident is a great blot on Australia's history. But the biggest blot on our history is the activities of the Queensland Premier.
Clause (b) of the proposed amendment states:
What consultative processes it has undertaken and completed to ascertain the desires of the Queensland Aboriginal and Torres Strait islanders . . .

Those consultative processes have all been held. The Premier and his permanent head and a couple of friendly Aborigines sat down with sandwiches in the back room of the Taj Mahal. That was their consultation. There will not be another one. The Premier will not allow it because 90 per cent of the blacks in Queensland want land rights. They do not want to fiddle around like this.
Clause (c) of the proposed amendment states:
the alternative legislative and/or administrative steps it now proposes to take, in accordance with the expressed wishes of the local communities . . .
The local communities are not going to be allowed to express their wishes. They have never been allowed to express their wishes. If they do express their wishes, the local council is sacked.
Clause (d) of the proposed amendment states:
What legislative and/or administrative steps it proposes to take to provide effective self-management . . .

The Queensland Government does not propose to take any such step. The Premier has already said that if any militant decides he is not satisfied with the decision of the Queensland Government the Aboriginals will not get self-management. They will not get any sort of land. They will not even get a 50-year lease.
I hope that my colleagues in the Senate will not accept this amendment, that in fact they will have second thoughts and allow the Bill to go through, political warts and all, as it now stands.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Bonner Sen N.T.

TALK.START.PARA: — This evening the Senate is debating the Queensland Aboriginals and Torres Strait Islanders (Self-Management and Land Rights) Bill introduced by Senator Ryan of the Opposition. This Bill provides for the granting of self-management and traditional land in Queensland for the benefit of Aboriginals and Torres Strait Islanders, and for other purposes. If I recall correctly, Senator Ryan, when introducing this Bill and making her second reading speech, asked that we debate it in a bipartisan way. That was to her credit. I wish that she had consulted with the previous speaker so that we all could have adopted that attitude. I am sure my colleagues on this side have endeavoured to do that until this point in time.

SPEECH.PARA: I am on record as saying publicly, and I repeat it this evening in this chamber, that I totally support the concept of this Bill. The Bill is long overdue. The granting of land rights to Aboriginal people in some States of this Commonwealth is long overdue. The Commonwealth Government, in its wisdom, has been able to achieve land rights for the Aboriginal people in the Northern Territory. I am proud to say that I played a small part in bringing that about. South Australia, to its credit, under a Liberal government, has given land rights to Aboriginal people in that State. We have all heard about the tribal Aboriginal people who now have a substantial amount of land in South Australia. But in our State of Queensland this has not been achieved up until now.

While I say that I support the Bill in principle, there are a number of parts of the Bill with which I am not completely happy. I suggest that this Bill be stood over for a period, as suggested in the amendment moved by my colleague, Senator Missen. I seconded that amendment. This will give us time, as my colleague has already said, to examine the Bill in much more detail and to have more expert advice and counselling in relation to it. This possibly will enable us to do something about those parts of the Bill that I and my colleague have some concern about, as does the Minister for Aboriginal Affairs (Senator Chaney).

What we are talking about is not land rights such as those that have been achieved in the Northern Territory. What we are talking about is an area in the State of Queensland that has been set aside as Aboriginal reserves since 1890 or thereabouts. I have taken the trouble, through the Parliamentary Library, to have produced a reproduction of a map of Queensland which outlines the areas and the communities that this Bill is talking about, or at least should be talking about. Look at the total Queensland area of 1,727,000 square kilometres. The reserves we are talking about occupy a mere 75,000 square kilometres or approximately 2 per cent of the total area of Queensland.

TALK.START.PARA: —None of it is new land.

—None of it is new land, as the Minister has said. We are not seeking to usurp the squatters, to use the old term, or the pastoralists, as we fondly refer to them today in some cases, or the cattle stations, the sheep stations, the grain farms or some of the small towns such as Laura or Cooktown or other places. No, we are not talking about usurping land from people in those areas. We are talking about land that has ben set aside for over 100 years as reserves for Aboriginal people.
—It is rather superior to the 7,000 hectares in New South Wales, isn't it?
—Indeed it is. That is the area that we are talking about, and that is land which has been set aside for a great number of years as reserves for Aboriginal people.

SPEECH.PARA: I think we need to have a small lesson in history. It might enlighten some of my colleagues on the other side of the chamber and it might also enlighten some honourable senators on this side of the chamber. Let us ask why that 7.5 million hectares, or 75,000 square kilometres of land was set aside for Aboriginals. It was not set aside of the goodness of the heart or the generosity of previous governments. It was set aside for Aborigines for a quite different purpose altogether. It was set aside so that the authorities could herd the Aborigines into communities, not because of their grave and great concern for them but for administrative convenience. What happened was that many Aboriginal tribes which normally occupied those lands and lived in separate communities, because they were separate tribes, were herded together. This caused tremendous problems for the Aboriginal people over that 100-odd years. It was done for administrative convenience so that the government of the day and the authorities knew where the Aboriginal people were. It was not done as the Act at that time stated, to protect the Aborigines.

Senator Keeffe, who is so knowledgeable about these Acts, did not even know the name of the Act. It was the Aborigines Protection Act, so called. Protection from what? In my opinion it was not in the true sense for the protection of the Aboriginals; it was to protect the whites from marauding blacks, as it were. That was one of the reasons for the setting up of these communities and for the setting aside of these lands. But the government of the day did not set the Darling Downs aside. It did not set any of the seaboard aside-land that was valuable for agriculture or for building towns. No, at that time it set aside what was considered to be worthless land. The land was no good for agriculture-growing citrus, grain or anything else. It was set aside for Aborigines, as I say for the third time, for administrative convenience-to keep the Aborigines where they could be kept under control.

Apart from the herding of Aboriginal tribes into these communities, there was another way of handling Aboriginal people or, to use the unfortunate terms that the Premier in Queensland has used on occasions, to get rid of the radicals. In those days they had different meanings from that used today. In those days we did not call them pinkos or commos or radicals, but immediately an Aborigine raised his voice in protest against some authority, he was picked up by the protector of the town or village, who happened to be the police officer wherever he lived, put into the local gaol and transported under escort to one of these communities, where he would remain until the authorities felt that he was behaving himself enough to go back and live in the broader community. Sometimes they were never returned to their communities. Descendants of Aboriginals who were forced on to the communities are still living there. They are the descendants of a number of generations. I can name some of them for the edification of some of my colleagues here today. Four people on Palm Island are descendants of people who were sent there- and they happen to be my sons Patrick, Kenny, Peter and Tony. They are the descendants of the late Mr Jim Banfield, who was forcibly put on to Palm Island by the authorities under these Acts that are now, thank God, not with us any more. All down through those years these kinds of things happened. I have seen them happen. I also know the people who were involved in getting rid of Aboriginal people who for some reason wanted to speak up against authority. Those reserves are still there.

Over the last 10 to 15 years, as in the past, many Aboriginal people raised their voices and asked for the repeal of the repressive Aborigines and Torres Strait Islanders Acts. The term that was used at that time by some of them was 'smash the Act'. This campaign has raged for many years but, more specifically, over the last 10 years. All down through those years I have cautioned against this so-called smashing of the Act. I have done that at great cost to myself. I am not talking about finance or economics; I am talking about the great cost to myself. I was called an Uncle Tom and a traitor and many nasty names by both Aborigines and non-Aborigines because I dared to caution against the smashing or the repealing of this repressive Act. I could see, more particularly since I had become a senator, the dangers for the Aboriginal people in the State of Queensland if that Act was repealed or if it was smashed.

The Government in Queensland has finally listened to the voices of the people who were calling for the smashing of the Act. Senator Keeffe, who sits opposite, was one of the leaders. Senator Georges, who is asleep, was another one of the leaders screaming for the smashing of the Act. Now that the Act is being repealed and we can clearly see the dangers, a different tune is being played. The repeal of that Act and the repeal of the Act that governs the lands go side by side. No one has told us yet what is going to replace the Act when it is repealed. We have heard speculation and some statements by the Premier of Queensland that when he repeals the Act he will give 50-year leases to the communities. But he has also gone on record as saying that the communities will not be allowed to become havens for radicals.

We get back to the days I spoke about. The authorities had a different method of handling radicals in those days. They pushed them and shoved them into a community where they were confined at the pleasure of the authorities of the day. We have a different method now. Now we threaten Aboriginal people by saying: 'We will give you a 50-year lease but the communities will not be allowed to become havens for radicals'. Does that mean that if a 50-year lease were given to the Aboriginal community on Palm Island and I, who have been called by Ministers of State in Queensland and by the Premier, a radical, a pinko, a little Afghan camel driver and such like, were to go there the lease could be revoked?

What security of tenure is that to any people? What security of tenure would that be to any local government authority? I wonder what the local government of my city of Ipswich would say if the Queensland Government were to say: 'Look, Alderman Freeman'-who happens to be the mayor of that town-'we will give you a 50-year lease on this place'? What would he say? How could he do any forward planning? What could he do with that community? But that is supposed to be good enough for Aboriginal people.

I never have and I never will settle for leases. I will speak out and do whatever I can to reject them and to prevent that from happening to Aboriginal people-the race I am proudly a member of. I will speak up at any cost to myself to prevent that from happening.

TALK.START.PARA: —It would depend. A long term lease with no conditions to a land trust might be adequate.
—It might be acceptable to some people.
—It might be.
—But that is not what we want for the people. We want the same rights as have been given to our tribal brothers and sisters in the Northern Territory. That is what we want.
—What is the purpose of the amendment?

—I will come to that. Be patient. I am giving a bit of a history lesson. The honourable senator might learn something. I think it important that we understand what we are talking about. I have outlined the reasons why the areas of land were set up and I have spoken about the repealing of the Act and all the things that I think are important to what we are talking about in this chamber this evening.

SPEECH.PARA: I am concerned that the Queensland Government has not yet made any kind of firm statement. Negotiations that have been going on between the Commonwealth and that State lead me to understand that the Queensland Government will be doing something in a reasonably short time. We do not know what it will do but I want to wait and see. In spite of some of the situations that have arisen in my State, I want to be fair to the Government of Queensland and give it a chance to tell this chamber, to tell the Commonwealth Government, to tell the people of Australia, to tell the people of Queensland but most importantly to tell the Aboriginal people of Queensland exactly what it intends to do. I want to see what kind of legislation will be brought down; I want to see what kind of regulations accompany that legislation; and I want to see exactly what the Queensland Government is offering the Aboriginal people in regard to these reserves.

I do not think the passing of this Bill tonight will be helpful in any way. I think it will be counter-productive. I do not want to see the State Government or the Premier of Queensland pushed into a corner where they will throw up their hands. They would get a lot of support in Queensland because people would say: 'This centralist Government again did not wait to see what we would do. We could have done something better'. They might do something worse, too, but once we know exactly what is to be done we can make the moves that I believe will ensure justice for the Aboriginal people of my State of Queensland.

The amendment moved by my colleague Senator Missen and seconded by me I believe represents the right approach to this whole mess in which we find ourselves. I think we can truthfully and honestly say we are approaching this problem in a bipartisan way. We can say, and I can say to the people of Queensland, that we are giving Queensland the right to make whatever moves it intends to make and to inform us as to what it is going to do. I think the amendment spells out exactly what needs to be done. The amendment states:
(1) the Bill be deferred to enable the Queensland Government to advise the Senate and the Australian people of the specific proposals of that Government on-
It then lists paragraphs (a) to (e). Paragraph (a) states:
Its announced intention to repeal the Aboriginal and Torres Strait Islander Acts and to amend the Queensland Lands Act in order to abolish Aboriginal reserves in Queensland;
I think that spells out what we understand the Queensland Government intends to do. Paragraph (b) states:

what consultative processes it has undertaken and completed to ascertain the desires of the Queensland Aboriginal and Torres Strait Islanders, who presently reside on reserve lands, for land rights and self-management of their own communities;
We are talking about self-management, not self-ruin. I am afraid that some clauses of the Bill make me suspicious in that regard. The amendment goes on to state:

(c) the alternative legislative and/or administrative steps it now proposes to take, in accordance with the expressed wishes of the local communities, to provide Aboriginals and Torres Strait Islanders with land rights or other effective security of tenure of lands now constituting the reserves and of other traditional lands to which they have proper claims;
(d) what legislative and/or administrative steps it proposes to take to provide effective self-management for Aboriginal and Torres Strait Islander communities in Queensland; and
(e) the date or dates on which such legislative and/or administrative action will be completed, and

(2) if no such advice has been received by the Senate by 29 October 1981, the Bill be restored to the Notice Paper, and the second reading be an Order of the Day for the first sitting day after 29 October 1981, and that such Order of the Day take precedence of all other business on the Notice Paper for that day.

I can see nothing wrong with the Senate carrying that amendment. As I understand it, the Government is not unhappy with it, but I cannot see why the Opposition and the Australian Democrats would be unhappy with it. Senator Missen has made a statement, and I intend to make the same statement myself. The statement reads:

Senator Missen and I have chosen, in our amendment, the date of 29 October, 1981 for receiving advice from the Queensland Government of its legislative and administrative intentions in relation to Aboriginal reserves, lands and self-management. From information we have received, we believe this is more than ample time for that Government to make its intentions clear. There have been suggestions, not confirmed, that this Parliament may complete its session before that date and we agree with Opposition senators that the vote on this Bill in the Senate should be completed in this session. However, we are advised by the Clerks that it is not appropriate to insert any alternative date in the amendment, but it can be achieved by vote of the Senate and by undertakings of procedural support. Consequently Senator Missen and I assure the Senate that, in the event of any proposed closure of the session before 29 October, or in the event of any earlier action being taken by the Queensland Government that might prejudice Aboriginal rights under this Bill, then we will support any procedural steps that may be necessary to bring on the Bill for vote before the closure of the session.

I was under the impression earlier in the piece when we first told people that we were proposing to move this amendment that the Australian Democrats had no real problems with it and that we could rely on their support. As I understand it-I may be wrong; I hope I am-that support has now been withdrawn. If that is the case and this amendment is defeated I want to say quite categorically, firstly, that I will not be supporting the second reading of this Bill and, secondly-I have the full support of Senator Missen-that in the event that the terms of this amendment are not achieved by the Queensland Government I give the Senate, the people of Australia and my fellow Aborigines in Queensland the assurance that my colleague and I will re-introduce this Bill, if Senator Ryan does not want to do it, or we will introduce a private member's Bill of our own that will achieve what we believe is in the best interests of the Aboriginal people of Queensland.

TALK.START.PARA: —That's right.

—I give that categorical assurance and my colleague Senator Missen now supports me. In the event of the Queensland Government not adhering to the terms of the amendment we jointly will re-introduce either this Bill or a Bill of our own.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Ryan Sen S.M.

TALK.START.PARA: —I rise to speak to the amendment moved by Senator Missen and Senator Bonner and to indicate that the Opposition will be opposing this amendment. Before I proceed to explain why I would like to thank Senators Missen and Bonner for the contributions they have made this evening. I believe that for the most part what they have had to say endorses my initiative and underlines and reinforces the arguments that I, and the Australian Democrats, have put to the Senate about the need to have Commonwealth legislation of the kind outlined in the Queensland Aboriginals and Torres Strait Islanders (Self-Management and Land Rights) Bill 1981. It is only a matter of regret to me that having made such important and informative contributions regarding the situation in Queensland, both from the legislative expertise of Senator Missen and the personal life experience of Senator Bonner, that they have still concluded that they want to delay consideration of this urgent matter.

SPEECH.PARA: I gather from the contributions of Senators Bonner and Missen this evening, and indeed from the contribution of the Minister for Aboriginal Affairs (Senator Peter Baume) in the second reading debate, that their objections are not really to the substance of the Bill but to the timing. I make clear for the sake of the record that as far as the substance is concerned I have been open to, and still am open to, any constructive suggestions that will improve the Bill either in its efficiency of operation or in its clarity of intention. The Minister knows this. Senator Bonner and Senator Missen know this. Indeed, Senator Missen has come to my colleague, Senator Evans, with some suggested areas for amendment. By and large, these will be accommodated by our amendments at the Committee stages of the debate. The more significant amendments were foreshadowed tonight by Senator Evans. I have given a complete list of these amendments this evening to the Minister so that he can assure himself that the legal difficulties that have been raised have been addressed by way of prepared amendments.

We cannot accept the Missen-Bonner amendment this evening because it would postpone the Bill and delay action in an unjustifiable way. We have been asked, and asked again tonight, why the rush? I answer again: A combination of facts makes this initiative an urgent one. There is the frequently stated opposition of the Premier of Queensland to land rights. This opposition has been adverted to tonight on both sides of the chamber. What are we waiting for? We know the Premier of Queensland is totally opposed to freehold title. That is the first issue. Secondly, the past record of the Queensland Government establishes that it is prepared to legislate overnight to obstruct the wishes of Aboriginal people. There can be no argument about that. The degazettal of the reserves at Aurukun and Mornington Island in 1978 shows that the Queensland Government can and will, at any time convenient to itself, introduce unilateral State legislation totally contrary to the express desire of the Federal Government. I cannot take comfort from the suggestions tonight of Senators Missen and Bonner that they will make sure that if the Queensland Government does the wrong thing they will revive this initiative. We have seen the Fraser Government, with what we believe were the best of intentions, out- smarted by the Premier of Queensland over the degazettal of those reserves. We believe that is how he will act again. We must forestall him. The Minister said: 'We will insist on four criteria being met'. We have heard these criteria read out again by Senator Missen. They are acceptable criteria except they do not insist on a commitment to freehold title.

Why should we wait until the Premier announces the details of a leasing system when our commitment and the commitment of the Australian Democrats is to freehold title? If we are forced to wait, what is the advantage? I hope the Minister will address himself to this point; if we are forced to wait then Mr Bjelke-Petersen's leasehold system, whatever its details, will be simply one more system that the Commonwealth will have to dismantle to pursue freehold title. Such a dismantling would accelerate that very State-Commonwealth confrontation that Senator Baume insists he wants to avoid. Such a confrontation will only be avoided if the Federal Parliament is prepared to insist at this stage, prior to any State legislation, that freehold title is its objective. If we voted on the second reading tonight in support of the legislation-with Government support-that step would provide a clear sign to the Premier of Queensland that the Federal Government was seriously committed to freehold title in Queensland and that anything less than that would be unacceptable.

TALK.START.PARA: —You know that won't happen, don't you?
—But the Government will not do this, as the doomsayer Senator Missen interjected.
—I am right, aren't I?

—Well, it is Senator Missen's Government. I am sorry to have to say this but the amendment moved by Senators Missen and Bonner tonight is a capitulation to the Premier of Queensland. It is a decision--
—It is good sense and you know it is.

—It is capitulation to the Premier of Queensland; that very person whose sins have been recounted at great length tonight by Senator Missen and Senator Bonner themselves. And here we have an amendment which capitulates to him. It gives him time and breathing space to express his contempt for Aboriginal aspirations in legislative terms. I believe we must now act to demonstrate the willingness of the Federal Government to secure land rights. We must demonstrate this willingness before Queensland acts and not after. Why is the Federal Government unwilling to demonstrate its intention? It is suggested by some honourable senators opposite that they have such an intention, but they will not demonstrate the intention.

SPEECH.PARA: The matter of the Commonwealth Heads of Government Meeting has been raised. Senator Baume in his speech at the second reading accused me of having all kinds of political motives in respect of timing in relation to CHOGM. I think it is time to question the cliche that I am acting out of political motives. What are political events for? How are they justified unless as a forum in which to advance a just cause? CHOGM is a political event initiated by a politician, the Prime Minister of Australia (Mr Malcolm Fraser) and attended by other politicians, the leaders of Commonwealth countries. It is a political forum, and a costly one. How is it to be justified unless as a forum for the advancement of just causes? Similarly with the Senate, we are all politicians here, though Senator Baume likes to pretend otherwise. This is a political forum. It is not an operating theatre or surgery, Senator Baume. Senator Baume is not here in his capacity as a doctor; he is paid to be here as a politician and so am I and so is every other senator in this place. I am advancing, as a politician, in a political forum, a cause I judge to be a just cause for the Aboriginal people. Any other description of what is happening is completely dishonest.

TALK.START.PARA: —It is the timing.

—I do not believe that the Minister really misunderstands the situation. I was not persuaded by what he had to say in the second reading debate that he had any serious objection to the content of the Bill. I must comment on a particularly unpersuasive aspect of the Minister's speech; that was the section of the speech in which he attempted to refute my criticisms of the current management provisions of the Queensland reserves. Surprisingly, the Minister went to some pains to claim that self-management, equal pay, and equal rights under the law already prevail on the Queensland reserves.
—I didn't say that at all. The Hansard record will show what I said.

—The Hansard record will show that the Minister attempted a defence of the situation of the Queensland reserves. I am pleased that the Minister is resiling from this tonight. I point out that if there is any doubt in the mind of any honourable senator about the unsatisfactory nature of life on Queensland reserves we need only refer to the judgment in the Supreme Court of Queensland last week regarding the conviction of a person who grew up in the reserves, Alwyn Peter. I believe this was a very humane and progressive decision because for the first time the actual destructive environment of life on the Queensland reserve was taken into account and mitigated the sentence afforded. Let us have no pretence that there is anything other than a totally unsatisfactory situation prevailing on Queensland reserves today.

SPEECH.PARA: The Minister talks about the need for co-operation and consultation. In principle, who would object to that? But he is wrong to suggest that, in dealing with the Queensland Government, co-operation and consultation are going to achieve our aims. Let me remind the Minister and the Senate of what has happened in the past. Both the Whitlam and the Fraser Governments attempted to assist Aborigines in Queensland through consultation and co-operation with the Queensland Government. That Government remained intransigent. It refused to co-operate. This is evidenced by the actions of both Federal Governments in passing Federal laws aimed at assisting Aborigines in Queensland, despite the Queensland Government and that Govern- ment's outright opposition to Aboriginal self- determination.

The Aboriginals and Torres Strait Islanders (Queensland Discriminatory Laws) Act 1975, the Racial Discrimination Act 1975 and the Aboriginals and Torres Strait Islanders (Queensland Reserves and Communities Self-Management) Act 1978 all attempted to protect Aborigines from the Queensland Government. They were all passed against the wishes of that Government. The major reason why these Acts were not more successful is that they did not provide for what has come to be regarded as a prerequisite for Aboriginal self-determination-land rights, secure tenure to their land. In our view that means freehold title. Therefore, successive Federal governments have tried consultation and co-operation with the Queensland State Government. It has not worked. We have tried legislating without making provision in respect of land. That has not worked either. Thus Senate committees, churches, numerous international experts on racism, lawyers, jurists, and so on have all examined the situation and the consensus is that to enjoy self-determination Queensland Aboriginals need secure title to their land, but the Queensland Government is not prepared to grant it.

The Minister for Aboriginal Affairs spoke of the fact that Queensland Aboriginal and Islander People are being consulted now, but there is no doubt whatever as to what those people want. Evidence for that exists in the survey published in the book by Malezar, Foley and Richards Beyond the Act. I will not describe that survey again because, conveniently, Senator Missen has already described it for us tonight, but it shows that the overwhelming desire of Queensland Aboriginals is to obtain freehold title. Yet the Minister wants them to wait. His Government is supposed to support land rights, but not now. His Government's policy is supposed to be self-management, but he is not prepared to listen to the Queensland Aborigines, at least not now.

Government senators have insisted tonight that we must wait to see what the Queensland Government will do. They read the papers, listen to the radio and watch television. Perhaps they even get Mr Bjelke-Petersen's Press releases. If so, they will know that the Premier of Queensland has given his final word on the granting of land ownership to Aboriginals and Islanders for their reserves. His final word is no. The Premier has ruled that option out completely. He has also apparently ruled out perpetual leases. In July of this year he gave a very clear outline of the system which will operate in Queensland after the abolition of the Queensland Act and the reserves. He stated:

Tenure will be initially for 50 years, 20 or 30 years longer than for normal grazing titles. Residents will be required to satisfy improvement conditions, such as fencing and land clearing 'the same as those applying to grazing properties'. Black communities will not be able to claim mineral rights 'as mineral resources belong to the Crown the same as on any other lease.' 'Militants' will be discouraged from the new leasehold.
Where would Senator Bonner stand then? He stated further:
An annual rental will be charged but 'the reserve residents will not be asked for a cash settlement to take over their leases'.
Elected councils representing the reserve population would hold the leases but would be helped by State advisers.
Mr Bjelke-Petersen explained-he was referring to the Aboriginals-that 'they are not losing control because they never had control over their land'. Of course, there he is quite wrong.

When the Minister for Aboriginal Affairs said in his speech of 16 September: 'It is simply not true to suggest that this is some kind of last chance to win recognition of land rights in Queensland,' and said that Queensland had been moving progressively, even if very slowly, in changing its legislation and administration of Aboriginal Affairs, I was quite astounded. I do not deny that the Queensland Government has effected some small changes which have had a little practical effect on the lives of Queensland Aborigines. On the major issues, the principles involved which are important, the attitude of the Queensland Government has hardened.

How can the Minister claim that there has been progress in Queensland when the Government of that State is currently mounting a legal challenge to the Racial Discrimination Act which will probably end up in the High Court? This challenge was prompted by the very same problem that we are discussing tonight, the Queensland Government's refusal to allow a group of Queensland Aboriginals to own land. That group was attempting to buy the land. That negates Mr Bjelke-Petersen's argument that Aborigines should, just like any other Queenslanders, buy land if they want it. They are not even allowed to do that.

The plain fact of the situation is that Mr Bjelke-Petersen will not allow groups of Aboriginal people to hold land because he fears they may obstruct the development of mining or tourism on the 2 per cent of land for which they seek immediate land rights. Therefore, Mr Bjelke-Petersen will not give Queensland Aboriginals secure title to their reserves. He will abolish the reserves, abolish what protection exists in the Queensland Act and grant leases on conditions that will allow their revocation by the Queensland Government. If Queensland Aborigines do not concur with the wishes of the Premier as to what is to happen on the reserve lands, he will not hesitate to revoke their leases. One does not need a crystal ball to work that out.

TALK.START.PARA: —Whose statement were you quoting from then?

—I was quoting the conditions which the Premier announced in his July statement and then I added my own comments. These are the reasons why the Bill must go ahead now. All other avenues have been tried and have failed. Also, the Bjelke-Petersen Government is moving towards creating a situation in which further encroachment upon Aboriginal reserves is facilitated by a lease system which can be revoked. The Minister knows that Mr Bjelke-Petersen can act very quickly when he wants to, as he did in 1978. Unless the Commonwealth acts now to protect Queensland's Aboriginal reserves it may be too late. I ask the Minister to say what steps he could take if we are unsuccessful tonight and the Government's amendment is successful. What would he do if overnight the Premier of Queensland brought in a system of leaseholds? What steps would he be prepared to take then? It is absolutely untenable to accept the argument that it is better to wait until the damage is done and then try to fix it up rather than to take preventive action now.

SPEECH.PARA: I want to make something clear with regard to the timing of this measure in relation to that of the Commonwealth Heads of Government Conference. We do not wish to see the Australian Government humiliated and downgraded at that conference. In fact, our view is the opposite of that. The Australian Labor Party truly wishes to see Australia applauded by other Commonwealth leaders for taking action on this vital issue. What better way is there to demonstrate to Commonwealth leaders that Australia will not tolerate the oppression of its indigenous people any longer than by making a decision to support this legislation. It is a golden opportunity for the Prime Minister to demonstrate his good faith to the indigenous people of this country in a most appropriate forum. That is what we wish to see happen. If the Goveernment wishes to avoid Australia being condemned at CHOGM and violent confrontations occurring, of the type which the Minister's senior adviser, Mr Perkins, has predicted will mar the Commonwealth Games, I urge it to support this Bill.

The Minister has argued that the legislation could be challenged by the Queensland Government in the High Court, that the Federal Government could lose and therefore we should not proceed with it. This is a specious argument. If the Commonwealth's legislation were successfully challenged in the High Court, the Federal Government would have demonstrated that it was prepared to use every avenue to obtain self-determination for Queensland's Aborigines. It would then be time to proceed, as we did in 1967, to approach the people of Australia to grant the specific power that we needed.
