In my view, of course, the exercise would not fail but if it did all would not be lost. We could proceed to another referendum. So to say that because we might fail we should not try really amounts to an expression of political cowardice. The Queensland Aboriginals want land rights and want them now. To vote for anything else in the Senate tonight would be to break faith with the Aboriginal and Islander people of Queensland.

For that reason, I believe that we should defeat the amendment moved and proceed to vote on the motion for the second reading of the Bill. I remind the Minister for Aboriginal Affairs that, that having been done, it would be open to the Senate in the Committee stage of the Bill, whenever the Government wants to bring on that stage, to set about improving the Bill along the lines Senator Missen has suggested improvement is needed. We will be totally co-operative at that stage, as indeed we have endeavoured to be co-operative at this stage. We are trying seriously to provide the Government with an opportunity to make the decision which, sooner or later, it will have to make. We cannot go on forever pretending that these matters will be resolved by hostile State governments. So why not take this opportunity? The legislation is available to us, the Committee stage of that legislation could be available to us, to advance the cause which nearly all honourable senators have said they wish to advance. Mr President, I foreshadow that we will oppose the amendment moved by Senator Missen and seconded by Senator Bonner. We urge honourable senators to proceed tonight to give a positive vote on the motion for the second reading of this Bill.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Bjelke-Petersen Sen F.I.

TALK.START.PARA: In speaking to this Queensland Aboriginals and Torres Strait Islanders (Self-Management and Land Rights) Bill 1981 tonight, I must say that if Senator Ryan cannot accept the amendment moved by Senator Missen I certainly cannot accept her Bill on a matter of principle. This Bill is an attempt by the Australian Labor Party and its Australian Democrats allies to set themselves up not only as the de facto government of Australia but also as the de facto government of Queensland. The people of Queensland have not given the ALP or the Australian Democrats a mandate for introducing this legislation. What really concerns and frightens me is that this move is unconstitutional. The ALP claims that the 1967 referendum gave the Commonwealth power to make laws for Aboriginals. That is not disputed. But that referendum did not give the Commonwealth power to take land, nor did it give it power to make other moves that are contemplated.

SPEECH.PARA: The matter before us concerns the Aboriginal people of this country. I remind the Senate that the Democrats and the ALP plan to introduce also private member's Bills to give this Parliament power to prevent sand mining on Moreton Island. What we are really considering here is a very serious constitutional question. Minority groups are trying to use this Senate to force their will on democratically elected State governments. What in fact they are saying is: 'Queensland won't do what we want, so you make them do it'. In case any honourable senator feels that this is a good opportunity to do in this Senate what he or she cannot do at the ballot box-that is, to defeat the Premier of Queensland-let him or her reflect on the fact that, whilst it may be Joh today, it surely will be their State governments tomorrow.

TALK.START.PARA: —Mr President, I raise a point of order. I am doubtful about the validity of the speech being made; it appears to be written by the Premier. But the situation is worse than that. The honourable senator is reading her speech. I draw your attention to Standing Order--

—There is no point of order. If one were to look around the chamber one could point to many honourable senators whose speeches are made from very copious notes. There is no point of order. I ask you to resume your seat.

—Thank you, Mr President. I noticed that Senator Ryan also was using copious notes. Minority groups, including the Democrats, are introducing private member's Bills. We are now to have a Senate select committee inquiring into issues related to the South West area of Tasmania. I think that to do that is to usurp the authority of the Government of Tasmania. After all, why hold a referendum if that is to happen? Mr President, I seek leave to continue my remarks later to allow a small amount of formal business to be attended to.

SPEECH.PARA: Leave granted; debate adjourned.

INTERJECT.SPEAKER: The PRESIDENT

TALK.START.PARA: —I inform the Senate that I have received letters from the Leader of the Government in the Senate, the Leader of the Opposition and the Acting Leader of the Australian Democrats nominating senators to be members of select committees on Government Clothing and Ordnance Factories, South West Tasmania and Private Hospitals and Nursing Homes.

INTERJECT.PARA: Motion (by Senator Peter Baume)-by leave-agreed to:

That the Senators indicated, having been duly nominated in accordance with the provisions of the resolutions passed on 23 September 1981 and 24 September 1981, be appointed members of the respective committees:
Senate Select Committee on Government Clothing and Ordnance Factories-Senator Button, Crichton-Browne, Martyr and Siddons;
Senate Select Committee on South West Tasmania-Senators Archer, Hill, Missen and Siddons;
Senate Select Committee on Private Hospitals and Nursing Homes-Senator Haines.

DEBATE.TITLE: QUEENSLAND ABORIGINALS AND TORRES STRAIT ISLANDERS (SELF-MANAGEMENT AND LAND RIGHTS) BILL 1981

PROCTEXT.PARA: Debate resumed.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Bjelke-Petersen Sen F.I.

TALK.START.PARA: —As I was saying, I feel that this idea of minority parties having a Senate select committee set up to inquire into issues related to South West Tasmania when the Tasmanian Government plans to hold a referendum on the matter is a waste of time and money. Next we will have those minority parties wanting to introduce Bills to make Sir Charles Court do whatever they want him to do concerning the Darling Ranges, to stop Mr Tonkin from building a petrochemical plant at Redcliff and to stop Mr Everingham from allowing uranium mining in the Northern Territory. Why should minority groups be able to tell elected governments what to do? Each of those governments was properly and democratically elected.
—Not in Queensland.

—I beg the senator's pardon; the Queensland Government was properly and democratically elected. It holds a majority of votes in that State. The National Party holds a majority of the vote in the seats within the Queensland coalition. The Queensland Government has been re-elected with more than 50 per cent of the total vote at every State election since 1957. It has a clear mandate from the people of Queensland for its policies. The ALP cannot claim it has that mandate. It has constantly been defeated at polls, both State and Federal, in Queensland. Yet this Bill seeks to override a democratically elected government.

SPEECH.PARA: I invite honourable senators to look at the Bill. It is a blatant, transparent political ploy designed purely to embarrass Mr Fraser and the Federal and Queensland governments on the eve of the forthcoming Commonwealth Heads of Government Meeting. Senator Ryan has admitted that publicly on television. The ALP is only interested in point scoring and looking after its own interests. In my opinion and in the opinion of many Australians, to the ALP the situation of Australian Aboriginals is quite secondary to this Bill and the debate it has generated. I fail to see how anyone can take the honourable senator's Bill or the ALP seriously. Her introducing this Bill really is an unnecessary misuse of her position as a senator and of the trust people have placed in her by voting her into the Senate.

TALK.START.PARA: —I raise a point of order, Mr President. A similar point of order was raised earlier by Senator Keeffe and in response to it you indicated that you believed that Senator Bjelke-Petersen was speaking from copious notes. I think that you might unintentionally have created a precedent in doing that. What Senator Bjelke-Petersen is doing quite openly and, to use one of her terms, quite blatantly is reading from a prepared speech. She does it blatantly because she has set herself up a rostrum of books so that she can read quite easily the speech that has been written for her. It has been a practice in this place that honourable senators, especially those who have no immediate responsibilities such as those of a Minister or for that matter a shadow Minister, shall not read his or her speech.

—Senator Georges, I have taken on board what you have said and I would say there is no point of order. I suggest to Senator Bjelke-Petersen that she use copious notes and that perhaps she may prefer to hold them in her hand rather than leave them in front of her on her desk.

—I foreshadow further that I shall ask her to table the notes from which she is reading because it is fairly clear to me from where I stand that she is reading a speech that has been prepared for her, and I will seek--
—Order! There is no point of order. I have ruled. I call Senator Bjelke-Petersen.
—Thank you, Mr President. As I said earlier, I noticed that the previous speaker also was reading from notes, but apparently that was quite all right.
—Order! I suggest you address the Chair, Senator.

—Thank you, Mr President. All I say is that even the Minister for Aboriginal Affairs has conceded that the Queensland Government has done a lot for Aboriginals. My husband in his early days when he was working in the area during the war had Aboriginals in our Cherbourg electorate working for him. They were fed and clothed. They came to work and they lived in the house. I wonder whether Senator Georges has ever looked after the members of an Aboriginal family, had them in his home, fed them and had them working for him. It is all very well to talk about theory but I am talking about facts. The funny part about it, Mr President, is that they kept coming back year after year. We have the Cherbourg settlement in our electorate. All I can say is that it is a very fine electorate. We know the people there very well. We have many dealings with them. We go there quite often.
—What happened to their petition?
—I had nothing to do with their petition.
—Who put it in the rubbish bin?

—Senator Walsh had better write a letter about that and find out. All I say as far as looking after Aboriginals in Queensland is concerned is that at the end of the war when Aboriginals from the far north of our State were at Woorabinda Joh spent a lot of his time and a lot of his money going up to search out another area for them in which to live. At that time the Lutheran Church took them from Woorabinda, where they were located, up to Hopevale because they wanted to go there. This to me is a demonstration of practical care for the Aboriginals. I would like to know whether Senator Ryan and Senator Georges who keep on interjecting have done anything similar for Aboriginals, other than talk about them. That is all they have done. They are very great on talking about these things. It is funny that they should complain about Queensland's treatment of its Aboriginals, yet the Aboriginals want to stay at these settlements, such as the one at Cherbourg; they do not want to leave. The same applies to all the other settlements throughout Queensland. As the Minister himself has said, the treatment of Aboriginals in Queensland is the best treatment of Aboriginals throughout Australia.

SPEECH.PARA: They are some of the points that I especially wanted to bring to the notice of the Senate this evening. I feel that it is very important indeed that the Senate give some consideration to these facts. As far as Queensland is concerned, all the hot air we have heard so far on this issue from alleged Aboriginal spokesmen has come from non-elected, self-appointed spokesmen and I certainly question their credibility. That is why I have brought these matters to the attention of the Senate this evening.

I feel that the Bill is a very devious and very sharp two-edged sword. Because of the constitutional dangers that I have spoken about I think Senator Ryan must think about what she is doing in this matter. If the Bill is passed, I feel it will bring in its train demands for curbs on the powers of the Senate and this Parliament to interfere in the Federal system. Our Federal system rests on the willingness of the partners to recognise each other's rights and responsibilities. The serious constitutional issue involved in this Bill far outweighs the subject. I urge the Senate to reject the Bill.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Macklin Sen M.J.

TALK.START.PARA: — The amendment moved by Senator Missen and seconded by Senator Bonner to the motion that the Bill be now read a second time proposes that the Bill be set aside until 29 October. The purposes of the amendment as set out in paragraph 1 (a), (b), (c), (d) and (e) are unexceptionable. I think there has been agreement on the part of all honourable senators who have spoken that indeed this is the position. There has been agreement in the second reading debate that there is no dispute on the principles involved. In this sense I think it has been an excellent debate and a very useful debate. We have at last come to an agreement on the basic principles of land rights. However, I think we are still in dispute on the technicalities of how this matter ought to be approached and what is the best time frame in which it ought to be dealt with. I think we should as far as possible work within those limits.

SPEECH.PARA: Unfortunately, the amendment is based on one inherent fallacy, which I think was well expressed by Senator Bjelke-Petersen, and that is that the Queensland Government will acquiesce in any way in a motion of the Senate.

TALK.START.PARA: —That is not assumed at all.

—That is assumed unfortunately, Senator Missen, because the amendment suggests that the Queensland Government will actually do something in October rather than say 'we will defer our consideration until November'. The Queensland Government is quite at liberty to make the statement that it will introduce legislation not in this session of Parliament but in the next session of parliament. Therefore it does not have to acquiesce in any motion of the Senate, and it has not done so in the past.
—I acknowledge that we could not ask the Senate to delay.

—Right. The situation is that if this Bill were to achieve a second reading tonight, which is unlikely, when we return to this place on 13 October the Bill will still have to go to the Committee stage in those weeks in October which constitute the time frame which has been proposed by Senator Missen and by Senator Bonner. So I do not know whether there is such a wide range of disagreement even in terms of tactics. We hope that in that event it may very well be that we can reach a compromise in relation to the time frame involved. If the question of the time frame is taken out of the second reading debate we will have among all senators who have spoken almost total agreement on the principles in this Bill.

SPEECH.PARA: I seek leave to continue my remarks later.
Leave granted; debated adjourned.

TALK.START.PARA: —Pursuant to the provisions of the Audit Act 1901, I present the report of the Auditor-General upon financial statements prepared by the Minister for Finance for the year ended 30 June 1981 and upon other accounts.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Robertson Sen E.A.

TALK.START.PARA: —by leave-I move:

SPEECH.PARA: That the Senate take note of the report.
I seek leave to continue my remarks later.
Leave granted; debate adjourned.

DEBATE.SUB1.TITLE: Presentation of Papers-Joint Committee on the Australian Capital Territory: Report on Energy Use, Distribution and Consumption-Order of Business

INTERJECT.SPEAKER: The PRESIDENT

TALK.START.PARA: —Order! It being 10.30 p.m., under Sessional Orders I put the question:

INTERJECT.PARA: That the Senate do now adjourn.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Chaney Sen The Hon F.M.

TALK.START.PARA: —I seek leave for the Senate to deal with the items on the Order of Business, paragraph 10, Presentation of Papers.

SPEECH.PARA: Leave granted.

TALK.START.PARA: —Senator Reid is to present a report, Senator Archer is to present a report, and I will table the papers. The relevant motions can then be moved.

SPEECH.PARA: Papers are tabled in accordance with the list circulated to honourable senators. I seek leave to have the list incorporated in Hansard.
Leave granted.

TALK.START.PARA: —Mr President, I raise a point of order. The time is now after 10.30 p.m. You put the question that the Senate do now adjourn. That motion has not been resolved.
—The motion has not been put, but leave was given to table the papers.
—You are now suggesting that we are going to have presentation of reports.

—To avoid any misunderstanding, let me say that, following discussions with other senators, I sought leave to deal with the items in paragraph 10 of the Order of Business, namely, Presentation of Papers. Mr President, you had already tabled the Auditor-General's report upon financial statements. There are two Senate committee reports to be presented and some papers are to be tabled by Ministers. Because no one rose to deal with reports, I stood up and, in accordance with the leave which had been given, tabled the papers on the list. I understood that Senator Robertson would now move that the Senate take note of the 22 papers which have been tabled.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Robertson Sen E.A.

TALK.START.PARA: —by leave-I move:

SPEECH.PARA: That the Senate take note of papers Nos 1 to 22.
I seek leave to continue later my remarks in connection with each paper.
Leave granted.
Motion (by Senator Chaney) proposed:
That the resumption of the debate be made an order of the day for the next day of sitting.

TALK.START.PARA: —The question is that the motion be agreed--
—I wish to speak to the motion.

—Senator Georges, I suggest that you resume your seat until such time as the Chair stops speaking. You are entitled to take a point of order afterwards but not to take it while the Chair is addressing the chamber. The question is that the motion be agreed to.
—I wish to speak to the motion because the methods that have been used here tonight have prevented debate by any honourable senator on any of the papers that have been presented.
—No; and it was done by agreement.

—The debate will be adjourned and the papers will go on to the Notice Paper and take their course. It means that at this time a person cannot speak to any of those papers. That is not a procedure we should accept.
—You could have refused leave.

—I did not refuse leave. I would have thought that the proper procedure was to negative the adjournment question and proceed with the business. That was not done. All I am suggesting is that in future we should negative the adjournment question, present the papers and allow any person who wishes to speak to a paper to do so.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Chaney Sen The Hon F.M.

TALK.START.PARA: —in reply-There was no wish to destroy the amity and comity of the Senate. By arrangement, it was agreed that this would be done in the adjournment debate. I agree that one could just as easily have negatived the adjournment question and dealt with it in that way. I am sure that the Opposition Whip and the Government Whip will take note of the comments of Senator Georges and I will bear them in mind in any future arrangements which have to be made. It was desired to clear these papers. For example, there are reports which people wish to have made available. The agreement of all parties in the Senate-the independent senator, the Australian Democrats and the Opposition-was sought. The matter was handled by leave, as matters are so often handled in the Senate. The honourable senator has indicated that he thinks that a better procedure could have been followed. I note his comments and ask the Government Whip to do so also.

SPEECH.PARA: Question resolved in the affirmative.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Reid Sen M.E.

TALK.START.PARA: —By leave-On behalf of the Joint Committee on the Australian Capital Territory, I present the report on the Committee's inquiry into energy use, distribution and consumption in the Australian Capital Territory, together with extracts from the minutes of proceedings and the transcript of evidence of the Committee.

SPEECH.PARA: Ordered that the report be printed.

TALK.START.PARA: —I seek leave to make a statement relating to the report.

SPEECH.PARA: Leave not granted.

TALK.START.PARA: —I seek leave to incorporate a statement in Hansard.

SPEECH.PARA: Leave not granted.

TALK.START.PARA: —I will read it out. The report I have just tabled deals with the subject of energy in the Australian Capital Territory.
—Order! Senator Reid, you have no right to speak on the presentation of the report without obtaining the leave of the chamber. Leave was denied earlier.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Chaney Sen The Hon F.M.

TALK.START.PARA: —I will explain the situation. Arrangements were made ten minutes before the adjournment to ensure that certain papers would be tabled. The arrangements were specifically in terms of the list. Reference was then made to the papers referred to in paragraph 10 about committee reports. I want to make it quite clear that there was no intention to do anything without the agreement of the various parties in the Senate. That agreement was expressly sought and obtained. The present position is that Senator Reid has presented the report of the Joint Committee on the Australian Capital Territory which was presented in the other place in the normal course by another member of the Committee, Mr Fry. In accordance with normal practice, the same statement was put down this afternoon in the House of Representatives. The honourable senator, having reached the point of presenting the report, would be entitled in the adjournment debate to read the statement.

SPEECH.PARA: That seems to be a fairly pointless exercise from the point of view of the honourable senator and the Senate. It would simply mean that, in accordance with the normal situation, the report of the Joint Committee on the Australian Capital Territory was tabled and the same statement was put down in both chambers on the same day. It was, of course, open to the Opposition or any member of the Senate to refuse leave for the procedure that was followed. If the procedure is one which does not please honourable senators, no doubt it will not be followed again. I want to emphasise to you, Mr President, and to the Senate that what was being done was being done by leave, after reference to all parties in the Senate, and therefore, as I say, any objections are objections which really ought to lie to the future rather than to the present. I suggest to the Senate that Senator Reid has a perfect right to read the statement now if the Opposition or anybody else wishes to deny leave to incorporate it. But it would save us all a little time if she were to be allowed to incorporate it.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Robertson Sen E.A.

TALK.START.PARA: —I should like to offer an explanation in connection with the arrangements. I think it is fair to say, without putting it too strongly, that there has been some disorganisation within the Government ranks today, and that there has been an attempt between the Whips and the various Ministers at the table to allow the business of the Senate to proceed. My understanding of the arrangements that were to be made was as follows: Firstly, there was to be one select committee brought in and that was to be the committee on the Bendigo ordnance factory, because we have four members for it. We now find that two committees were brought in, the Bendigo committee and, I understand, the South West Tasmania committee.
—No; the full membership of one of the committees and some of the members of the others. So the others have not been brought in in toto.
—That indicates exactly what I am saying. It is quite clear. I will continue, and come back to that.
—The agreement was not breached.

—If we put four committee members on that means that that committee can now meet, and so for three weeks there will be no Australian Labor Party representatives on that committee. There was an agreement that this would not go ahead. Obviously there can be some lack of communication. But when this sort of thing happens it tends to throw the credibility of those sorts of discussions into some doubt. Let me say quite clearly that I believe that the discussions I have had with the Government Whip represent what I am saying, and I would exonerate him from any involvement in any changes that were made.

SPEECH.PARA: We were then told that we were going to have the President put down a statement and then we would have 22 papers put down. It may be that I am a little thick and did not understand all of this. But quite clearly we would not be too happy about people coming into this chamber and putting down a statement to go with a paper, whether it is incorporated or not-incorporation would give it certain publicity-without our being given the opportunity to respond to it. Let us face it. We are pretty gullible on this side. We go along with a lot of the things that the Government does. But it seems to me that we cannot operate unless we have reasonable arrangements. I think that the Government once again, as it has done so often in the past, has tried to put one over on us. I do not think that is good enough. We cannot operate as two Whips unless what we decide in consultation goes ahead; otherwise we lose our credibility with our colleagues. I lose credibility with honourable senators on this side, and my colleague loses credibility with honourable senators on the other side.

We have taken the papers Nos. 1 to 22. These were put down so that the Minister at the table could have one of his papers presented and there could be debate about it. There was agreement that these would be brought on on the Tuesday we returned to the place. I did not hear mention of this. Those matters were adjourned to the next day of sitting, and I can understand my colleague's reaction. I would rather the Minister had agreed, when he stood up, that these papers would be brought on on the next day of sitting in the full sense of the word-in other words, the Tuesday when we resume. I would hope that the Minister can now say that we will have no more business tonight and that there will be no more attempts to bring things in on the adjournment. We are going to be very wary of coming in on this practice at a later stage. After the Minister has made his statement, as was the general suggestion, the thrust of the arrangements, the Senate will then adjourn.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Kilgariff Sen B.F.

TALK.START.PARA: —Unfortunately there has been some misunderstanding in the Senate over the last few minutes. Perhaps I should support some of the words of the Opposition Whip, Senator Robertson. I indicate to the Senate just what happened. In the first place it was decided, with the agreement of all, that the debate on the Queensland Aboriginals and Torres Strait Islanders (Self-Management and Land Rights) Bill should continue until the adjournment at 10.30. Honourable senators will realise, too, that during the day the Select Committee on the Government Clothing and Ordnance Factories has been set up. All the nominations from the Australian Labor Party, the Australian Democrats and the Government have been received. As there had been some restriction on the reporting time of this Committee, it was felt that another two weeks delay in its formation would cut into its time of investigation. So, it was agreed by all that before 10.30 p.m. the Select Committee should be set up.

SPEECH.PARA: It is unfortunate that the formation of the Select Committee on South West Tasmania is incomplete. The reason for this is that the various parties associated with it have not put in their nominations. I think the Minister for Social Security (Senator Chaney) and everyone else would agree with me that nominations have been received but that they mean absolutely nothing. The formation of the Select Committee on South West Tasmania cannot be completed until all the nominations have been received. I assure honourable senators that while one particular party has indicated its nominations this will mean nothing at all until the Committee is formed in two weeks time.

I refer now to the reports that have been tabled. I have given an assurance to the Opposition Whip and to honourable senators who discussed this matter in the last few minutes that the reports will be noted and debate on them adjourned. I assure the Senate that these reports will be available for debate on the return of the Senate in two weeks' time. There is no suggestion that these reports are being put aside so they cannot be brought forward for debate. I have given honourable senators an understanding of what has happened. Nothing is hidden; there is no suggestion of trickery. It is a straight out arrangement. There is no time lost in respect of the formation of the Committee. The Committee cannot act until--

TALK.START.PARA: —It can act.
—Senator Coates makes the point that it can act. I give an assurance that nothing will be done until the nominations to the Select Committee are completed.

—It is unfortunate that arrangements which were made obviously between the two Whips have broken down in this way. I certainly hope it does not happen again. It is unfortunate that Senator Reid was embarrassed to a certain extent. No one on this side of the House was told that Senator Reid's report would be brought in. I just do not understand how this sort of thing can happen. I certainly need considerable assurances from the Government side of the House on the Select Committee on South West Tasmania. It is beyond me why the nominations for that Committee were introduced at all. We also saw the extraordinary situation of the nomination of Senator Haines on the Select Committee on Private Hospitals and Nursing Homes without any nominations of Government or Labor Party senators. It is of concern to honourable senators on this side of the House that the four members on the Select Committee on South West Tasmania can form a quorum and can run away for a couple of weeks and do all sorts of things.
—I can assure you that we will not meet.

—I dare say. Knowing Senator Missen, I will accept that assurance. But why on earth do it? Why on earth embarrass the Whip in this way? I do not want to get to the stage where we may have to have written agreements between Whips on such matters. It seems to me that in the future we may have to have written agreements if extra reports are going to be added to the ones we have arranged and if extra committees are going to be added to the ones that were previously arranged. I suggest that the Government ought to get its house in order so far as these arrangements are concerned or there will be no satisfactory arrangements between sides at all.

—I raise briefly the question of the proposed presentation of papers as I think it is of some importance to the Senate. Over a period of years the Australian Democrats have fought over and over again for the principle that when papers are presented there should at least be an opportunity for honourable senators to make some sort of comment on them. It is a fact that most papers can perhaps wait. But if we allow the Government the precedent here on the last day before we adjourn for a lengthy period of bringing in a whole list of papers, no matter what they are, and not allowing them to be discussed by honourable senators for another fortnight because there is no time to do so, we are going to have a situation--
—Your Whip was party to it.
—Excuse me, Senator. I am expressing my view as a senator.
—But your Whip was party to it.
—Are you trying to make some kind of point to me?
—Not at all. Just recall that your party was consulted.

—If the Minister will forgive me, I will proceed to make the point which I began with, which, as he knows, I have spoken about in this place from time to time over a number years and which I will speak to again now, with his permission. The time will come eventually when the Government will store up some extremely important papers and drop them on us in a circumstance like this, have them publicised and have us in a situation where we will not be able to say anything about them for two or three weeks, by which time they will no longer be of interest to the community, when a purely government point of view or some specious view is put forward in a paper without honourable senators having any opportunity to discuss it here. That is a situation which I think we certainly ought to guard against. I am glad of the opportunity of bringing this matter to the attention of the Senate.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Baume Sen The Hon P.E.

TALK.START.PARA: —It has been put to Estimates committees by honourable senators that where possible the annual reports of the departments should be available when the estimates of departments are being examined. I do not intend to suggest that a twenty-third paper be tabled tonight, although it is within Standing Orders for me to do so. Papers can be tabled at any time by Ministers. The estimates for the Department of Aboriginal Affairs are to be examined tomorrow. Late this afternoon the Government Printer delivered the annual report. It would have been our intention, under more felicitous circumstances to have tabled that report so that honourable senators on Senate Estimates Committee G could have had the annual report of the Department available for the estimates examination, as was requested by committes. When the report is not available I ask honourable senators to understand that I could have sought leave to table it tonight but I do not intend to do so.

SPEECH.PARA: Question resolved in the affirmative.
Senate adjourned at 10.54 p.m. until Tuesday, 13 October, at 3 p.m.

PROCTEXT.PARA: The following answers to questions were circulated:

QUESTION.SPEAKER: Button Sen J.N.

TALK.START.PARA: asked the Minister representing the Prime Minister, upon notice, on 6 May 1981:

QUESTION.PARA: (1) What are the details of all cases of Commonwealth revenue being foregone in departments of the public service as a result of Government imposed staff ceilings, which are disclosed by the March 1981 Auditor-General's Report.
(2) What is the estimated loss to the Commonwealth in each situation.
(3) Is it necessary to have accurate information with regard to this issue in order to make informed staffing and expenditure decisions if there are no adequate estimations of the amount lost.
(4) What has already been done to correct the situation and what is proposed to be done.

(5) Will the Government dishonour those commitments in the Review of Commonwealth Functions particularly those relating to 2 per cent staff reductions if those commitments cannot be met without costing the Government more in revenue forgone than they save in salaries not paid.

ANSWER.SPEAKER: Carrick Sen The Hon J.L.

TALK.START.PARA: —The Prime Minister has provided the following answer to the honourable senator's question:

ANSWER.PARA: (1) to (4) The Auditor-General's report refers to specific areas of activity where departments and authorities advised there were staffing difficulties. I am advised by the Public Service Board that these difficulties were in the context of work and staffing priorities. In most of the cases referred to in the Auditor-General's Report remedial measures have been taken to overcome the problems mentioned. These measures were, in the main, the introduction of alternative management methods, technological processes. the re-distribution and more efficient handling of workloads, and the overcoming of recruitment difficulties. In the remaining few cases existing staffing priorities appeared to be justified, having regard to factors such as normal backlogs, costs and convenience to the public.

(5) In taking decisions on staff ceilings the Government expects that departments and authorities should give proper regard to revenue protection in Government operations. This will remain the case following recent staff ceiling decisions, including the average 2 per cent reduction in areas subject to staff ceilings. Should Ministers be of the view that the ceilings set cannot be achieved or are inconsistent with Government policies the Government has established appropriate machinery for reviewing such cases.

QUESTION.SPEAKER: Archer Sen B.R.

TALK.START.PARA: asked the Minister representing the Minister for Transport, upon notice, on 9 June 1981:

QUESTION.PARA: Has the Air Transport Group section of the Department of Transport received any requests from either of the two major domestic airlines to withdraw from or vary any of their present F27 routes within the Victorian-Tasmanian Region.

ANSWER.SPEAKER: Messner Sen The Hon A.J.

TALK.START.PARA: —The Minister for Transport has provided the following answer to the honourable senator's question:

ANSWER.PARA: No formal approach has been made to the Department of Transport. However, I understand that East-West Airlines and Trans Australia Airlines have successfully negotiated the takeover of some of TAA's F27 services by East-West including Albury/Melbourne and the Tasmanian services. I also understand it is intended that these routes be transferred on 1 February 1982.

QUESTION.SPEAKER: Walsh Sen P.A.

TALK.START.PARA: asked the Minister representing the Minister for Communications, upon notice, on 19 August 1981:

QUESTION.PARA: (1) What fee or commission is paid by the New South Wales Lotto organisation to the Australian Postal Commission.
(2) By what means was this amount determined and does it differ from the amount paid by Lotto to its private agents.
(3) What is the duration of any contract entered into between the Postal Commission and the Lotto organisation.
(4) Under what legislative authority has the Postal Commission entered into its present arrangements with the Lotto organisation.

ANSWER.SPEAKER: Baume Sen The Hon P.E.

TALK.START.PARA: —The answer to the honourable senator's question is as follows:

ANSWER.PARA: (1) The commission paid to Australia Post by the New South Wales State Lotteries Office varies with the type of Lotto entry lodged but it is considered to be a matter of commercial confidence between agent and principal.
(2) The rates of commission payable are determined by the New South Wales State Lotteries Office, and are understood to be set on a common scale of rates paid to its agents.

(3) Australia Post has signed an agreement with the New South Wales State Lotteries Office to provide Lotto agencies at specified post offices for as long as the arrangement is acceptable to both parties.

(4) Australia Post is authorised to enter into arrangements to act as agent for Federal and State Government departments and authorities, under the provisions of section 12 of the Postal Services Act 175. The New South Wales State Lotteries Office is an authority of the New South Wales Government.

QUESTION.SPEAKER: Walsh Sen P.A.

TALK.START.PARA: asked the Minister representing the Minister for Communications, upon notice, on 19 August:

QUESTION.PARA: (1) On what date did the Australian Post Office become an agent for New South Wales Lotto.
(2) On whose authority was this decision made.
(3) Did the Lotto organisation make the initial approach to the Postal Commission, or did the Postal Commission approach Lotto.
(4) Have any other organisations been invited to use, or have any sought to use, post offices as agents for private business including gambling.
(5) Does the Postal Commission act as agent for other private business undertakings.

ANSWER.SPEAKER: Baume Sen The Hon P.E.

TALK.START.PARA: —The answer to the honourable senator's question is as follows:

ANSWER.PARA: (1) 17 October 1979.
(2) The decision to enter into the agency agreement with the New South Wales Lotteries Office was made by an officer delegated by the Australian Postal Commission.

(3) Australia Post responded to a newspaper advertisement, placed by the Director of State Lotteries, New South Wales, which invited applications from organisations and persons interested in becoming official agents for Lotto in New South Wales.

(4) No. Australia Post is not empowered to act as agent for private business organisations under the terms of section 12 of the Postal Services Act 1975. Some organisations have approached Australia Post for this purpose, however.

QUESTION.SPEAKER: Chipp Sen The Hon D.L.

TALK.START.PARA: asked the Minister representing the Prime Minister, upon notice, on 25 August 1981:

QUESTION.PARA: (1) How many letters or representations has the Prime Minister received concerning proposals to dam any more rivers in South West Tasmania.
(2) What parts of the country have the letters or representations come from and do they support or oppose the damming of any more rivers.

ANSWER.SPEAKER: Carrick Sen The Hon J.L.

TALK.START.PARA: —The Prime Minister has provided the following answer to the honourable senator's question:

ANSWER.PARA: (1) About 4,300 representations to date.
(2) Representations have been received from all States and the percentage for each State is shown below:
per cent Victoria 77.5 New South Wales 12.4 Tasmania 6.1 South Australia 2.2 Queensland 1.3 Western Australia 0.4 Northern Territory 0.1
These representations generally oppose the damming of any more rivers in South West Tasmania.

QUESTION.SPEAKER: McClelland Sen The Hon D.

TALK.START.PARA: asked the Minister representing the Minister for Transport, upon notice, on 26 August 1981:

QUESTION.PARA: Has any projection been made of the likely surge in unemployment that is likely to occur, particularly in non-metropolitan areas, as a result of the Government's decision to contract by tender road works on national highways rather than have them carried out by State of local government authorities.

ANSWER.SPEAKER: Messner Sen The Hon A.J.

TALK.START.PARA: —The Minister for Transport has provided the following answer to the honourable senator's question:

ANSWER.PARA: The claim of major unemployment caused by the Commonwealth's decision to require all national road construction work to be put to tender is pure speculation. It should be realised that State Government and local government councils are free to tender for national road construction projects and that staff can be redeployed from national road construction to maintenance work and projects on arterial and local roads. In addition national road construction works commenced by day labour prior to 1 September 1981 will not be affected by the new tender provisions. Consequently the Government will not speculate as to any impact on the labour market in this instance.

QUESTION.SPEAKER: Bolkus Sen N.

TALK.START.PARA: asked the Minister representing the Minister for Science and Technology, upon notice, on 8 September 1981:

QUESTION.PARA: (1) Were any purchases made or contracts entered into by the Minister's Department or authorities with the Minister's responsiblity, with McLeay Bros., Pty. (2) Will the Minister provide details of all such purchases or contracts.

QUESTION.SPEAKER: Jones Sen G.N.

TALK.START.PARA: asked the Minister for National Development and Energy, upon notice, on 9 September 1981:

QUESTION.PARA: (1) Is the Minister for National Development and Energy aware of a statement by Sir Rod Carnegie in which he claimed that the expected minerals boom is a myth.
(2) Does the Minister agree with this statement; if so, does this alter in any way Government policies regarding resource industries.

ANSWER.SPEAKER: Carrick Sen The Hon J.L.

TALK.START.PARA: —The answer to the honourable senator's question is as follows:

ANSWER.PARA: (1) In a Press release of 1 September 1981, Sir Roderick gave details of the half year shareholders' report for Conzinc Riotinto of Australia Ltd. In this Press release, attention was drawn to 'the constant public references to the so-called ''resources boom'' ' as emotive words conjuring up expectations of immediate profits, at least for some sectors of the economy. It is this picture of development which Sir Roderick has termed 'a mirage'. He was concerned that Australians would attempt to distribute the benefits before the gains existed.

(2) The basic strength of the Australian economy and the opportunities opening up to it through the 1980s are evidenced by the upsurge in actual and forecast levels of investment and an associated rise in investment-related imports. The fundamental competitive advantage that Australia enjoys by reason of her natural resource endowments, particularly in the field of energy, remains unimpaired. This situation will continue, so long as private enterprise responds flexibly and positively to changing economic conditions and Government policies continue to provide the appropriate economic environment.

ANSWER.SPEAKER: Baume Sen The Hon P.E.

TALK.START.PARA: —On 26 August 1981 (Hansard, page 320-321), Senator Hearn asked a question, without notice, about placement of post boxes.

ANSWER.PARA: The Minister for Communications has provided me with the following answer to the honourable senator's question:

Australia Post's policy for the provision of posting boxes at present is that a new box should not be provided within 800 metres road distance of an existing posting facility and that at least 30 articles a day could be expected to be posted in a new box.
The preferred locations for street posting boxes are shopping centres, busy commercial and industrial areas, transport terminals and large institutions such as hospitals.

In reviewing the continued need for an existing street posting box the same general principles apply. In practice, however, only posting boxes receiving less than 10 articles daily are being considered for withdrawal.

When considering the withdrawal of a street posting box, the special needs of aged residents are recognised and taken into account. A street posting box would not, under normal circumstances, be withdrawn if it were located near an elderly people's home or a hospital or other institution which caters to the needs of the aged.

At least four weeks in advance of the intended date for withdrawal of a street posting box, a notice is attached to the box, advising users of Australia Post's intention to withdraw the facility. This gives residents the opportunity to comment on or appeal against the decision. No formal social impact study is undertaken but the following elements are considered:
the needs of the elderly;
the level of inconvenience to the public, as assessed by the distance to alternative posting facilities;
the extent to which the posting box in question is used.
If a posting box has low usage then the level of inconvenience to residents of the area, resulting from removal of the box, would be minimal.

The availability of transport is not a relevant factor when considering the withdrawal of a posting box because, generally, the distance between posting facilities is not great. Furthermore, anyone who resides more than 400 metres from a posting point may give fully stamped, unregistered articles to the postman for lodgement.

Australia Post must certainly consider the cost of maintaining and clearing boxes but its aim is to arrive at a reasonable balance between service and costs. Consideration of provision and withdrawal of street posting boxes is not confined to purely economic terms.
